column1: This game has a lot of potential. I like its style and base mechanics. But it's hard to really see the good parts in this game right now because of some fairly dire problems:
1. Balance. There doesn't seem to be any kind of ""base rate"" these cards are built on. Like
column2: there's a card that increases shield capacity by 1 for 1 energy. Another card charges shields by 10 for 1 energy. Another card makes a 4/2 drone for 2 energy. There's also a card called ""AI Supremacy"" that gives you 10 shield capacity
column3: 10 shield charges
column4: and 4 4/4 drones. Going by the established rates
column5: this card should cost at least 19 (ignoring the fact that it also gives you all these effects in one card). Instead it costs 3. Yes it's ""mythic""... but that should mean it's maybe twice as good
column6: not 6 or 10 times as good. Having cards this strong makes your strategy and the enemy's strategy irrelevant - you just play your card and win. Things won't be perfectly balanced... but I feel like there could be a better attempt here.

column1: 2. Easy Exploits. Like Slay the Spire
column2: it feels like health is a resource that should slowly exhaust through a stage
column3: and most game mechanics here seem to suggest this was the plan. But there's a card that heals you and doesn't ""deactivate"". This means it's easy to kill all but one enemy
column4: shield up
column5: and loop through your deck until you're healed to full. I think there's one for credits too. You shouldn't be able to get these kinds of effects so easily (ie. with a single card and some patience). Learn the lessons of the other games in this space. These cards should exhaust.

column1: 3. Do-nothing events. Whatever is in the mysterious crate
column2: don't have it be nothing. Again
column3: I get this is early access... but I've played the game twice
column4: and it feels like I've opened 6 empty crates. Events don't need fancy graphics or something - just placeholder in _something_.

column2: if I was you
column3: dear reader
column4: and if I was looking for a game to play now - I'd add this game to my wishlist
column5: and come back to it once it has had a little more time to bake. But you shouldn't forget it
column6: because I think it could be good.";4.6;1.0;252.0;493.0;Posted: 28 March

column2: FTL meets slay the spire.

column1: HUGE potential here. I think a few things need reworked.
1. Balance: jmzero's review goes in depth.
2. No discard pile: this i feel is an odd design choice
column2: since there's no discard pile
column3: all cards used immediately go back to the deck
column4: so attaining any new card is a constant lower percentile of getting any card in your deck on every turn. So you may never see your new card in play...ever. Since the deck is *shuffled* every turn. This is poor design
column5: you cant structure synergy here
column6: as you are constantly threatened to draw the same cards over and over. This just feeds into the balance problem
column7: of ""just grab the most OP cards and scrap the rest""

column2: nailed most of it. I will add shields (especially after unlocking a particular ship) are VERY exploitable. You can turtle up
column3: create drones forever
column4: and heal any dmg that gets by.

column1: 4. All events: now jmzero went over the crates. however
column2: many ? events are lackluster. you find a trader...repair your ship...get fuel...sell fuel...etc. the only promising one is the temple ruins
column3: but even that is just a choice of getting more credits at expense of fuel and hp
column4: 5 times. Also to add to the crate
column5: it doesn't help that the literal ""do-nothing"" iteration of that event can soft-lock the game!! (had it happen twice where the pop up doesn't go away ever
column6: the event never ends
column7: and i have to alt F4

column2: event
column3: etc. is just slow to show up or finish.

column1: even with these issues i can recommend this considering the alpha state. Potential buyers
column2: i would say if you like FTL and slay the spire and want to support the devs
column3: go for it
column4: otherwise
column5: wishlist it and wait.";9.3;1.0;36.0;292.0;Posted: 27 July

column1: It has the feel of FTL
column2: but plays similar to slay the spire. The biggest turnoff for me
column3: and what ended up causing me to refund it
column4: is that you don't draw from your deck. Every turn
column5: you get 5 random cards out of the cards in your deck. you could get the same hand over and over; it does not cycle through all the cards. For example
column6: In my 21 card deck
column7: I had one copy of a card that boosts the attack of all your active drones and 3 cards that made drones. In one battle (and the battles are decently lengthy) I drew the drone boost card every turn
column8: but never once did I draw a card that made a drone. It was very frustrating. In addition
column9: energy is not saved between turns but shields are (there is a shield capacity)
column10: so you can have totally wasted turns where you draw mostly shields and your shields are already at max so the turn just gets wasted.

column2: I enjoyed FTL and slay the spire but found this to be more frustrating than fun.";0.5;0.0;78.0;1004.0;Posted: 8 April
the game is fun but some things just don't work as you'd expect.

column1: It's less a deck-builder and more a card pool-builder - you have discard & draw mechanics
column2: but cards don't play in any sort of deck order. You can draw the same card in every hand
column3: and never see others even over many turns.

column1: The ability to explore sectors is cool
column2: but it's not very useful and can encourage you to time-waste. Having played this I can understand why FTL has an enemy fleet chasing you. It's quite possible to become self-sufficient (gaining fuel with every battle & self-repairing) and clean out an entire sector
column3: but there's little value to doing so - you'll have loads of money without anything useful to spend it on and just see the same two groups of enemies over and over.";36.3;1.0;15.0;693.0;Posted: 10 January

column1: Ultimately disappointing. Listen to other popular negative comments. They're right.
This game struggles from extreme balancing issues. I wouldn't even bother picking this up until they're fixed

column2: Summit Reviews
column3: to see more high-quality reviews regularly.

column1: Indie made. Space-faring roguelike. Futuristic sci-fi setting. Procedurally generated 2.5D star map. Turn-based strategic exploration. 2D side-on
column2: turn-based card battler. Ship vs ship tactical combat. Session only deck-building. Requires constant deck management. RNG can cause heavy imbalance. Imbalance makes it very challenging. Quality pixel graphics & art. Matched by synth-pop soundtrack. Short on content. Some variety of components. Made to be replayable. Singleplayer only

column1: For the Warp provided a mixed experience which has some surprisingly involved card-driven space combat. However
column2: the hefty use of RNG gives it an unbalanced nature. One that is further complicated by a lack of mechanisms to limit its impact. Some gamers may find its content on the low side
column3: but it has been made to be replayed. Very likely the reason for its steep difficulty curve.

column1: For the Warp is a well made but unbalanced game. Strategic gameplay is good but could do with a few more additions and added variation. Tactical combat is at times an enjoyable experience with several viable strategies and synergies available. However
column2: the substance deck-building possesses is affected by a level of RNG that causes its overall difficulty to rise steeply
column3: detrimentally impacting balance.

column1: This results in a frustrating experience which is why its rating falls from being worthwhile to a purchase
column2: though only just.";17.5;1.0;21.0;923.0;Posted: 10 April
this game has a lot of great features and has some compelling gameplay. However
column3: there are three things that kill it for me because they lead too far down the path of heavy RNG.

column1: 1) The shuffler makes no sense. The fact that you don't discard cards and that every time you draw a hand that you are pulling from your entire deck is against the foundation of what a deck builder game is supposed to be. It has all of the other facets of how to build and manipulate your deck but the player should be drawing from a shuffled stack and continue to do such until the discard pile needs to be shuffled back in. I might have been less opposed to this if you could freely discard cards from your deck without needing to pay for it or have NPC's want to buy them during events. But as it stands
column2: it is far to easy to get a 18-20 card deck and that is far too much RNG when doing pool draws.

column1: 2) Draft mode is not worth playing due to the design of ships and certain cards. Each ship has a core deck archetype that goes with them. To top it off
column2: you are shown 10 cards to pick from
column3: then 9
column4: then 8
column5: etc. While this would certainly be what you would experience playing Magic: the Gathering
column6: the cards do not have enough synergy to interface with each other in this format let alone to build a half way viable starter deck that matches the ship you selected. Also
column7: you select the ship BEFORE you draft which should be the other way around. See what comes to you and what archetype you can build towards then decide what ship you want. The problem stated in #1 compounds this since you might not have that many shield cards and drawing them when you are getting blasted for 40 damage a round in the first map is not a good experience.

column2: there are certain cards you need to make your ship's archetype deck come together and there is no way to guarantee that you get those. As such
column3: it leads to runs that are destined to fail because you
column4: through RNG
column5: just don't power up your deck to the point that you can handle later encounters. Especially when you get screwed by not drawing what you need from your pool (see #1) for several turns.

column1: I like the premise of the game and it has a great foundation. Hopefully
column2: these issues will get addressed by the developer in the near future as I look forward to playing this game after those patches land.";12.2;0.0;16.0;235.0;Posted: 10 January
the theme and general direction this game is taking. Pixel art spaceships and roguelike.....take my credits! But For the Warp (FtW) makes you appreciate FTL
column3: Slay the spire (StS) and many other roguelikes;

column1: I am not enjoying the gameplay right now. It feels very RNG heavy and I'm constantly getting my butt kicked. The first ship is not very good with it's measly shield cap of 10hp and you will routinely run into groups of 3 enemies who hit for 9dmg each a round. Bosses hit for 10-20
column2: and mid sized enemies can also do 10-20 damage. It's very hard to keep your shields up while also putting up an offense. The second ship is immediately better boasting 15shield cap and a ton of attack and draw cards. The game drastically gets more fun in the second ship
column3: but the world is still wonky and not set up in an approachable way. I hope the other ships are cooler still but I don't feel inspired to play more and unlock them.

column1: The grid you fly around on is frustrating. I find I""m getting bombarded with enemies
column2: then bombarded with allied ships but there isn't any way for me to know ahead of time what I will run into. In FTL you could see the whole region and make a guess at which routes to avoid and which ones would be better. In FtW you only know one space ahead and backtracking costs precious fuel. You will run out resources.

column1: In SlayTheSpire you could also plan ahead how many bosses/rests/merchants you'd roughly encounter. In FtW you can't plan at all. I""m often sitting outside the boss gate with 10%hp and not enough fuel to explore for help. Was I supposed to power through in a straight line? How many encounters should I risk for loot? It's incomprehensible.
I miss that in FTL the stations all offered the same services. You could always buy fuel
column2: repair and purchase from a wide variety of weapons
column3: drones and ship upgrades. SlayTheSpire had a similarly good merchant who offered card removal and card upgrades along with his RNG items. FtW could really benefit from stable merchants. The cost of fuel and repair is wildly different and making that last fuel jump to a station that doesn't sell fuel is very frustrating. I could see space games drop fuel as a mechanic if I""m honest.

column1: The merchants in FtW would be better if they had actual selection. Three cards and one equipment is silly small. There are many deck styles you could build in this game. Either make the cards cheaper so that you can buy a large number and design your play deck and side deck
column2: or give the players way more selection. In one instance I had a significant amount of money
column3: and I bought more equipment than I could use
column4: but there is nothing you can do with it afterwards. No merchant buys equipment from you and it's not relevant to any story based encounters. So if you don't plan on using the cards
column5: you can't reliably get rid of them and they don't serve a story purpose....can I send the out the airlock?

column1: Ultimately I want this game to be good but I don't like it right now. I am leaving a down vote so that the Devs see this feedback
column2: but I also hope that other players will play the game in hopes that the devs get the resources they need to continue. I won't be refunding and will keep my fingers crossed that some of my concerns are addressed
column3: or that other improvements are made.";2.1;0.0;19.0;220.0;Posted: 29 March

column2: the draw mechanic is nonsensical. You don't draw a card from the top
column3: you draw it from a pool. So you can miss a card again and again and redraw cards immediately after playing them.

This game is far too barebones currently. There is no real meaningfull synergy. The best way to beat the game is to simply remove cards from your starting deck so that you can fill it with cards that cost 0 and draws 1. It has cards that are too strong like reversing all enemy intents for 0 energy. It becomes more of a war of how much time do you wish to spend on the save rather than how great of play do you do and how interesting of a deck you can build and due to that there are never any exciting moments where you live on a sliver of health. You can tell from the first three battles if this run will be worth doing or not. Its not totally meaningless but it would need quite the rehaul to make it worth playing more than once

I don't think I can recommend For the Warp in its current state (January 2021). After three hours
column2: I already beat the game once after 4-5 tries and I don't have that urge to try and beat the game with the other ships like I do in other roguelites.

column1: Encounters are fairly repetitive with low variance and there doesn't seem to be much variety in enemy types. All enemies seem to do mostly the same thing just with varying HP pools. It's not even close to Slay the Spire where different encounters require you to approach the enemies differently.
Card balance seems a little off. A number of cards seem to require you to get other cards to make them useful
column2: but there's no guarantee you're ever even going to see cards of those types. On the other hand
column3: I have been able to make some broken combos using cards that aren't crap on their own.

column1: There's also poor explanation of mechanics. For example
column2: one card I've seen has the Explosive property. It sounds like it's supposed to ignore X% of armor
column3: but it just says 0% on there. Is there something I'm missing? I also still don't understand how the Synergy keyword works with its vague description. Another card tells me it does more damage for each ""Plasma"" type in my hand
column4: but I don't know how to tell if a card is Plasma type or not. I thought maybe it was if the card had ""Plasma"" in the name
column5: but my starter cards with Plasma in the name didn't seem to count.

column2: the game looks and sounds pretty good
column3: although I do wish cards had more on-screen effects. The game also has a twist on deck building where there is no discard
column4: which I find interesting. Cards you play in a turn immediately get sent back and shuffled into the deck. This causes you to approach deck building a little different than the typical deck building approach where you don't reshuffle until you've played your entire deck.

column2: I think they need to work on card balance and make encounters actually interesting. With every encounter playing out the same
column3: the game gets boring extremely fast.";2.9;0.0;8.0;2352.0;Posted: January 21

column1: I've played a lot of FTL and Slay the Spire as well as many other deckbuilding/exploration/roguelikes. They are my favorite games
column2: and so I was sad that this one missed the mark for me. It looked right up my alley
column3: but the problem was that there was just too much RNG in the way without a lot of time to counter it. I couldn't find the mechanic to scrap cards fast enough so my deck became bloated fast
column4: and I kept running into unavoidable unwinnable fights. I investigated one space and fought some mega-ship that did 30-50 damage a shot. I had the card to escape a combat but I was dead before I drew it.

column1: And why is my starting hand only 3 cards? When there are three ships each swinging for 9 damage on the first round and I draw 3 base attacks it's not much help. Also
column2: 3-9 is not an acceptable range of damage for me to plan around
column3: nor is 10-18. That's too much control for the RNG to have and I'm not interested in continuing to play until the RNG gods deem it appropriate for me to win.

column1: I do like that your shields carry over if you don't use them
column2: but that just means I over-shield every time and only attack when I'm above the max shield. shrink the ranges
column3: or maybe do away with them altogether
column4: but at least shrink them.

column1: I'm more than willing to keep trying and to figure it out
column2: but then there is the issue that the core mechanics were not very fun. I don't see why I need to select my ship in order to shield if I'm the only ship that's there that logically I would want to shield. Explain to me why I have to select a ship to attack if there is only one target. It would be more fun if there was a right-click default action for cards that are obvious on how a general player would use them.
the cutscenes and dialog aren't fast enough for me. Put the text up there
column3: allow me to hit enter to skip it. Every single time you approach something t h e g a m e h a s t o m a k e y o u w a i t t o r e a d t h e d e s c r i p t i o n and it bores me every time. I read fast and I don't play games to be bored. Maybe there's a setting to control this in the options
column4: fine
column5: but whatever the fastest setting in should be the default and there should be a setting to slow it down if you like long-drawn out time to read text because I'm going to go ahead and assume that's the minority.

column1: It's very possible this game could hook people but for me there are too many games out there without these issues

snappier

column1: The card design is extremely simple
column2: the diversity between 'ships' limited
column3: the difficulty is extremely low and
column4: perhaps worst of all
column5: it's so utterly slow.

column2: enemy health/shield pools
column3: and the limited damage output of even your most synergy-dependant
column4: powerful attacks
column5: battles take a very long time by ""roguelite deckbuilder"" standards (though perhaps you may be used to the pace if you've played a lot of Deck of Ashes). But a big issue is that each map - of the 5 you go through for one 'run' of the game - is filled to the brim with enemy encounters and there's very rarely anything stopping you from going through all of them
column6: plus the myriad of beneficial random encounters and 'quest'-like events dragging you back and forth over the map very
column7: very slowly.

column1: I suspect the ""Fuel"" mechanic - as well as your health limits - is intended to prevent you from just fighting constantly for huge quantities of money and other partial benefits
column2: but it fails to function because there are cards that let you easily earn Fuel in-battle
column3: as well as heal in-battle
column4: as well as even permanently remove selected cards from your deck in-battle. As a result
column5: you can easily just leave 1 enemy alive in a battle then spend all of the time you need healing to full
column6: optimizing your deck and restocking your fuel (until the enemy eventually runs away).

column2: a very poor handling of in-battle resources with out-of-battle
column3: run-long resources leaves a glacially paced
column4: unfulfilling and fundamentally boring game
column5: lacking inventive classes
column6: deckbuilding
column7: story or much of anything else. I do give some credence to the aesthetic and theming of the game
column8: but even that runs dry quickly when there appears to be as little as 3 (4?) visually distinct enemies per map
column9: and (not counting bosses) seemingly only about 18 or so types of enemies in the game.

column1: And those 18 enemy types are painfully similar. In fact
column2: same with bosses. Enemies just... attack you for X-Y damage
column3: shield themselves (basically self-heal) for X-Y damage
column4: and... that's actually almost it. Occasionally they will take an offensive action like decrease your max shield or place an absolutely trivial damage-over-time effect to you (like ""1 damage over 3 turns"" at a time when enemies are regularly doing 10-14 damage with regular attacks). Occasionally an enemy may spawn a new enemy which... just does the same thing. Deal X-Y damage
column5: shield themselves for X-Y
column6: or do some minor amount of DoT or max shield decrease.

column1: On top of all of the many issues
column2: even if they fixed the ability to exploit battles to maximize all of your resource gains too easily
column3: your cards are both super slow and yet they easily let you break the game. In my first battle
column4: I was just playing a ""barrel roll"" card every turn rendering me literally immune to damage on each turn
column5: and there seemed to be no penalty or limitation to doing so.

column2: minimal content
column3: minimal variety
column4: minimum difficulty
column5: terrible pacing. This is
column6: sadly
column7: probably the worst deckbuilding roguelike game I've played on Steam.";2.9;0.0;4.0;380.0;Posted: August 15

column1: This one is tough for me and may come across as a negative review
column2: but it really isn't. I absolutely adore the overall idea of this game. A spaceship version of Slay the Spire? Hell yes! However
column3: it often feels like it's deliberately holding the player back from having too much fun.

column1: The game ends a zone or two too soon
column2: right when your build is the most fun to play. The Hardcore mode levels up as you play Normal and Draft
column3: but there's no way to level it back down again. It's stuck at Level 10 for me which makes the first zone nearly impossible out the gate. Speaking of Draft mode
column4: it's my favorite
column5: but some ships are just plain better for it than others
column6: which is sad. I wish each ship had more tangible differences than just the amount of hull/shields it starts with. It's also difficult to build an efficient deck without predictable scrapping opportunities. The shop card offerings are very limited and there's no way to sell back excess equipment. I'm often swimming in credits and loaded down in stuff I don't want but can't get rid off. Definitely detracts from the overall fun of the experience.

column1: Is it worth the price? Sure
column2: but I was really hoping for more longevity from it. I'm giving it a recommend because I've had a good deal of fun with it
column3: but there is a lot of room for improvement. Also

column4: but the developer is on the message boards and talks to his players so hopefully some of these things will get ironed out over time. Honestly

column1: For The Warp has a lot of charm.

column2: the music is fun and appropriate.

column1: But the game is severely lacking in the balance department.
This lack of balance really makes you relinquish any feeling of real freedom that your choices matter; as you can make every ""perfect"" play and you'll still lose pretty quickly.
The difficulty stacked up against you cannot be overstated
column2: and the constant over-powered opponents are a wall too high to climb with skill
column3: as you'll often feel like the encounters you win are due to pure luck.

column1: Attacks have no ""chance"" to hit either-- just a range of damage it WILL do.
You can never actively evade or dodge. You can never attempt to escape an opponent who is too overwhelming for you.
So you're stuck just watching your whole run get blown away due to a random (and seemingly likely chance) you'll see an opponent who just mops the floor with you.

column2: you start the game with 100 coins and can buy from a selection of 3-4 random cards.

column1: You are stuck using your incredibly under-powered deck of actions against opponents which can out-damage you
column2: out-shield you
column3: and have the benefit of numbers on you almost every combat.

column1: You most certainly will run out of fuel EVERY game
column2: as the only way to stay alive
column3: being so severely outgunned all the time
column4: is to try and avoid conflict (and you can't).

column1: You don't make enough money to do anything important
column2: nor will you run across a way to fix your ship's shields.

column1: Running out of fuel will invite even more overpowered encounters to spawn directly on you-- to where you will eventually throw your hands up and put the game back on the shelf.

I can't recommend this game in its current state. It's too unbalanced and you won't want to play very long when you feel like the game constantly ♥♥♥♥♥ you without any determinable merit to the challenge.";0.9;0.0;4.0;353.0;Posted: March 21

FOR THE WARP definitely a game i will be playing for a long time. Its a deck builder where you start out with a bunch of cards which during the course of your journey you can trade or sell for resources such as fuel
column2: new weapons and ship upgrades etc. Card selection is vast and it all makes sense with the science fiction theme and how they play out. Combat is fun where you can win if you play your cards right :) even when it seems the odds against you. Keeping your shields fully charged is very important to prevent physical ship damage. You will meet others in your travels who can provide repairs for something in return or give you fuel when your running low. I think one time someone even did this for free.

column1: When defeating a boss you will unlock a new ship with new gear adding the variety of things that can be done. Maps are areas of space you can cross any way you want while trying to avoid too many hostile encounters as you attempt to get to the warp exit location. The maps are full of random encounters such as distress calls and ruined civilizations where something foreboding happened in the past. You will also come across merchant zones where you can purchase new cards.
Music is good though at the moment i believe there are only like two or three songs. One for exploration and another for combat. Since its early access many are hoping more music will be added.

column2: BUY IT! PLAY IT! Embark on a epic space age journey across the galaxy where futuristic riches await with all their glory and terror!";1.6;1.0;4.0;1469.0;Posted: August 20

column1: 游戏中的资源：钱 油 hp 都有对应的卡可以在战斗中赚到
有些卡的入手时间直接影响你能不能活下去 比如mass driver每场战斗可以让你踢掉一张不在你手牌里的卡 对一些卡组来说越早削薄卡组越早开始血赚
敌人会在大概13回合以后逃跑 暂时不知道逃跑会不会影响掉落质量
比较难受的是一部分增益状态不会显示 比如barrel roll 2费下回合不受直接伤害
然后一回合打出的牌数也是有限制的 没仔细数过 可能在20张左右 也是没有任何显示就说你船过热了不让你出牌
每次过完图会在新地图原地生成一个商店 而只有这个商店的卡牌和装备是无限补充的 所有商店只能访问一次 而地图里的商店提供的服务和货物数目都是有限的 为了赌商店去跑路战斗觉得很不值
装备只有买来堆积 目前没有把不需要的装备换成资源的办法
最亏的是遗迹 亏血亏油 很大概率收获一张商店里能刷到的垃圾
感觉平衡方面还有加强余地 有时候拿不到关键牌可能在普通难度第一关劝退";6.2;1.0;1.0;620.0;Posted: February 28

column1: It's a super well polished approach to the genre
column2: featuring beautiful pixel art
column3: a catchy soundtrack and great game design. The hints of lore in this Alpha version already have me intrigued about all the ""races"" and very distinguishable ship designs
column4: the ""oomph"" of card synergy power is very well executed
column5: the feeling of challenge and the achievement when you beat each of the bosses is on point and it even had me gasping at certain random encounters (that I won't spoil) I did not expect
column6: but have left me further intrigued.

column1: I have only managed to collect a single ""legendary"" grade card so far but it already had me working to build a deck around it and I could not put the game down until I managed to unlock all the ships available so far and take them for a spin.

column2: I am very eager to continue playing and for all the ways I can see this game growing towards its 1.0 release. I can estimate that the content in this current build will probably have me playing it for around 10 hours
column3: but I will definitely follow its development for the chance to play more For The Warp.

column1: A great game that will only get exponentially better as it gets more content.";8.1;1.0;2.0;171.0;Posted: April 9
I can't in good conscience recommend this game. I wish I could. As other reviews have said
column2: this game has potential. I truly believe this game as good potential
column3: the stuff to become a great game. But
column4: it has an issue. A major glaring issue.

column1: It has no replayability. For a game priced at $21.5 AUD
column2: I would expect there to be some replayability in this game. Now granted
column3: it has done something to that end. There are 5 ships in the game. The problem with those ships however is that they only affect starting cards and stats. Nothing about the run itself changes. Card rewards are the same. Encounters are basically dealt with in the same manner. No special equipment for individual ships. Nothing. Once you start a game
column4: it's all the same.

column1: I can't see myself playing this game again. I am bored. I am bored of this game. I know how I should play now
column2: I know what makes for a good deck of cards and what isn't. I know what all of the encounters are like now. Although on that topic
column3: what's the point in different encounters? The different encounters barely affect by I play. Some encounters will be more health draining then others based on some RNG factors
column4: while others I just pass through not even so much as a scratch. Difficulty isn't what makes encounters different
column5: but the encounters are so similar and samey
column6: that's how I see them. My play-style doesn't change
column7: just how much health I am going to lose.

column1: With the ships not changing how the game itself is run
column2: and the encounters all blurring together. The first couple of runs will be fun
column3: but after that. It's all the same. I can not recommend this game if you value replayability.";5.8;0.0;1.0;112.0;Posted: November 25

column1: There are some interesting concepts here but some weird decisions that
column2: ultimately
column3: I didn't enjoy.

column1: * It's bizarre to me that you start with 3 cards instead of a full deck... No idea why that decision was made (but I'm assuming there is one...?) This means you'll easily take 9-27 damage (probably more later on) without being able to charge your shields or prevent damage (unless you get lucky with your draw on those first three cards) That's my biggest complaint
column2: really. I flew through the first system no problem but died within two encounters on the second system due to this mechanic.

column1: * I enjoyed the sci-fi spaceship/deckbuilding setting and the art is pretty good. Seeing the animations for the corresponding card you played is pretty cool. The backgrounds are bright and colorful and it's always fun to look at. The music was pretty great but seemed to be a bit repetitive?

* 'Burn' (think 'bleed' in other games - damage over time) doesn't take effect until the end of the enemy turn... which is a strange decision as well in my opinion. It doesn't allow the damage to be a real 'game-changer'. You'll take the enemy's attacks and THEN they die... which really hurts your momentum on a run since your HP carries over.

column2: I only played this for about 0.4 hours before dying and deciding I didn't enjoy it. It's possible that the game continues to open up as you progress (as deck-building games usually do) I want to like this game and will definitely keep an eye on it as it continues to progress through early access. If you like this genre of game you might really vibe with it... I'm sure I'll pick it up again in the future but I don't think it's something I want to play just yet.";0.4;0.0;0.0;509.0;Posted: September 14

column10: the Aylon has a starting shield capacity of 45 if you include it's starting equipment

column15: because that was Spelunky-shop levels of smooth.

column2: nice tunes... The only truly negative thing I can say about the game is its overreliance on RNG. I get it's meant to be a ""roguelike"" but the balance or lack thereof is all over the place. I can't begin to tell you the number of runs ended in the first sector because of several clusters of enemies that all spam their attacks and leave you at half or less health past the first encounter; then the sector one enemies that enjoy their 10 ~ 23 damage attacks.
enemy attack values vary wildly unlike yours which are static. Their 'Burn damage' also pierces/ignores your Shields/Block while yours can't do the same.
it's still entertaining for what it is but if the talk about its balancing or lack of certain elements common to deckbuilders of this kind puts you off
column3: I'd suggest waiting for a sale or watching someone else play it before deciding.";9.8;1.0;0.0;701.0;Posted: April 12

column2: nothing has broken a run (IE
column3: the UI broke

column5: ect.) without being fixed by quitting to the main menu and just continuing. However
column6: this has reset one event where I got an epic equipment and made it as if it didn't exist.

column1: 2. NO EASY STATUS ICON. if you get set on fire
column2: you have to see it on the combat log. otherwise something happens and you wonder ""Why the heck did I lose a card this turn"" or ""Where did that 2 damage come from?""
in my time of playing
column3: nothing has hampered the FTL-esque random encounter combat too badly and the combat (other than the occasional glitch that makes shields ""NON""
column4: as well as the status thing.) too heavily.

Gameplay is solid. If you pay attention
column2: you can find cards that work really well together
column3: and that's the real joy of a deckbuilder.

column2: I enjoy this game and plan on playing it more. So that's a thumbs up.

column1: I have not seen any of the bugs other users have reported. I don't know if I've just been lucky or if they were all fixed in the 1.01 patch.
My biggest complaints are all UI-related. For example It's not always obvious what just happened. Some enemy attacks have clear animations
column2: many don't. There's a text log in the upper left that I guess is supposed to solve this issue
column3: but solving it visually would have been a lot better.

column1: The map can also get a bit confusing. They put giant arrows on top of the sectors you can travel to
column2: which sometimes makes them hard to see and understand. I don't know why the arrows are even there. We all understand what adjacent squares are. The arrows could probably disappear after the tutorial and it'd be fine.

column1: Those are the kinds of complaints I have. Minor UI stuff. I see that other people are complaining about difficulty or ""RNG""
column2: but those are all about where I expected them to be. I don't expect to beat a game like this on my first couple runs
column3: and that's fine
column4: so long as I have fun while I fail.";53.6;1.0;0.0;386.0;Posted: April 1

column1: If all you want is a winning strategy
column2: you can try to go for one of three possible decks. Carrier Deck
column3: which is broken as all hell. Inverse Shield Damage deck
column4: which can kill 300hp ships in a single hit later on. And Booster Deck
column5: which is so fun and broken it's not even fair to the enemy. Just remember
column6: look out for synergies and cards that let you draw fast and cheaply. But do whatever you can to get the Barrel Roll card
column7: that's literally the best card in the game
column8: period. With it
column9: you have a 99% certainty to win. Also
column10: keep you decks on a 8-14 cards limit
column11: anything more it becomes useless
column12: anything less
column13: you are left powerless.

column2: I give it a 8/10.";10.3;1.0;0.0;362.0;Posted: August 10
and actually has an interesting design.

column1: That being said it's still unbalanced in alpha
column2: its incredibly easy to force a build without consequence due to the enemies lacking enough impact.

column1: I really enjoyed their deck design having no discard pool; you draw and discard to the same pool.
Even though there are a lot of crazy loops you can pull off
column2: the number of cards you play is limited based on the number of cards in your original deck.

column1: This means you can place higher value on cards that dissipate during the fight as it allows your refined combo deck more cards to play.
It would be interesting to see some balance around this aspect of the game via enemy auras and debuffs.";10.4;1.0;0.0;276.0;Posted: May 14

column2: I normally don't do reviews on Steam
column3: however this game has made me make an exception. The easiest way for me to describe this game at the time of writing is FTL: Faster Than Light mixed with Slay the Spire with a slight influence from tactical rpg's. That being said
column4: there are a few issues at the moment I have noticed
column5: however it could just be my PC at the moment. First issue is in the intro cut-scene the audio jacks up near the end and transfers into the map. Second issue I found is the random encounter that shows all PoI (Places of Interest) on the map
column6: causing a soft lock
column7: however going to main menu then pressing continue resets the tile and allows you to continue playing. Third issue I found is when you run out of fuel
column8: you click the arrow
column9: the distress beacon dialogue appears in which you lose some credits and gain five fuel.

column1: The combat is good. I like the shield system where you can rollover shields to next turn
column2: unless you have the Kinetic Shield card or something else along those lines
column3: however I will say the GUI during combat is not my friend. The GUI is beautiful
column4: however there are no tool-tips except for equipment. If I ignite the enemy
column5: I have to remember how much ignite is on the enemy
column6: how much damage it might do
column7: etc. I see the icon under the enemy
column8: I just don't have any information to work with regarding that aspect.

column1: Synergies is an interesting concept. I like them to be honest
column2: and with the estimated 80 cards you're more likely to encounter synergy cards. It makes the actual deck-building fun
column3: and you can get some pretty interesting combinations. If you find an Ignite synergy with Nova Strike it's beautiful.

column2: I haven't messed around with this all too much. I have noticed that removing cards from your deck is a much more difficult process than adding cards to the deck. There's a few random encounters that allow you to remove cards
column3: and it's a beautiful sight that makes a grown man cry with joy.

column2: I would pick this game up if you like FTL and/or Slay the Spire. There's a few things that could deal with a bit of polish or reworking
column3: but otherwise it's a good game.

column1: For The Warp is a good game in the making. I've put a decent amount of time into it at the time of this review (about 15 hours or so) and I feel like I've seen pretty much everything the game can throw at me by now. There are definitely some cool combos (I personally enjoy the 0 cost discard cards with the 'draw cards and gain energy when you discard' equipment) and fun gameplay but there are definitely some balance issues.

column2: you quickly realize that some strategies are just better than others because the cards needed for those strategies are the best cards. When I get a bad first shop and don't find many useful early cards in the first area
column3: I end up just starting over because my deck doesn't have the defensive capabilities to survive multiple fights in the second phase. If you need specific cards to progress past the early stages of the game (I'm looking at you barrel roll/cloaking device) then what's the point of adopting any other early strategy that doesn't best support these cards?

column1: An example of a game that I think has perfected the 'balance' concept is Slay the Spire. Any strategy can win the game if you are smart about how you play it and get the key cards/relics you need for that strategy. This game can get there
column2: but it definitely needs work. I will say though that it's a good time while you figure it out
column3: but once you've figured out what works and what doesn't it feels a bit stale.

column1: I still think it's worth picking up though as long as the developers are actively making good changes to the game. Being a part of the evolution of a good game is pretty exciting and if you're okay with hitting a few snags here and there
column2: go for it. Just remember that it's still a work in progress.";38.8;1.0;0.0;45.0;Posted: April 1

column1: I originally bought this game on itch.io in December
column2: back when it was in alpha 0.2.3
column3: so I have a lot more hours in the game than what is reflected on Steam. It's been really cool to see how much work the devs have put into it in just a few short months.

column2: FTW is a roguelike where you move a spaceship through several sectors of a galaxy toward a goal
column3: sort of like FTL
column4: but the combat uses cards (which are shaped like 3.5 inch floppies and are cute as hell) with different skills and effects
column5: similar to Slay the Spire. Because the loot and maps are randomized
column6: each game is unique and there are many different play styles you can go for in your deck. So
column7: I think it has a good amount of replay value
column8: even in this early alpha stage of development.

column1: I love the pixel art. I love the music and hope they add more. I love the little references (""twisted firestarter"") and the quirkiness of some of the enemies. It's a fun game and I appreciate the insane amount of work they've put into it in just the three or so months since I bought it.
At this point (alpha 0.5.0) my biggest complaint is money. It's too easy to acquire and that makes it too easy to buy a lot of overpowered equipment at shops. I think either money should be more rare
column2: or that loot should get progressively more expensive. That
column3: I think
column4: would help balance the game and make it more difficult. It's a roguelike
column5: after all. It's supposed to be hard! Aside from that
column6: I think they've got a good thing going here and I look forward to seeing what else they do with it in future builds.";16.1;1.0;0.0;154.0;Posted: March 29

Quality of life is already pretty good (only major complaint is that the game doesn't do such a great job of indicating and describing status effects). The only significant problem I have with this game right now is that it is badly in need of balancing as it's much to easy as is.";1.8;1.0;0.0;708.0;Posted: March 31

column4: so we installed it on his computer and he started playing. By the end of the week he had 24 hours on this game. This was horrible for me
column5: as it was already hard for me to find ways to spend time with my son
column6: as he is always out with his friends or just watching YouTube. So I decided to make a Steam account and get this game to see if I could maybe play alongside him. I loaded into the game
column7: picked my character and world and started playing but I was stuck on Margit the fell omen. I asked my Son for help and I hosted a game for him to join. I loved it as it was the best time I had spent with my Son since my wife had died. This game has ever since brought me and my son closer again and now we actually spend time together outside the house together as well. This game reminded me that there's fun to be had in everything
column8: and it has brought both me and my Son many happy memories.";98.0;1.0;789.0;441.0;Posted: 17 May

column1: Goodbye Elden Ring. After achieving and experiencing all there is to do in the single player campaign it's time to move on. The adventure
column2: awe
column3: and breathtaking vistas are incredible. This is easily the frontrunner for GOTY. If you've never played a Soulsborne this is an absolute gem to welcome you to the community. That said
column4: the PVP is... just not good. There's no other way to put it. It's so broken there's too many things to list here. I will check back periodically to see how all the others that have suffered through the growing pains have fared. After the pinnacle of Soulslike combat in DS3 I had high hopes. But even the culmination of their incredible Sekiro combat and literally a decade of refinement can't save them from their own ambitions of marrying an open world to souls combat. If PVE adventure is your thing I cannot recommend this game any more strongly! If you loved souls for their pvp combat... I'm sorry. Lol. From... for the love of God
column5: please bring back the DS3 servers so we can play some legit PVP again! I don't have much confidence you can fix this mess in ER. Time will tell. Hello DLC? Hello patches? (not Patches
column6: but hello to you too
column7: you bastard). So until then
column8: I will not mend the rune again. No more linking the fire. Let it fade. Melt it all away with the yellow chaos flame.";484.8;1.0;6.0;56.0;Posted: 20 May

column2: I can say this is my least favorite game from FROMSOFTWARE. Now this is completely personal and I expect people to disagree
column3: that's fine
column4: but I'll still explain why I think this is their worst game. (Note that I have not played Demon's Souls or Bloodborne because I'm not buying a Playstation just for those games. I only cleared DS1 once but cleared DS2
column5: DS3 and Sekiro multiple times each
column6: so I don't think this is a ""git gud"" issue.)

column1: The two main problems I have with the game are parts of the open world and the (not always but way too often) godawful enemy design.
The open world is beautiful and offers lots of options to the player
column2: which at first glance is very nice right ? Well
column3: it turns out that this same open worlds comes in to butcher what other souls games have been pretty great at executing : difficulty progression. Yes
column4: in other games you could stumble upon an area you were not supposed to clear yet and get destroyed by the enemies in there
column5: but there was a limited set of possibilities in terms of new areas that were accessible to you at a time. In Elden Ring however
column6: you have infinite possibilities. Therefore
column7: the pattern that starts to occur when you enter a new area is ""Either I wreck everything in here or they wreck me"". This makes for a mediocre experience at best because if something is too hard
column8: you just walk out and go somewhere else until you find something you can actually clear. The fact that the game is so open also doesn't really fit a souls game. Maybe that's just me ? I feel like exploring should be sort of relaxing and laid back but then you find some cool ruins and you need to activate tryhard

column1: mode to clear it. Kinda breaks the rythm of the game in my opinion. Also it kinda kills one of my favorite aspects from the Dark Souls series : the claustrophobia inducing level design. (Obviously we can still find that in the legacy dungeons which are AMAZING in both presentation and level design. There's a reason why those are by far my favorite part of the game.)
Now on the topic of the enemy design
column2: it's been pointed out a lot already but I've heard that the enemy design was very inspired by Bloodborne enemies. You'll remember from earlier that I did NOT play Bloodborne but I did play Sekiro and I'd say that some enemies very much do feel like they were taken straight out of Sekiro and slapped into Elden Ring with no adjustments whatsoever while WE only have a DS1 moveset at our disposal. Some of them are just way too fast
column3: some of them keep on attacking for so long you can grow a 6ft long beard before they stop and some do both. This makes for some of the most frustrating encounters I've had in any game I've played and
column4: mostly for that reason alone
column5: I think this game is way
column6: way worse than all their previous games. Also don't get me started on double boss fights. It's like they picked out the pairings at random.

column2: the open world is insanely gorgeous and very fun to explore
column3: but there's still this weird feeling that the game shouldn't switch from ""pleasant exploration"" to ""absolute sweatfest"" in an instant
column4: but then again it's not THAT big of an issue. The real problem really resides in the enemy design which is really flawed in certain areas of the game. I sometimes feel like I was given a toothpick to go fight a tank. That's unfortunately not something I can enjoy.

column1: I'm interested to hear your opinions. Are they different ? Do you agree with some of my points ?

column1: It's a truly unique experience. It's an open world game like no other
column2: and at the same time a souls-like game like no other. It's not perfect by far: the world is massive
column3: which makes exploration a lot of fun
column4: and the build variety is huge
column5: which makes experimenting with weapons and items very enjoyable
column6: but some of the content can start to feel repetitive
column7: especially if you decide to explore every corner of the map
column8: and some of the boss encounters can be annoying.

column1: FromSoft tried to make the game more friendly to new players by adding a proper tutorial
column2: a map
column3: and even quest objectives for some quests. They also added a new gameplay mechanic -- ash summons
column4: a variety of upgradable friendly NPCs that you can summon at many places in the overworld and on every boss to make encounters easier.

column2: this is still a souls-like game: combat requires strategizing
column3: patience and good reflexes; NPC quests are obtuse and you will probably miss 90% of them if you don't look up guides; environments have to be meticulously explored otherwise you're likely to miss chunks of the game or valuable items
column4: etc. And
column5: of course

column7: some attacks are bullsh*t
column8: some mobs are bullsh*t
column9: this sh*t totally wasn't supposed to hit me

column2: Elden Ring IS amazing.
the game is absolutely stellar. Veterans of the series will appreciate subtle nods to prior entries
column3: and find that many of the mechanics are familiar.

column2: there is no better way to enter into the series. Graces (bonfires) are more abundant (they have to be
column3: given the open-world nature of the game)
column4: and the mechanics are much more clearly explained The open-world allows players to come back stronger in the event a boss proves too hard
column5: and opens up many different ways to go about completing the game.

column1: I found the lore of Elden Ring more fascinating than any other game in the series
column2: not to mention a caste of NPCs that haven't felt so fresh since Dark Souls 1.

column1: Elden Ring does sort of flounder in the late game. The bosses begin to get overtuned and excessive
column2: and begin to rely on inflated health pools and indistinct tells. I feel like in the late game From fell into the trap of attempting to out-do their own difficulty
column3: without regard to keeping the fights fair and enjoyable. Ultimately
column4: I think this is due to the fact that FromSoft balanced the later bosses around using spririt ash summons
column5: a choice which I find questionable at best.

column1: Some of the NPC quests are also excessively convoluted
column2: and beyond what a normal player would be able to figure out without a guide or the internet.
the game is a testament to FromSoft's continued prowess at it's genre. After 120+ hours and beating every boss solo
column3: I'm confident that I'll be going through again to collect the rest of the endings. Yes
column4: Elden Ring is absolutely worth it.";138.4;1.0;3.0;29.0;Posted: 22 May

column1: Elden Ring is a commendable 7/10 game that you will most certainly get your money’s worth. However
column2: it falls well short of a 10/10 and is absolutely not a masterpiece
column3: there are too many flaws of significance for me to consider this one. For this spoiler-free review I will go through the main features that constitute an ER playthrough (and Souls games in general) and break down what ER did well regarding them
column4: and what it did poorly.

column2: one of the biggest games you will ever play
areas which are similar to the more linear sections of previous Souls games.
a lot to unlock and discover
a lot of obvious reused assets and structures you explore over and over again. 4/5 of the open world areas are the same thing but different color palettes.
ambitious
column3: crazy project of a game. I can't emphasize enough that Elden Ring and its world are absolutely HUGE
column4: and its lore is equally gigantic and deep. Even with the combined efforts of a huge community
column5: people are still piecing together mysteries in the plot and background lore.

column1: I know Fromsoft games have a reputation of being brutal and punishing
column2: and while Elden Ring is no walk in the park
column3: I think the reputation is a bit overblown here. If something is too difficult
column4: you can just leave and do something else
column5: and come back to it later with new skills
column6: new gear
column7: more levels
column8: etc. The summons system also gives a variety of NPC assists or even allows you to bring in other players to help. If that sort of thing dilutes the ever-important challenge
column9: you can simply avoid those systems. But it's a helpful hand to people willing to leverage every tool to overcome some of the meaty challenges.

column1: Elden Ring isn't perfect. It's deliberately obscure
column2: some systems don't really pull their weight (like crafting and weapon upgrading)
column3: and lots of the math is more or less invisible to the player and left for the community to figure out. But it's good. My god it's good. And there's so damn much of it. At 281 hours
column4: I've done two playthroughs and I'll probably come back for a third when there's DLC.";281.1;1.0;2.0;864.0;Posted: May 21

column1: What could have been a truly amazing co-op experience is unfortunately hindered by one of the worst co-op multiplayer systems implemented in a game to date. Progress is not saved for both players
column2: meaning you have to run all bosses and objectives twice. The player being summoned will also be de-summoned after every single boss event and/or after either of the two players die. This means that throughout even a short play session you'll have to spend tons of time just re-summoning your friend
column3: over and over and over
column4: ad nauseam. It doesn't add anything meaningful to the gameplay cycle
column5: and I struggle to see why they chose this system over literally any other more viable option. Finally
column6: you'll spend lots of time struggling against invading PvP players (that you cannot disable). Now
column7: I don't mind PvP in games (although I would of course prefer to at least have the option to choose)
column8: but when the vast majority of encounters are with players using either cheats to win or to brick your game (yes
column9: that's a thing
column10: they can ruin your save file by using altered items)
column11: then the whole gameplay experience takes a hard turn for the worse.";91.2;0.0;2.0;298.0;Posted: May 22

column1: After ungodly amounts of hours in Souls games
column2: I've come to realize I don't quite enjoy playing these sorts of games anymore
column3: and Elden Ring only exacerbates everything that turned me away from the series in the first place. Is it the sacred cows that pervades throughout all the games? Perhaps it's the pastiche of poorly realized action and RPG mechanics that only seem to blend together because the systems lack any sort of depth in the first place. Or just maybe
column4: it's because it revels in this sort of mean-spirited
column5: emotionally manipulative design
column6: tacitly inserting brain worms telling you the dopamine pay-off of playing a ""hard game"" more than makes up for the impotent rage it'll definitely put you through
column7: no matter how terrible
column8: or lazy

column4: all of which exist solely to make a mockery of my Demigod slayer's amazing feats that would pit him in the annals as an incredible hero of legends? My character never feels stronger

If you're not currently playing ELDEN RING
column2: and are unsure about whether the game is for you
column3: here are some observations that might help swing you.

column1: This game is by far the most accessible of the infamous FromSoftware lineup. This includes games such as Dark Souls
column2: Demon's Souls (I
column3: II
column4: and III)
column5: Bloodborne
column6: and Sekiro. I have played and loved all of these games. ELDEN RING works very similarly to all of them
column7: especially Dark Souls 3
column8: but on a scale unprecedented and personally unimaginable before now.

column2: and hesitant to invest into this game and it's siblings
column3: it may be because of their reputation as difficult and ""hardcore"" games.

column1: They all have similar reputations given to them by (annoying) players
column2: games journalists
column3: and the games' own marketers as being difficult
column4: inaccessible
column5: not for the faint of heart
column6: etc. In my opinion
column7: any player conscientious enough to pick up what the games put down
column8: and use the tools at their disposal
column9: without trying to conform to what the community deems ""gitting gud"" will find their way through these games (with the exception of maybe Sekiro).

column1: These games want you to succeed. They want you to make your way through their vast and beautiful worlds. The games do not look down on you for doing what you need to do to get through it's challenges
column2: including asking for cooperative help. Only Reddit will look down on you for that
column3: and it's opinions don't matter anyway.

column1: ELDEN RING more than any previous title from the developer is about exploration
column2: about discovery
column3: about letting your sword or charm or staff carry you through epic moments. It's challenges can be deterring
column4: but they also are not often limitting. You can skip the first castle entirely and come back 100 hours later if you like.

column2: you'd be showing support for a dev that does not and has never engaged in weird or unethical business practices. No lootboxes
column3: no microtransactions
column4: no pay-to-win or games-as-service
column5: just honest to god making games that are good
column6: that feel good
column7: that reward your hours
column8: and with replay value years from now.

column2: ELDEN RING is miles above 99% of the 60 euro games on the market. It's more deserving of your hard earned cash and precious time than anything of comparable scale on the market coming out right now.";79.5;1.0;2.0;66.0;Posted: May 22

This is a legendary game that has awoken what I like to call ""playground talk"" aka talking with people back in recess at schools where you talk about your experience with a game with others and nobody has an identical experience and inevitably people will say ""you had a WHAT? I didn't find that in my playthough!"". This game is so massive it's very unlikely two people will have the same experience and it's also unlikely that they will find every single possible thing on their first go

column1: I've played what I consider to be a decent amount of the game. Got about as far as Leyndell before deciding I'd had enough of the nonsense. Elden Ring is far and away from being a good game. A beautiful-yet-boring world stuffed with repetitive filler to make the game look like there's a lot of content when really it's just copy/pasted enemies filling in a pretty backdrop. No joke
column2: that's all you do: run around a big empty world and kill enemies and even bigger enemies. Oh
column3: and die a lot.

column2: this game is difficult. Yes
column3: I went into this knowing that FromSoftware games are notoriously hard. I didn't think I'd mind that because I love a good challenge. But there's a HUGE different between being difficult and being straight-up immersion-breaking. And Elden Ring is a whole lot of the latter. Enemies and bosses can one- or two-shot you even if you've leveled up a significant amount. Even if you've gotten better weapons or upgraded your existing ones. Even if you went and found an NPC or Ashes of War or even another player to summon to your aid. No matter how many hours you spend grinding runes. No matter how many times you try to parry or dodge or heal or even cheese
column4: all of which are at many times impossible to do because the enemies and bosses are just too fast and too unpredictable. At some point they've killed you so many times that it becomes more of a chore than a game.

column2: which in and of itself is virtually nonexistent and should more or less be labeled ""loreytelling"". There's a ton of exposition in the beginning cutscene
column3: and then you're just told to go become Elden Lord. No reason why
column4: just go do it because that's the game. But beyond that
column5: there's no unfolding
column6: driven narrative. No characters worth giving a crap about. No plot twists or emotional moments or anything that makes the player WANT to continue. All there is is worldbuilding and an egregious amount of it that most people will probably miss. The game doesn't even tell you what the purpose of any of this is. WHY do I need to claim the title of Elden Lord? WHY is the Erdtree important and not simply the biggest freaking MacGuffin I've ever laid eyes on? WHAT is the point?

column1: I don't particularly care what excuses anyone has defending this game's insulting lack of story. Lore and story are two very different things
column2: not interchangeable synonyms. If Elden Ring were a novel
column3: it'd be one of the worst-written novels I've ever heard of.

column1: The last major issue I have with this game is the dungeon design. Maybe I'm spoiled by the dungeons of Zelda
column2: but these ""dungeons"" are little more than fortresses filled with a ton of enemies and little else. Whether it's the big main dungeons or the smaller castles or even the stuff underground
column3: everything is routinely the same. The big dungeons at least have different visual appearances to them
column4: but there's so few of them compared to the tons of copy-pasted smaller dungeons that it almost doesn't matter. None of these dungeons are memorable in any sense of the word.

column1: The only real aspects of Elden Ring that I can confidently consider pros are the gorgeous graphics and the stellar soundtrack. If even half as much effort went into making the rest of the game that good
column2: I wouldn't be as upset at it. But in no conceivable way can I recommend this game. It just does not live up to the hype surrounding it.";40.2;0.0;2.0;101.0;Posted: May 23

column1: Not much I can say in a review that's already been said by a million other players but I'll still try. The Soulsborne formula fit very well into the open world format but it also sacrifices a few things that some people I know deem to be extremely important. Due to allowing the player to go anywhere they'd like to from the very start
column2: the level design is not as laser focused as it has been in previous games. This freedom serves as Elden Ring's greatest strength but can be seen as an unfocused and unbalanced mess to a scant few who prefer a much tighter experience.

this has been my favorite game in years and I can easily see myself returning for new builds and playthroughs despite getting every achievement already because of the incredible amount of replayability (albeit a little daunting given the immense size of the game). As with any game
column3: it's very important to know what kind of genre you are most inclined to
column4: and to those who love games with a tight focus and clear vision on what the devs intend the user experience to be
column5: maybe give this game a pass. To those who are looking for a freedom unseen in almost every game before this
column6: Elden Ring is worth every cent.";391.1;1.0;1.0;130.0;Posted: May 23

column1: elden ring is from software's most accessible game to date whether that be a good or bad thing. that doesn't mean this game is 100% perfect because that endgame is very rough in my opinion
column2: one of the worst end games in a videogame ever. i would say elden ring when you start out is a completely different game because you're still trying to learn the mechanics and explore limgrave thoroughly to your own ability. most people have said it and i 100% agree but limgrave is the best area the game has to offer. i explore for hours on end before finally meeting upon margit the felled and beat him or her (idrk) second try. this is game design at its peak and trust me it doesn't stop there. after margit there's still a entire castle to explore which the average player won't fully explore it because it is literally a castle filled with treasures and enemies within it. this is just the very beginning
column3: you'll often find yourself in awe as you explore the lands between
column4: this game is filled to the brim with things to do and things to see. that being said those things to do and things to see can often be repetitive and boring. not all of them but you see what i'm trying to say. building a world as big as elden ring is obviously going to have it's fair share of problems and copy and pastes
column5: but there's still something magical about exploring and finding what works for you. i would say once you get to the mountain of the giants (70% through) then you're gonna start seeing the many problems i have with this games end game. i'll just be completely honest it wasn't as fun as i hoped to be. the fire giant
column6: maliketh
column7: elden beast
column8: godfrey
column9: dragon lord
column10: melina
column11: godskin duo
column12: etc are bosses that really show how lazy the devs can get. even in some of the beginning bosses you could really see the problems emerging before you reached this point. delayed attack
column13: somehow infinite stamina
column14: one shot moves
column15: are all a lot of these final bosses have
column16: and that makes the game for me atleast not replayable because when i'm getting one shot with around 50-60 vigor there's something wrong with the boss design. that's not to say that they're essentially bad bosses but these bosses seem to be almost like you're just watching a huge anime fight before your eyes
column17: it's really unecessary. these bosses will do crazy moves non-stop with nothing to really do about it
column18: that's the problem. notice how i never mentioned radagon which is the first phase of the finale boss. he seems to be the only one that's actually fun. his attacks are easily readable and you're able to memorize his attack patterns without being punished by delayed and crazy attacks. his boss is the peak boss design from software makes. other than that bosses are just completely broken in this game sometimes. my favorite boss in this game is the very first demi-god (godrick the grafted.) his attacks are crazy but they're sustainable

Where do I even begin on this game- it's unbelievably good. Guess I'll begin with the TL;DR so here it goes. While a bit of a challenge
column2: Elden Ring gives you a beautiful landscape worthy of exploration
column3: and expansive underground and hidden world to explore. The wide variety of bosses encapsulates and challenges you while rarely reaching a point where you'd consider it unfair. The game gets harder as you get more skilled
column4: encouraging innovation and adaptation regarding your play style especially towards the middle of Act II. This game is everything I could have asked for
column5: and more.

column1: Across my 3 playthroughs (NG++) and 100% achievement completion
column2: I have never found a boss fight or area that didn't immediately captivate my attention. The underground areas such as Nokstella or Deeproot fascinated me
column3: and the rewards for venturing into the more challenging areas match the difficulty expected. Graphics were stunning too
column4: as all areas are visually distinct.

column2: there's a lot you need to discover yourself. The lack of a quest log is a generally good thing
column3: as it really makes it seem like you are venturing totally independently. I mean
column4: I beat the game three times and I am still left thinking I missed incredibly large chunks of the game (which is by no means a negative
column5: as it gives me every the reason to play even more than I already have
column6: and leaves discovery for every subsequent play-through).

column1: This game is truly a work of art

column1: First of I want to say that I've played tons of souls and souls-like games. With that in mind
column2: I'm extremely divided with my experience with this game and here's why.

column1: I'll start off with the positives; the first third or half if we're being generous are downright magical
column2: especially the first 20-30 hours or so. For me
column3: time flew by
column4: I stayed up all night exploring
column5: killing tough bosses
column6: finding out all sorts of great secrets and just had myself a blast. Open world and Dark Souls works surprisingly well...or so I thought
column7: but more on that later.

column1: The overall atmosphere of the game is also great and it looks gorgeous. Visuals have always been one of the better selling points of Souls-games in my opinion and they nailed that once again. Many areas in the game are as fun to look at as they are to explore and they were for the most part fairly creative with them. Exploring them is also pretty fun
column2: although that again diminishes over time in my opinion; last third being exceptionally boring if you ask me.

column1: One double-edged sword for me is the variety given to player to tackle the many enemies that the Lands Between throws at you. While variety is the spice of life and I'm a big spicy food enthusiast
column2: I think this time it might have gone a bit too far. I'm the completionist type who likes to explore everything
column3: which I did during my playthrough of the game; I explored every area
column4: every dungeon
column5: beat every boss
column6: got every possible rune to get whatever ending I desired. The issue is that many of the items you get
column7: you will just not use
column8: which diminishes the eagerness to explore. Spells are good example of this; there are dozens of them in the game
column9: but if you're playing a melee build
column10: which is the most common way to play these games
column11: you will most likely not use them all that much
column12: or mostly a selected handful that boost your combat effectiveness. Still
column13: I enjoyed the exploring overall
column14: but this aspect of it did suffer as a result.

column1: Many weapons you get might be hard to upgrade with lacking materials
column2: so once you find what works for you
column3: you're not likely to change
column4: unless to have a backup weapon or two in case you want something specific
column5: like bleed damage for example. Never before has there been an option to get so over-powered so easily
column6: which I feel takes much charm out of the experience.

column1: The last third of the game for me was a slog
column2: with any battle be it just normal foe or boss being challenging in a fun way; most of them I could beat after few tries
column3: some of which I didn't even get to hear all of the dialogue. The element of summon spirits is also fuels this much more. Code Vein
column4: also Souls-like game
column5: also had co-op character as integral part of it's design and in that game the difficulty of it was still well maintained. Sadly
column6: I can't say the same for Elden Ring. One spirit summon in particular is notorious and most people who have beaten the game know what I'm talking about. Some people would say that you don't have to use it
column7: which is true
column8: but summon spirits are a game mechanic the game very heavily promotes
column9: be it through upgrades
column10: sheer amount of them you can get and how many of the bosses are seemingly made with one (or more) additional character on your side. Them taking the attention away from you
column11: taking away the one versus one nail biting gameplay the series is known for to me is maybe the single biggest miss with this game. This is the most accessible game From Software has ever done
column12: but I think it has come at too big of a cost. Much like horror movies
column13: to me difficulty of the experience is just part of it's foundation; by default
column14: some people aren't going to like it
column15: and that's okay. With them trying to please everyone
column16: ultimately it feels like the opposite of desired effect was reached
column17: unless the player handicaps themselves.

column1: Outside of the issues with the bosses and their design
column2: the second biggest flaw that really hindered my enjoyment of the game is oddly enough the open world nature of the game. Since the player is fairly free to explore the areas in whatever order they desire
column3: it is fairly easy to end up being too low level for a certain area and being too high level for another. Since Souls-games don't exactly show you what level you ought to be for any area (which I think is good
column4: mind you
column5: we don't need these games to be Ubisoft clones)
column6: it made some areas extremely boring.

column2: I visited the Raya Lucaria Academy fairly late
column3: after I had beaten Volcano Manor. Volcano Manor was maybe the single best experience to me in the game; the entire area oozed with atmosphere
column4: was challenging
column5: with memorable characters
column6: enemies and bosses. Were everything about the game to this level
column7: I would have given this game two thumbs up for sure. When I entered Raya Lucaria Academy afterwards
column8: it was absolute cakewalk. During my run
column9: I think I died maybe two or three times and that was mostly due to falling
column10: not because of enemies. I'm also by no means the most amazing gamer out there
column11: despite being Souls veteran
column12: but I was simply way too high of a level to the area. I really wish there was some sort of scaling option in the game to keep the areas challenging
column13: but without it the enjoyment for me was ruined almost completely when I never had to learn the boss moves and patterns
column14: as simply going to their face and smacking them did the trick.

column1: I also think that the game is too big for it's own good. To me this is maybe heightened the most by the absolutely insane amount of bosses being recycled in the game. There are total of 9 truly unique boss fights in the game
column2: with everything else being copies of at least one another boss one way or another. Some bosses you will see so many times that they lose all of their magic
column3: like dragons or magma wyrms for example; both fights that were initially extremely fun
column4: challenging and memorable
column5: but by 5th time you can't help but to your roll your eyes. I would have much preferred if they had cut out chunks of the game
column6: like the snowy area towards the end to make the rest of the experience tighter
column7: more narrowed
column8: focused and unique.

column1: I quickly also want to mention riding and crafting. I was fairly neutral on both of these personally. I didn't use crafting all that much
column2: with exception of ailment items and pots for the most part. There were tons and tons of recipes
column3: but more often than not there was no need for them
column4: at least not for me personally. This is maybe because gathering resources was tedious when you're not riding past a field of them or when exploring a cave. Not a bad concept
column5: but I still felt like it wasn't utilized properly either
column6: but certainly didn't ruin the game for me either.

column2: I quite enjoyed the horse combat. I liked it when especially when fighting the dragons as you could dodge the breath attacks and quickly catch up with them. Overall though I feel like this system too was a bit underutilized. This might be a personal taste thing
column3: but to me Souls games are still better without it. Again
column4: a hit and miss feature in my eyes.

column2: this is the first Souls game I struggled having to finish. The highs of the game are very much up there
column3: the first third or half of the game is truly a magical experience
column4: definitely worth both the time and money I put into it. As the game progresses
column5: however
column6: the magic fades away and you're left with big
column7: yet empty feeling world. The numerous issues that seem to go up against the very core design the series is both know and loved for makes this a bitter soup to swallow. I can't say that I hated my time with the game
column8: but I can't say that I wholeheartedly enjoyed it either. I hope that despite the insane success of this title that From Software takes few steps back to inspect their work before starting the next project. If their next game repeats most of the things that were in the Elden Ring
column9: it might be my very first purposeful pass for the series. And as someone who really loves these games
column10: I hope that won't be the case.";135.9;0.0;3.0;596.0;Posted: May 21
