Combining the combat system from soulslike games and open world elements is no small feat. The bosses feel challenging and even fighting smaller enemies can feel insurmountable at times. The game encourages the player to find alternate routes
column2: whether that be in the literal sense of jumping across rooftops or the more metaphorical route of changing/upgrading equipment or even completely changing your build. Implementing a crafting system with dozens of consumables greatly helps with the feeling in previous FROM titles of having no equipment to get past a given fight. The spirit ash system gives players an additional level of difficulty to choose how casual or hardcore they want their experience to be. The player is never trapped. If a boss can't be beaten you have the simple option of leaving and finding somewhere else to explore
column3: a different boss to kill
column4: or new equipment to find.

column1: If I had to pick out some negatives
column2: many of the ""Main story"" bosses feel like gimmick fights. You're forced to use a certain weapon
column3: or overcome a certain mechanic which doesn't make you feel like you've actually improved as a player. Some builds (notably bleed and sorcery) are significantly better than standard strength
column4: dex
column5: or faith builds. It can definitely feel like you're limiting yourself by playing the build you want
column6: simply because the dps difference is so staggering. A lot of the weapons scale with intelligence; it's a good thing in my opinion to have more options for melee as an int build
column7: but it feels like FROM sacrificed a lot of physical scaling weapons just to give int builds more melee weapon diversity.";184.6;1.0;1.0;44.0;Posted: May 18

Tl;dr - I'm a big fan of From Software and have played DS1
column2: DS2
column3: DS3 and Bloodborne. Let's look past the marketing fluff and the unrealistic 10/10 ratings this game has received before launch. Please remember
column4: this is purely my view and shouldn't in any way influence your decisions. Elden Ring is an awesome game and an amazing experience
column5: albeit it a bit overambitious and just way too long (I’m a completionist). Truly a landmark achievement for From Software. 8/10 would recommend at least one play-through. A masterpiece? It depends...

column1: If you're familiar with previous titles you'll feel right at home. It's textbook From Software and incorporates mechanics from all previous titles. The biggest notable change is in the combat mechanics. Those who dabble in PvP mostly benefit from this change as the build variety is enormous.
Graphics are beautiful and the world building is astonishing allowing for a fully immersed experience. You will find yourself pausing often to view many of the world's amazing vistas.
Combat feels smooth and intuitive. Despite a ton of new spells & abilities
column2: the character animations are smooth and combat feels very satisfying.

column1: The music is epic. It feels very different to previous titles. Not as dark as Dark Souls
column2: however
column3: there were countless moments where the hairs on my neck were standing up. There's nothing better than fighting epic bosses complimented by an epic score.

column1: NPC character design is fresh but still in line with what the company is known for. Expect all manner of strange and normal NPC's. This is high fantasy at its best.
Day & Night cycles are a great addition to the From Software formula and really brings the world’s atmosphere to life.

column2: I was happy to find that I am no longer invaded all the time. Invasions now seem to only happen during cooperative play. Which I'll also cover in ""The Bad"" section of the review.
bar a few...

column1: The game feels overambitious. The fact that it’s From Software’s first attempt at a massive open world
column2: really shows. You can clearly see that most of the effort went into the first couple of zones as the quality drops when you start noticing the reuse of assets in later zones. Which brings me to my next point.

column1: Elden Ring's biggest strength is also its biggest weakness. I.e.
column2: the massive open world. Because of the sheer size
column3: the game fails to create the intimate and memorable experiences the previous titles created. This is largely due to the fact that the large landmass merely serves as a glue between the more traditional legacy dungeons and unfortunately there's not much between The Lands Between. It feels like butter scraped over too much bread. In typical From Software fashion (much more than in any previous title due to the size)
column4: many of the game's assets are repeated
column5: copied
column6: and pasted throughout the world. There's the classic dungeon crawler mix of caves
column7: catacombs
column8: ruins
column9: churches
column10: sewers etc. However
column11: with each iteration they feel less unique and intuitive and this contributed to me feeling burned out after a while. This is not a big living world. Most things are static and will only perform what they’re scripted to do. This was a massive missed opportunity as a world this size could’ve benefited greatly from dynamic events. E.g.
column12: you’re walking through a forest at night and suddenly you’re ambushed by bandits or an assassin jumps from a tree to slit your throat.

column1: The story is as cryptic as ever. Another missed opportunity granted the fact that George R.R. Martin was involved. Not that it shows
column2: though. In fact
column3: I’m not quite sure what his contributions were other than for marketing purposes. Understand that I love George R.R. Martin’s work but From Software seems more than capable of creating lore-rich worlds as they’ve shown in all their previous titles and the mysterious approach to unraveling the plot is what they’re known for. However
column4: I would’ve preferred with this release
column5: a little more streamlined and traditional story-telling that’s easy to understand and to follow.

column2: still happens during cooperative play but not solo play. This was a weird one for me to digest. For some people this is probably fine but for me and my partner
column3: it's frustrating and retracts from the immersion and experience. All I wanted to do is explore The Lands Between with my partner while sipping on some cognac. At least allow players the opportunity to opt-out of PvP. The world is huge
column4: allow us to explore it with our loved ones
column5: uninterrupted.

column1: Not optimized for PC and misleading recommended hardware. Everything was fine after I upgraded to an NVMe SSD
column2: 32 gigs of ram
column3: Geforce RTX 3070 Ti OC
column4: and a clean install of Windows 11 Pro with the latest drivers. Keyboard and mouse controls... yeah don't waste your time. A controller is still highly recommended. No ultra-wide screen support and no ability to switch off chromatic aberration
column5: a graphic technology that I’m not a fan of at all. Frames are also locked to 60 fps.

column1: Some bosses are clearly designed for cooperative play which might turn away some solo players. And before you think “Git Gud”
column2: I know all about spending weekends learning boss mechanics to topple a challenging foe as I’ve done it countless times in previous titles. Maybe I’m getting old. However
column3: in this game some bosses are just insanely punishing to the point where I felt screw it
column4: I’m going to summon some players to assist. And it felt good. There’s nothing wrong with summoning players for assistance. I’m looking at you
column5: elitists. However
column6: I would've preferred defeating them solo. I just couldn’t be bothered as some boss designs are not solo-friendly.

column1: I also urge everyone who has enjoyed Elden Ring
column2: to give the predecessors a go if you haven’t already done so. I myself will definitely be enjoying Dark Souls 1-3 again.";261.7;1.0;1.0;187.0;Posted: May 18

I want to love this game but it has some very glaring issues that make me unable to recommend it. The boss design is terrible
column2: some of the worst in any game I've played ranging from bosses that do extremely long
column3: almost impossible to avoid combos that end in delayed AoEs so melee players can't get in
column4: or the boss will fly completely across a huge map constantly so you're chasing and dodging for an eternity hoping to get 1 hit in or the boss is made that you can only attack if you take damage but all the bosses hit like a nuke
column5: even with full vigor most bosses can take half your health in 1 hit
column6: but ranged players aren't home free either
column7: there are bosses that are completely resistant to magic
column8: story bosses that are immune or heal from things like holy damage so if you tried to make a faith build around holy damaging weapons or spells
column9: your journey ends here because that story boss is completely immune to you and the fight would be hard already for a build that can actually damage it with their best stuff. The worst part is
column10: the worst offenders of the bad design issue are mandatory story bosses
column11: like a certain someone who's name rhymes with Margaret or the star that shall not be named
column12: if you played the game more than a few hours you know. There are also lots of dungeons that lock you in with no way to get out but fighting
column13: no indication on the level or anything so exploring
column14: it is entirely possible to end up stuck somewhere with no way to get out because you're not strong enough to fight
column15: including a trap right in the starting area that could very easily have you stuck if you don't know the path to get out. then you add in bad patches where they remove access to upgrades or things that just made certain mandatory encounters manageable on all builds while leaving in extremely bad things that some bosses can do that they very clearly shouldn't and the community complains about nonstop
column16: or things like PvP that is awful and you're left with a fun but fatally flawed game. It has a lot of good but when the worst part of a Souls game is the bosses
column17: there is a big issue.";152.4;0.0;3.0;8.0;Posted: May 17

This game looks amazing. I'm not huge on my game looking amazing since my PC can't run a lot of games on anything higher than medium /low (GE-Force GTX 1060 6 Gb)

the design make the areas come alive and really show you how good a AAA-game CAN /SHOULD be.

column1: The map is huge and filled with things to do
column2: I was expecting a lot of dead zones devoid of content but was pleasantly surprised with how filled to the brim with things to do the map is.

column1: Exploring is the name of the game in Elden Ring.
Difficulty wise the game has a steep curve since unlike Dark Souls you don't have to fight bosses in a certain order if even at all.
So the first boss feels really hard since you probably like me come from other DS titles and want to get on with the bosses ASAP
column2: with good timing and dedication you can do only bosses.

column1: But the game actively wants you to explore and do side-content to become stronger and then come back to the bosses for a fun fight instead of throwing yourself on the boss like mad until you kill him.
Elden Ring is as hard of a game as you make it.

column2: get a strong weapon with a good Ash Of War.

column2: chief.

column1: This is the game that gave me hope for open-world games.
Elden Ring has managed provide hundreds of hours of content without the monotonous BS that other open-world games do.

-Combat in general feels great. I have had no issues with hits connecting. The weapons feel like they should; bigger weapons don't just mean bigger damage. Lighter weapons such as katanas and daggers don't stagger enemies
column2: but things like greatswords and hammers do. Making you choose between speed and strength.

column1: -AI is nuts sometimes; I mean that in a good way. Some enemies will wait for you to try and heal/cast something before they take a stab at you. They will dodge and block projectiles very well too.

-World design is absolutely breathtaking; Each area and the enemies within is are unique in appearance (mostly). Being able to go from ""peaceful"" ol' Limgrave to the nightmarish hellscape that is Caelid very early on is the most terrifying thing in this game. The sudden shift in atmosphere
column2: the music
column3: and the change in enemies feels very much inspired by Berserk. I love it.

column1: -A lot of the dungeon designs are great: Obviously
column2: there is a lot of reused assets with them
column3: but the puzzles within the areas themselves are a breath of fresh air. They realize people don't wanna be able to just run through a dungeon. It is too straighforward. So
column4: what they did was implement some Silent Hill PT-style mapping that makes some areas ""wrap"" around with little things changed here and there.

column1: -NPCs are pretty memorable: This game does a great job of getting you attached to these characters and their endeavors. You'll encounter many of them several times throughout your progression and it is always a breath of relief to find another living thing that is not trying to kill you. Mostly...
Even the one-off NPCs are great. The ones that I personally love are the Jellyfish sisters. Hands-down the most beautiful moment in the game.
-New Game+ is great: I'm a bit of a completionist when it comes to games like this. So being able to continue and play through it again with the same character is right up my alley. Of course
column2: the enemies get tougher with each tier of NG+
column3: but they also drop more runes which makes it quicker for you to level your skills more.

column1: I genuinely think this is one of the best games I have ever played and quickly became favorite of mine. That said
column2: it is not without problems.

column1: Caveat before you start fondling FromSoft's nutsack; a lot of the following is my opinion and not fact.

column2: I know FromSoft isn't the best at optimizing their PC ports. It still should not be acceptable for them to leave the game a stuttering mess. Like many others
column3: I played the entirety of this game while stuttering every few minutes. If you did this too
column4: then you know how incredibly annoying and disheartening it is to be moments away from beating a boss when you suddenly get slapped with a stutter in the middle of the boss' attack
column5: where timed dodges are crucial. Several areas also suffer from extreme FPS drops
column6: obviously drawing inspiration from Blighttown in DS1.

column1: -Large enemies are not as big of a threat... when compared to the camera: When you use melee weapons to fight an enemy substantially larger than you
column2: you'll find yourself not using the target lock function because it will almost never be aimed at where you will be hitting. This is especially the case with the dragons.

the dragons: Arguably the most unfun enemies in this game next to damn birds. (Could it be a coincidence that I hate all the enemies with wings?) Dragons have the annoying tactic of flying away and crop-dusting an area with their breath attacks. The problem isn't the attack itself
column3: but the fact that sometimes is lingers a little too long and counts as 2 separate hits. 1 hit alone does damage; 2 hits is an insta-kill for someone like me who doesn't invest all their points into vigor.

column1: -One-shot attacks are not good game design: Like I said
column2: I don't put over 40 points into vigor. Why? I don't believe my health bar should be on par with that of a boss. It looks ridiculous and makes fighting enemies that one-shot you a lot less fun. Sure
column3: they keep those one-shot attacks mostly tied to bosses
column4: but it still doesn't make them challenging. A challenge would be several attacks to overwhelm you and deteriorate your health over time. Not a single near-unavoidable attack (inb4 ""git gud; learn 2 roll"". Go see 'Performance').

column1: -Some enemies deal substantially more damage than others: Things like birds and dogs end up dealing more damage per hit that some of the bosses. This type of ♥♥♥♥ is break immersion and makes those trash mobs more annoying than they should be.
-NPC quest progression is a chore: If you're familiar with any of the souls games
column2: then you know that properly progressing an NPC's story is damn near impossible without a guide. Nothing is really written out for you
column3: no markers on the map telling you where they'll be next
column4: and if you progress too far in the story before doing necessary steps for the NPC
column5: they'll vanish from your game or die. So be prepared to hug the wiki or YT guides if you care about the NPC stories.

column1: -Weapon variety is pretty much non-existent in PvP: Sure not many will care about this
column2: but running into the same handful of weapons over and over again when being invaded is so tiresome. I couldn't tell you how many times I have seen Rivers Of Blood being spammed.

column1: -Stealth is a half-assed gimmick: You get a tutorial that teaches you to use bushes to hide yourself from enemies
column2: but in pretty much every place afterwards
column3: those bushes are almost non-existent. The only purpose the stealth system serves is to get you easy backstabs... but only once
column4: because every other enemy nearby becomes alert as you're still in the middle of the execution. If you intend to use stealth to sneak past enemies
column5: don't bother. You're better off just running past them like in all previous souls games.

column1: -Platforming: Or lack thereof. Trying to ""platform"" in this game is just hoping you hit the sweet spot and your character doesn't slip off an edge during their recovery animation. If you fall
column2: you will almost always die due to the game having different scenarios in which a certain height will kill you.

column1: - The final boss is such a disappointment.
Again this is all my extremely casual souls enjoyer take. I don't ""cheese"" bosses and don't use unga bunga caveman tank builds. I enjoy a challenge
column2: but I don't enjoy downright lazy design.
I still enjoy the game a lot. In my opinion
column3: this game is a solid 7/10 in its current state. The game can still be polished and balanced. When it does
column4: I will gladly update this review. I may have also missed some things that I will add to this later.";209.1;1.0;1.0;584.0;Posted: May 20

I really took my time with this From Soft game. This is the first time I decided to do everything I needed to do for the Platinum in my first run through of one of their games. I kind of regret doing that
column2: because I did have to do a bit of research before continuing through the whole game
column3: but for the most part I played the game blind and what an incredible experience it was.

column1: I cannot get over the talent that this developer has for world design
column2: art style
column3: game mechanics
column4: and did I mention world design? My god. So good.

column1: Every time I would push forward into a new area
column2: whether it was Stormveil
column3: Caelid
column4: Weeping Peninsula
column5: Luirnia
column6: Altus Plateau
column7: Consecrated snowfields
column8: and on and on
column9: every single new push was something completely new
column10: fresh and exciting.

column1: I have seen some complaints online about the fact that they re-used assets and my jaw literally dropped open reading that.. Do they have recurring areas? Of course
column2: but pretty much every single rehash is side areas. Every. Single. major area and legacy dungeons are just completely unique and beautiful.

column1: By the time I got to Altus and saw how wildly different that area was - and by this point I was easily 100 hours into the game
column2: I was just in awe how the game kept surprising me and blowing my mind.

column1: I personally thought every major boss fight was a win except for the Elden Beast one. I just found it annoying and nonstop running around trying to get a single hit and then running around some more. Other than that though
column2: I had a blast.

column1: This game is now the second most played game in my Steam library by hours played only coming behind the Witcher 3 which is one of my favorite games of all time
column2: so that really says something. I am not someone who typically puts hundreds and hundreds (thousands) of hours into games. I like to beat the game
column3: get my enjoyment out of it and then move on to a new experience. So anytime I put upwards of 100 hours or more into a game
column4: you can rest assured it is a game that REALLY held my attention.

Since there's no neutral option I'm going with neg to point out some of the games flaws. Some of what I say may have spoilers
column2: but I'll try not to add any. Overall I enjoy the game and will continue to play it off and on
column3: but this is definitely the weakest souls game From Software has made in my opinion.

column2: it's solid
column3: but it's the jankiest of any FS souls game I've played
column4: has multiple glitches
column5: and the open world mechanics clash and weaken what I personally like about the souls games
column6: like a sense of achievement or reward. I went through my first time cold
column7: then my second time with a guide to comb through. I've been through a third since then
column8: and I've tried out about 2 builds per char.

column2: on PC at least. Summoning errors that have not been corrected since launch that only seem to effect a certain group of people (https://tinyurl.com/42rhh6nt) Body/rune recovery glitches
column3: broken quests (still) inaccurate stat scaling on multiple accounts (some fixed) Getting attacked through walls is way worse than it's ever been before - enemies and bosses read inputs as a cheap mechanism to kill you.

column1: -Overall I died more in this game to being overrun with surprise enemies than in any other souls game - being jumped and surrounded and stun locked seems to be the main thing in this game. As long as you are patient and use target lock there's not much of a challenge outside of a boss room or two.
-as for BOSSES - so many are reused it's sad. some of the main bosses are re-used over and over again in the open world dungeons
column2: which are quite often the same layout
column3: and just feel like weak busy work and excuses to kill time. Most can be completed in less than 10 minutes. a couple few may give you a challenge and last 30.

column2: that obscure souls quest system was fun and great in the more funneled design of the previous souls games. Having NPCS randomly move around such a large open world makes some quests impossible to understand without a guide.

column1: -While a a previous Dark Souls game may offer you multiple paths to take
column2: you'd always inevitably hit a boss you need to handle
column3: sometimes leaving you stuck between a rock and a hard place until you figured it out. The sense of accomplishment from this situation is gone
column4: since now you can run around the open world and level and gear to your hearts content. Without killing the first MINI boss
column5: you can comb every single area of the game minus a small handful of end game areas
column6: which only require 2 boss kills. The result is a lot of well geared invaders at lower levels stomping people. There's also no level cap on weapon buffs like the old games
column7: so a level 5 char can rock an end game +25 sword and invade your beginning char. This could happen in previous souls games
column8: but it took skill to pass the boss gates at the low levels to get that gear to invade. Not anymore.

column1: -The lack of design in the open world can be plainly seen
column2: and is mostly there as a huge time waster. There's not much reason to the day/night cycle besides some hidden bosses and some enemies may drop a small amount more of runes. The stealth mechanics are laughably OP and the AI is totally blind making free stealth damage a constant no matter what your build. A lot off items I'd usually just be able to buy from a vendor over and over with souls/runes are now replaced with crafting system crap I need to waste time to farm up instead. If you get invaded in the open world might as well just sit and wait for 5 minutes for the idiot to come running towards you lol. Just a lot of weakness in what I was expecting to be tighter gameplay.

column1: Overall this game is the worst where it strays from it's traditional design
column2: the open world is weak
column3: almost everything about it is a boring addition
column4: or weakens the strength of the souls formula
column5: I think it's a good first attempt
column6: but my hope in the future is they do more legacy type areas and far less open world areas
column7: the lack of having a funneled design in a lot of the open worlds places makes it weak
column8: exploitable
column9: and overall less enjoyable.";243.0;0.0;2.0;313.0;Posted: May 22

I was on the fence about buying Elden Ring
column2: but I really wanted a game with action combat and interesting bosses. How bad can it be
column3: I thought? Well
column4: I'm sure it's great for Soulsborne fans
column5: but if (like me) you just wanted something that was exciting without being a slog
column6: stay away.

column1: I'm not wholly unenthusiastic--the art direction and visual style is good
column2: and if they fixed the numerous things I am about to list below as the problems I had
column3: then I would genuinely enjoy the combat. I'm also told that previous games by this publisher used to be even less accessible
column4: so progress
column5: kind of
column6: I guess?

column1: But there are a lot of flaws I've already butted into with only a few hours of playtime (anyone who wants to tell me to ""git gud"" or similar should be aware there is a special circle of Hell for those who demand people treat their leisure time like a job).
--Co op with friends comes with mandatory PvP attackers you cannot opt out of. Also
column2: no form of scaling is available to make co op with higher level friends more functional if you are starting out.

column1: --Currency and XP are the same thing
column2: and both are lost on death. You can theoretically reclaim them
column3: but only within a limited window
column4: and there is no bank. Period.

column2: in addition to the loss of resources already mentioned
column3: you may not be able to get to the enemy that killed you to learn how to better deal with them for a while
column4: because pulling too many enemies at once will just murder you so you need to approach every fight cautiously--and therefore time-consumingly. Add to this that the theoretically great build variety comes with all sorts of animation details you need to learn
column5: and you're going to be spending a lot of time in loading screens and carefully approaching enemy camps and the like.

column1: --There are no difficulty settings of any kind
column2: which would be a thing that would allow the good of the game to shine through without making it disrespect the player's time availability nearly so much.
this is a game I very much want to like and simply cannot. More power to those who can
column3: but I want to warn those who like me
column4: were tempted by the acclaim into thinking it might be a decent casual dip of a game
column5: rather than a lifestyle you adopt for months.

column1: Addendum: I was able to do a ton of external research and conversations with friends and get to the point where I am enjoying the game now. I stand by my original review
column2: however
column3: as the game should not require that level of external resource use.";55.8;0.0;3.0;92.0;Posted: May 16

column1: So this is a full priced AAA 2022 game which has:
* PC controls which would not be considered acceptable even in the 1980s. (Even though you can rebind the keys
column2: this game was designed exclusively for a PS controller
column3: not a mouse/keyboard - so for instance
column4: the F key by default jumps - because that's how insane the PC controls are.)

column1: * UI design which would also not be considered be acceptable even in the 1990s
* Loading screen which shows a message box you have to click ""Accept"" on every time you go to the main menu. EVERY. SINGLE. TIME.
* Graphics which would be considered cutting edge back in 2006.

column2: but not one which you can actually follow. I finished it and as far as I can tell there's a ring (maybe? it's in the title of the game - but never seen it) and eventually <spoiler>you kill the ruler/god of the land and I guess that means you're in charge?</spoiler> I don't think I finished a single NPC's questline - and there were about 50 of them. I mean you could if you really
column3: really wanted
column4: but you'd have to Google how to do it and then follow the instructions exactly - if you deviate
column5: the questline just ends - with no notification whatsoever. While there is a map (thank god - the world is huge)
column6: only < 1% of the questlines actually put locations that you're supposed to go to on this map - to the extent that if you see a location marked on your map - you think it's a bug.

column1: * Intentionally annoying level design - which just consumes your time - but neither adds difficulty nor is fun. (You will die 500ish times in the course of playing this game - and each time
column2: you'll burn about 10s on a loading screen
column3: and then 20s-120s just running back to start the boss fight again). So that's about 20h of your life wasted.

column1: I find this notion that I will become powerful enough to breeze through every ""boss"" very hard to believe.(*)

column1: Some people love these kind of games

column3: as I've heard they really like this game—the pinnacle of the genre

column1: I'm just here to say: if you didn't like Dark Souls et al.

It’s no secret that Elden Ring has gained A LOT of praise. Besides the buggy launch with performance issues (welcome to the gaming industry for the last 15 years)
column2: most people have only great things to say about it. I’m more in the mixed camp.

column1: For the first time in the Souls series from Software
column2: it’s fun to use mage build. It’s VERY flexible and you have so many spells (if you can find them) to play around with. The Spirits is also a good addition if you lack co-op help.
while I do enjoy most of the game I also have gripes with it. But none of it makes it a silly super low score.

column1: The Easy Anti Cheat is really pointless and network stability when doing invading or co-op is unstable. Somehow this has gotten worse since Dark Souls 3. Which is weird. I do hope FromSoftware does a better job on online play in the future because it REALLY needs work. Framerate is still unstable and I’m sure if it’s the old game engine or the damn awful AC implementation used.
I know OPEN WORLD is very popular. Sadly Elden Ring’s map feels more like something from a Ubisoft game. By the end
column2: you have so many icons on the map that it’s ridiculous. Also
column3: the many mini-dungeons are really BORING. I know the previous games had smaller environments because of the consoles. But it also just worked pretty well for the games. Everything felt connected. I don’t feel that with Elden Ring.

column1: - The lock-on system is still awful and they REALLY need to update it with their next game as well.
- Unless you are hardcore and have A LOT of time
column2: good luck finding and understanding most things in the game without online guides. Some of these quests are old-school Nintendo Castlevania ♥♥♥♥ and not that interesting. Of course
column3: this is not new to the Souls series.

column1: For me the game is a 3/5 Stars

It’s not bad and there is fun to be had. No doubt. For me it’s just a mixed bag. + not greedy tactics from the publisher is good. But for me games like Bloodborne (PS4 only sadly) and Dark Souls 3 is still their best games to date.";122.6;0.0;0.0;258.0;Posted: May 21

Though video game enthusiasts often point out the medium's artistic merit
column2: there are few games that truly make the most of that opportunity. The ambitions of so many modern game developers seem so misplaced
column3: whether they're releasing ten first person shooters' a decade
column4: creating the most disgusting interpretation of a woman's body possible
column5: or writing a story that divides it's audience in it's attempt to reach towards a deeper connection. Elden Ring's ambitions are lofty
column6: yes
column7: but it fulfills them
column8: to their fullest extent. While it is not a perfect game
column9: it defines the artistic capabilities of video games

column1: The story of Elden RIng is truly like a spiderweb. Intricate
column2: beautiful
column3: haunting
column4: and hiding. There's only one exposition dump in the intro to the game
column5: and without context
column6: it's seeds remain in your head
column7: waiting for clues and information to water them into an understanding. The players who love a good story will find their curiosity rewarded greatly
column8: and the players who only care about killing enemies won't be burdened by heavy dialogue. I'll leave this review spoiler free
column9: but suffice it to say that many revelations in the plot are expertly handled
column10: and each one left my mind racing to connect the dots into the larger story. I have made four drafts of a family tree for this game
column11: all of which furthered my understanding. The story is not a sequence of events
column12: but a collection of information
column13: left to assemble itself in your head.

column2: the one drawback to this games style of storytelling is it's questing ""system"". Quest NPC's are loathe to provide information about where they're going
column3: or what they need you to do
column4: and unless you're a truly deranged person
column5: I suggest using a questing guide to play through the quests. If you prefer to have a more organic experience
column6: you won't have to use a guide
column7: but be warned
column8: many of the quests will completely slip past you
column9: and many of the endings will elude you.

column1: Learning to play this game is an amazing
column2: but incredibly challenging process. The amount of builds and playstyles is endless
column3: and every new start could have any combination of spells
column4: weapons
column5: armor
column6: and stats to go with it. How you choose to play this game will decide where you struggle
column7: and which bosses and enemies are challenging. A healer will steamroll a revenant
column8: for instance
column9: but struggle against enemies that deal more potent status effects. An archer will be able to fight many of the games enemies from a place of safety
column10: but will find that few of their foes will just sit their and be shot. A knight can fight skillfully from horseback
column11: but will notice that the enemy has their own cavalry to employ against them. Every playstyle has it's draws and disadvantages
column12: and they all feel both natural
column13: and encouraging.

column2: you are going to die. You are going to die a lot. You are to die a lot. Don't be discouraged if you've died dozens of times to a single boss
column3: and don't get cocky if you kill someone on your first try. Managing your confidence is just as important as managing your healthbar.

column2: this wouldn't be a category to even discuss. But
column3: this game is just . Every locale
column4: from every perspective
column5: is perfectly framed
column6: organically beautiful
column7: and inspires the kind of imagination that video games haven't done properly in decades. The trees
column8: the structures
column9: the landscapes
column10: everything in this game just blends into the most picturesque vistas imaginable. Jawdropping
column11: wondrous moments are commonplace in Elden Ring
column12: and it's rare to arrive to a new locale without finding the beauty in it's design.

column1: And the enemy designs! Whether they were just average footsoldiers
column2: or the most challenging boss in video game history
column3: or the animals roaming the Lands Between
column4: every single one of them is excruciatingly memorable. Puppets that dual wield bows
column5: dragons infested with illness
column6: t-rex's masquerading as dogs
column7: sorcerers wearing crowns of stone
column8: giant flowers! Oh! Elden Ring's enemy variety is unmatched
column9: and each one fits into the world exquisitely.

column1: Play Elden Ring. Play it if you love video games. Play it if you want to love video games. Play it. It's artistic achievement alone merits that
column2: but it's rewarding
column3: punishing
column4: and an experience unlike any other game out there. 10/10.";230.8;1.0;0.0;136.0;Posted: May 19

column1: Honestly not that fun on PC. Great reviews so I was excited to play this game. I enjoy the challenging nature of the fights. It's obvious that an incredible amount of care and attention has gone into making this game
column2: which I appreciate. But a few choices make it kind of irritating. I never know what the heck I'm supposed to do. Many other large
column3: open world games have some kind of quest tracking system
column4: typically integrated with the map. I've got over 30 hours into the game and I don't know if I'm working toward the main story or not. The artwork is intricate and highly stylized
column5: but seems too whimsical for me. Everything has a fairy tale
column6: dreamlike quality. It's also clearly designed for consoles. I purchased the steam version for PC and literally wasn't able to get through character creation since by default all the controls are for console. I needed to Google instructions to change the defaults to use keyboard and mouse. Is it so hard for the devs to make the PC version default to using PC for input? It seems more like the game designers just don't care about the player's convenience or happiness. The quick slot system makes it very hard on PC to change between for example sometimes using a bow and sometimes using a sword and shield combo. Finally there's no way to pause the game. If you're playing
column7: I hope you don't get a phone call or have a roommate or child that needs help
column8: because your character will just die since you cannot pause. Why? Maybe I'll try to load up some mods to make it more user friendly for PC... For reference
column9: I have not played Darksouls or any other FromSoftware games
column10: so maybe I'm struggling with a one-time learning curve. Other games I like include the Witcher Series
column11: Assassin's Creed series
column12: Elder Scrolls series
column13: particularly Skyrim which is probably my favorite game. Anyway
column14: I hope this review is useful.";71.7;0.0;2.0;13.0;Posted: May 19

column1: The Elden Ring is calling you Tarnished
column2: become an Elden Lord and claim your throne!

column1: Elden Ring is not a masterpiece.
Playing the Elden Ring is a constant ebb and flow of success and frustration. Before long
column2: the joy of defeating a boss can turn to frustration after encountering the main boss.

column1: Nothing is explained to the player. I was only able to learn the function of the game mechanics with the help of google and youtube. Whether it's leveling up the weapons with forging stones or the potions with the help of tears or the use of sound beads
column2: I only discovered it through the use of external sources.

column1: Almost the whole world is hostile to the player. There are hardly any neutral characters (apart from traders) or figures that are friendly to the player. As a result
column2: the world seems less alive and some of the incentive to find out more about the world is lost. I only found the existing sidequests by using google.

column1: One of the game's biggest flaws is the way the main story is told. The player does not notice much about the lore for which George R. R. Martin (Game of Drones) was hired
column2: especially at the beginning of the game. I only really understood the lore with the help of a YouTube video and was thus able to put the processes of the game in a meaningful context.
but it's not a masterpiece in my eyes. For me

I respect the business practices and all the art that went into this game. I think there are truly excellent parts. It's very repetitive
column2: the bosses are mostly unremarkable or unfair or simply annoying and the RPG elements are weaker than they've been in a Souls game in years. I can't recommend this game because it didn't make me feel anything new and was boring or annoying for the vast majority of the runtime.
there are so many dungeons smattered throughout the world that are caves
column3: catacombs
column4: mines
column5: etc. There are a few truly special ones
column6: but once you've beaten one of the generic ones
column7: you've beaten all of them. This system feels significantly worse than the much maligned chalice dungeons. Since the dungeons in Elden Ring are finite
column8: I felt a desire or hope to find something really interesting and unique in them. Instead
column9: they generally provide summons or weapons that were almost always useless. Without any extrinsic benefit
column10: you'd hope that they'd be fun. Unfortunately
column11: none of the dungeons provide satisfying puzzles and many of the bosses are just regular enemies from elsewhere put with a big health bar. Chalice dungeons had unique and good bosses
column12: extrinsic benefits that couldn't be gotten anywhere else
column13: and were a good mix of repetitive and challenging. This new dungeon system is a step backwards in most ways.

column1: That's just one area of this game that really shows its weaknesses. There's too much content with a lack of originality and specialness. There's so much good here spread out with long open plains and peppered with crap to fill the world. Compared with the games from Ubisoft and their ilk
column2: this is a triumph with commendable business practices and tons of wonderful elements. I think FromSoftware has released significantly better games in the past (Demon's Souls
column3: Dark Souls 1
column4: Bloodborne and Sekiro especially). You could probably play at least 2 or 3 of those in the time it'll take you for your first playthrough of Elden Ring. I highly recommend doing that instead.";96.8;0.0;2.0;72.0;Posted: May 17

column1: I've extensively played Sekiro and DS1-3

the few really tough bosses in Elden Ring need excess RNG to win (without investing ridiculous time mastering or using cheese)
column3: and you miss that sense of reward from predicting a bosses moveset (also in sekiro's case
column4: new skills help tip the battle in your favour in balanced ways). Certain bosses in Elden Ring feel more like a chore than a challenge.

column1: Three other key related issues: too many copypasta enemies/bosses
column2: crazy input reading
column3: and overly delayed attacks. The latter two make fights feel like you're facing a computer code more than anything. There are still some wonderful areas and bosses
column4: just not as many with the calibre of other souls games.";92.2;0.0;0.0;14.0;Posted: May 22

column1: I tried giving this game a good review
column2: but it simply is not fun if you ever try to summon any friends. You get invaded every 3 minutes by people with higher levels. They are always fully equipped
column3: they are always overlevelled
column4: and their main move is rolling. When in doubt
column5: roll it till you make it. It's an atrocity. I've played the original Demon's Souls on PS3 where invasions added a touch of danger to the game
column6: but this is just stupid. The developers put no thought into this at all.

column1: Nowadays there is too many players active
column2: and you simply can't enjoy yourself. The invasions don't add anything to the experience if they are so methodical. It's just repetitive annoyance. The only players here having fun are the invaders
column3: everybody else be damned.

column1: I've been trying to play the same strip of 15 meters with my friend for weeks. It's impossible
column2: you simply can't. You get invaded over and over and over and over. 90% of the time by the same person with no life at all
column3: who sit there and only invade.

column1: Edit: We do manage to kill the invader sometimes
column2: but seems like we get a 10 minute grace period after which the invasions just keep on coming again. A grace period of 35 minutes or at least banning the same person from re-invading for a while would have helped. Instead you get the same invader often 3-4 times. Even if you defeat them
column3: they just keep coming back.";61.1;0.0;3.0;366.0;Posted: May 21

column1: If you don't have enough stress in your life and need something that makes you want to kick puppies
column2: if hours worth of pissing contests is your cup of tea

column4: this is the game for you!

column2: you are the type of person who plays games to wind down or have fun

column1: Elden ring is like going through a maze with a blind fold on while people hit you in the face with baseball bats. The little bit of story there is in the game tends to have many steps to it and very little of it has any guidance
column2: expect extensive use of Google. If the game actually tried to have a meaningful story
column3: other than a general idea of one
column4: it could have been enjoyable enough to justify the purchase for me but as it stands it was a waste.

column1: - Graphics are about average for current games (character creation is an exception).

column2: while most often frustrating can be fun sometimes.

column1: - The builds and leveling seem rewarding and can be interesting.
- Finding something interesting or a secret area can often be an enjoyable experience.
- Mods made the game playable for me. I shouldn't have to mod a game to make it enjoyable
column2: at least it's not terribly difficult to do.

column1: - The characters you meet in the game are mostly shallow
column2: not well written or have any real effort put into them. After 70 hours of play
column3: I haven't found any character I care about or care what they have to say.

column1: - Very little direction as to where to go and what to do
column2: some see this as a positive but I don't because the only way to find out your in the wrong place is to get your face beat in and keep getting your face beat in until you find a place where you don't get smashed(or google it). Wander aimlessly around until you find something interesting and repeat that until you can get through one of the areas where you previously got your face beat in.

column1: - Character creation is clunky and out dated. Women don't really look like women
column2: they look like ugly men with boobs. It feels like the designers forgot to have women in the game and added the option last minute?

column1: - Can't figure out where to go to get that thing you need to progress to the next area? Google. Can't figure out where to find that weapon or armor you need? Google. Google. Google..... Annoying.

- Experience points and money are the same thing. Interesting idea except that you can lose it all when you die. Losing hours worth of experience when you are unable to get to the same place you died isn't fun. While it's not a big deal early game
column2: late game when you are talking about millions of experience is a big deal and not fun.

column1: - Online play. While Co-op could be fun the rest is really stupid and pointless. Invasions are for those who really enjoy the pissing contest aspect of the game
column2: really not my thing
column3: I'm not 12. The notes players can leave for other players could be interesting and worth while if the people who were leaving notes weren't 12 and obsessed with genitalia and butts. The blood stains allowing you to see how other people died is rarely ever useful either as it's mostly just people jumping off cliffs or doing something similarly stupid. The ghosts of other players and the path they take is also interesting but again poorly executed as they look a lot like the ghost mobs so they can cause frustrating deaths when you mistake a player's ghost for a mob while you are in a dark cave where you can't really tell what is going on in the first place.";69.9;0.0;4.0;65.0;Posted: May 20

column1: Elden Ring Is my favourite game of all time now. This is the best Action RPG I have ever played and blows every other Action RPG out of the water. Forget Assassins Creed
column2: Forget Bioshock
column3: Forget God of War
column4: Forget Mass Effect 2
column5: Forget Skyrim and Forget Witcher 3. Elden Ring is the new king.

column2: it's epic and beautiful to look at
column3: the freedom to go anywhere is fantastic
column4: their are so many surprises and secrets
column5: exploration is really fun and you're not bogged down with collectables to find and endless fetch quests. The game after the tutorial cave never holds your hand
column6: no map markers showing you exactly were to go and no objectives.

column1: Like all Soulsborne this game is hard but if you're struggling with a boss you can ride off on Torrent and grind runes to level up before trying that tricky boss again. The combat is FROM software's best I think it is the perfect balance of all the other FROM software titles
column2: more intense than DS3 but not as frenetic and punishing like Sekiro.

column1: Their is a good mix of bosses with some extremely challenging ones but unlike previous FROM games some bosses are easy. Several bosses have 2 phases and some have added challenge like adding debuffs
column2: being invisible or having backup. Their are plenty of field bosses and tough enemy groups roaming around and night time you will find some even tougher field bosses. The main story is typical FROM
column3: you can follow the fundamental story but it's dense and will take multiple play through's and online lore explanations to truly grasp the full story.

column1: Elden Ring is now the benchmark for all future open world action RPG's. The game respects the player and rewards you for your curiosity and patience. You are free to tackle the game anyway you want and the games challenge makes it even sweeter when you see the credits roll. Wow
column2: what a game and I still have some hidden endings to unlock in New Game +.";274.0;1.0;0.0;301.0;Posted: May 17

column1: Reason number 1 by far: There are so many bosses and mini bosses that are the same or just randomly put together in different combinations over and over and over again. It is boring and I am sick and tired of it. The general vibe of wanting to beat a boss and progress is just done for me in this game.
Number 2: The world gets emptier and emptier the further you progress. It's boring.

Number 3: The clipping issues on some armor are ridiculous for a 2022 game. Bull-Goat set for example is the biggest cancer I've ever seen in any game. And why does heavy armor always need to look as stupid in any FromSoft game anyway?
Number 4: Multiplayer balancing needs serious rework done.
Maybe some DLCs will bring change but I am not to hopeful.";159.7;0.0;3.0;86.0;Posted: May 20

column1: If you think I got some detail wrong
column2: feel free to inform me so. Now to the review.

column1: This game is a waste of potential. It takes the fantastic concept of challenging bosses that make you feel godly and are extremely rewarding upon their defeat and removes the ""make you feel godly part"". Ill compare this to hollow knight(Hence
column2: spoilers for hollow knight ahead) since these 2 games share some very similar ending sequences: Radagon-Elden Beast and Hollow Knight-Radiance

you first have to fight a stupidly unbalanced boss that will hit you with carbon molecules he exhaled from his ass before being able to fight a boss that will keep a distance of 9 marathons from you all while spamming so many projectiles you forget what a projectile even is. Whenever you die you have to go through the stupidly unbalanced boss every time
column3: effectively draining everything you have-potions
column4: summons
column5: you name it
column6: before putting you in another fight.

column1: Now the game I draw comparison to: Hollow Knight. In it
column2: you follow a very similar formula: fight a boss to reach the other one
column3: have to refight the entrance boss every time you die. Now here is the magic of hollow knight: the fight isnt overly challenging in comparison to other fights in the game. The fight is actually very well balanced-all the attacks are perfectly manageable(Im looking at you
column4: Radagon's 10 mile long hammer slam hit-you-with-his-ass hitboxes). Beyond that
column5: Hollow Knight
column6: too
column7: has an invincibility-roll kind of mechanic with it's dashes at that point in the game. So what makes the fight different? Literally everything. Hollow Knight is there(in my opinion
column8: I know a lot of people see it as a big flaw) to make YOU feel hollow. The fight is simple-its just a gate to get to the final boss. If you die to the final boss once
column9: it feels like a punishment
column10: after all
column11: chances are
column12: you got your ass kicked into nothing by the Hollow Knight
column13: but you get progressively better and better at it to the point where you feel like a god
column14: until eventually you fight him so many times the feeling fades away and you are fully focused on defeating radiance
column15: at which point it is you successfully ""contain"" it. Now what happens in Elden Ring in the same exact scenario: you are alive by a single strand of hp with 4 potions as you go into the final boss
column16: you die. You then die to Radagon 7 more times before getting to the boss again
column17: you die. You eventually get good enough where you beat him consistently but it kind of stops there for your average Joe. You get your ass kicked over and over and over. If this is a roleplaying game the role you are playing is the victim of abuse. When I finally defeated the Elden Beast I didnt get a feeling of ""HELL YEAH FINALLY"" like I did with the radiance
column18: rather it was ""finally this fat ♥♥♥♥ is dead"". It felt like a burden. In case you cant see the issue here-Hollow Knight(the boss
column19: not the game itself) was BUILT to be a burden and yet felt 10x less of a burden than whatever the hell Elden Ring has going. And dont even get me started on how bleed-a whole major build type-was disabled in its entirety on the fight. I could draw many more similar examples-Malenia and Mantis lords(both fast paced and very punishing fights) for example. And don't even get me started on the quests here. They are so horrible they dont deserve to be spoken of. Basically the main issue is how unbalanced boss battles are(took the challenging for the sake of challenging path instead of challenging for the sake of rewarding path)

column1: best game of the year!!!!";27.1;1.0;0.0;24.0;Posted: May 23
The game has one of the most enormous and intricately detailed worlds I have ever seen in gaming. The castles
column2: cities
column3: and fortresses that you must traverse in this game are truly awe inspiring. They are all massive
column4: unique and filled with a plethora of secret areas just waiting to be uncovered. The landscapes of the world are also astonishing. The sheer variety and scale of the environments is a sight to behold. Players can expect to explore vast mountains
column5: forests
column6: fields
column7: deep caves
column8: ancient ruins
column9: and even secret underground civilizations. It is clear that a great amount of work went into the design of all of these areas
column10: as they are all exceptionally detailed and have complex lore
column11: realism
column12: and beauty to them that makes them a joy to explore.

column1: The combat in the game is utterly masterful
column2: blending elements from many of FromSoftware's previous works including Dark Souls 3
column3: Bloodborne
column4: and Sekiro to create an extremely tense
column5: fluid
column6: and customizable combat system. The amount of variety in terms of different play styles
column7: build variation
column8: and weapon types is enough to make the combat in this game endlessly enjoyable.

column1: The boss roster of Elden Ring is extremely difficult and unforgettable. Most of the boss battles are remarkably challenging
column2: rich with lore
column3: and breathtaking to behold. The complex fighting style of the bosses can also not be overlooked. Many of the bosses have extremely intricate
column4: fast
column5: and punishing attacks that are both extremely difficult to avoid and fun to fight against. This makes the battles against the bosses feel like a dance
column6: as you rhythmically dodge their devastating combo attacks before finding small windows to go on the of offensive. This is nothing new
column7: as this style of boss encounter is exactly what the Dark Souls series pioneered. However
column8: Elden Ring perfects this age old formula by giving the bosses bigger move sets
column9: greater speed
column10: and more complex combos than ever before. Some of the bosses can hammer you with 10 hit long combos with little margin for error
column11: and the player must master a boss' move set if they ever hope to come out on top. When you combine this with the grotesquely stunning visual design of the bosses
column12: you get some of the most tense and engaging boss battles in gaming history.

column2: the epic scope of the boss encounters and vast areas is further heightened by Elden Ring's stellar musical score. Many of the soundtracks in this game are utterly blood pumping in a way that few other video game scores can match.
in my opinion
column3: Elden Ring more than lives up to the enormous hype surrounding it
column4: proving to be one of the most memorable
column5: challenging
column6: and complex gaming experiences of the last century.";54.5;1.0;0.0;35.0;Posted: May 23

column1: In short: Best game ever for me despite its shortcomings.
- Open World is super fun the first time around. Exploration is interesting
column2: so many places to discover
column3: loot to pillage
column4: bosses to fight.

column2: while simple at first
column3: their layouts get more and more intricate in later zones and stay refreshing and interesting.

column2: so much loot to gather
column3: so many interesting builds to build.

column2: humongous. Tons of different stuff to do every playthrough
column3: and the build potential is massive in this game. You can also create many builds very early in the game
column4: so every run can feel somewhat fresh.

column2: more improved than ever
column3: the jump button/attacks
column4: the new counter mechanic
column5: and myriads other smaller things keep the combat familiar
column6: yet refreshing enough ever for veterans to the series like me. Being able to jump over certain attacks (slashes/ground effects) is very interesting also and brings a new dynamic to the table.

column1: - Narrative/Lore/Story: Phenomenal. The game is set in an extremely interesting fantasy world
column2: with unlimited potential for sequels/DLCs
column3: and very satisfying puzzle pieces laid out carefully throughout the game for you to piece together and make your own stories. I would defo recommend having a digital
column4: or handwritten journal for more immersion.

column2: phenomenal. Many times I would stop and taking out the binoculars to marvel at amazing vistas
column3: or I'd rotate my camera to take in the amazing scenery
column4: take screenshots
column5: etc. I will never forget some of the best places I've visited in the game.

column2: a mixed bag of decent to extremely good tracks.

column1: - Npc side quests: some of the best in the series
column2: really interesting lore to be found from nearly all of them.

column1: - Bosses: The best in all of soulsborne. Some may disagree
column2: but even with the overuse of certain bosses
column3: the general quality of bosses is above and beyond any of the other souls games
column4: and some of the optional bosses in Elden Ring are ''DLC quality'' compared to previous From Software's games. A Crucible Knight may be overused
column5: but his varied moveset and different weapon/fighting styles is more interesting than half the bosses in every Soulsborne game
column6: and he is not even a ''main boss''.

column1: - 4 of the endings are copy pasted
column2: with just a word difference and a color palette. In my opinion
column3: they should have gone a bit further
column4: some more different lines would have been nice.

column1: - Many spells/ashes of war are still not worth using
column2: as they weren't really looked at even with the tuning passes. Hopefully something to be fixed in the future.

column1: - Extremely bad optimisation. I hope that it will be fully fixed eventually. It's disheartening to see even ppl with 3080s struggle and stutter when playing this game.
- Online connectivity is in shambles. There are entire zones where you can't even summon due to your summon getting disconnected the moment they get in your hosted game (looking at you Siofra River
column2: and certain parts of Volcano Manor). Also you can get randomly dc'ed even with good connection.

column1: - Co op: While fine for other souls games
column2: there are simply too many barriers for Elden Ring and how ''mainstream'' the title has become. Having ''fog walls'' to enter dungeons
column3: and having to resummon your friend
column4: or when crossing to a different zone
column5: not being able to summon for evergaols
column6: not being able to summon in certain zones after you killed the legacy dungeon boss
column7: etc is BAD. I always play my first playthrough solo
column8: and in general I am a solo player
column9: but my partner and I like to do a co op playthrough
column10: and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥'s fun but also extremely painful.

column1: - Overuse of certain assets. It is okay that the game reuses assets
column2: bosses
column3: etc. HOWEVER
column4: it is NOT OKAY to have 14 Erdtree Avatars
column5: Ulcerated Defiled Tree Spirits
column6: 20 deathbirds
column7: reusing a couple of the ''main bosses'' as stronger foes. It basically removes the ''charm'' of ''Oh dude
column8: finally time to fight this guy again!'' to a ''Ah not this guy again''.

column1: That was all for me personally. 9/10 game. I hope that this review was helpful
column2: and I hope to see you in the lands between fellow TARNISHED!!!";313.3;1.0;0.0;31.0;Posted: May 23

column1: I dumped 70 hours into it in my first 6 days of playing it. God help my soul.
The individual fights don't have as many highlights as some other Soulsborne games
column2: but there is just so much more to do compared to the rest. It can easily make up for that.

column1: Music is quite a bit weaker than earlier titles
column2: but this is hardly damning
column3: as FromSoft has a track record of incredible music
column4: so that just means the music is slightly above average rather than their usual excellence.

column1: Hopefully the DLC can fix both of these issues.
The side questlines are a little unintuitive as is the progression paths.
It's also quite easy to end up accidentally in situations where you are either massively over or massively under-leveled for an area over your playtime. Equally
column2: it is quite possible to end up accidentally breaking NPC questlines
column3: with nothing to tell you what you did wrong bar asking online. Far from ideal.

column1: Both issues come across as growing pains as the developers transition from a linear to a much more non-linear game structure. Hopefully this shall be resolved in the sequel that I expect is bound to happen.
Stat scaling is also a touch unintuitive. For those approaching blind
column2: Vigor scales non-linearly
column3: rising and then falling in value per level
column4: peaking in value as one levels from 30-40. I mention this stat first
column5: as lack of this knowledge can easily gimp one's progression as one finds oneself getting one shot by most hits if one doesn't bother with vigor soon enough as one can do in other Soulsborne games. Other stats scale much the same.

column1: A few mechanics and areas come across as rather clearly underdeveloped
column2: the easiest example to point towards being ""Madness"" as a status effect
column3: being massively underrepresented
column4: and the areas associated with it seeming rather barren. Hopefully this will end up being resolved in DLC and was just a result of limited development time.

column2: game is real good and worth buying if you are already a fan of the series
column3: or if you think the open world might help you approach the game if previous games had too much of a barrier to entry. Hoping very much for DLC in the same vein as the Dark Souls 1 DLC
column4: with significantly harder bosses.";95.3;1.0;0.0;135.0;Posted: May 23

column2: there are many quests in elden ring but it doesn't help you keep track of any of the info and it also doesn't tell you whether the questline is completed or not. some NPCs will ask you for certain things or to do something without giving you any directions or hints. NPCs would also move all around the map without any indication on where to find them for the next part of the questline. Some quests doesn't even tell you what to do next to progress the questline

column4: the only choice you have is to either do it or not. Quests are huge part of open world games and so far Quests are the weakest link in elden ring. I spent a lot of time looking at quest guides just to finish the questlines.

column1: Elden Ring is one of the best games I've ever played. But that does not mean it is not without flaws. Here is how I would like to rate Elden Ring.
Gameplay: 5/10 (Its failed where it was expected to be the best)

Elden Ring is the most welcoming of all Souls game because of this open world and AI summon system. Elden Ring was made to appeal a broader audience. There in lies the problem. You cannot make a ""one size fits all"" type of game. Even though Elden Ring does not have a difficulty setting
column2: people experience extremely different combat when playing with or without AI summons.

all combats (including boss fights) are extremely trivialized. AI summons are like a get out of jail free card. And that is fine because it is a choice of every player. I chose to not use summons and completed the game the first two times. I had to deal with ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ but made it. But on my third playthrough when the bosses have more HP and damage
column3: I started feeling the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ even more and started thinking about it. All the bosses after you go to mountain tops have a sudden spike in difficulty.

column1: And the difficulty is unfair difficulty
column2: the kind of difficulty which is not fun to deal with. Bosses will have tons of 50/50 mixups like in actual fighting games. Its fair in fighting games because all characters are roughly equal. But in a souls game
column3: getting the wrong guess can mean getting 1 shot or combo'ed to death. That bring us to the second non-sense. Bosses have combo attacks and attacks designed to catch rolls. If they hit you once they are pretty much guaranteed to hit you again. If you someone manage to roll out
column4: you will get caught by their delayed roll catching attack like a aeo ground stomp.

column1: Then there is the combo attacks. The end game bosses will keep doing big moves where all you can do is dodge dodge dodge. They finally finish the combo and you think its now your turn to hit
column2: the boss will say ""nope"" and start doing another combo. Or it will just float in the air (or just swim to the other side of arena) and start throwing ranged attack. Like when do I get to hit.

column1: And did I tell you about the input-reading? When you are at low hp
column2: the boss will menacing walk towards you and not do any attack. Just when you feel safe and start drinking your flash
column3: the boss will do a rush attack or ranged attack.

column1: All these ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ mechanics force very passive play where you wait for the boss to make the first move or just keep chasing it around the entire arena. And this kind of difficulty is not fun. I though about these problems and realised this is because the end game bosses were designed with AI summons in mind. Because the AI summons made the early game to easy
column2: they had to amp up the difficulty if you want a hard experience at the late game. The bosses are hyper aggresive because they are assuming you will have a AI summon to share the aggro. But if thats the assumption
column3: what about the players that decided to not use summons? They are either forced to deal with all the ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ (which is possible but not fun) or use the AI summons (which isn't fun either because they want to 1v1 experience).

column2: they should have 2 different set of boss AI depending on summons
column3: they wanted to make a game that pleases everyone afterall. Overall the end game bosses are an unbalanced mess which makes Elden Ring a flawed masterpiece.";335.7;1.0;0.0;102.0;Posted: May 23

column1: Having just finished the Elden Ring Achievement (Get all other achievements)
column2: this is solidly my favorite From Soft game. If you're reading this review and aren't sure if you should get it
column3: I have two answers for you. If you're a fan of the Souls games
column4: GET. IT. NOW. If you're not a previous fan of the Souls games
column5: wait till it goes on sale (if it goes on sale)
column6: then give it a shot.

column1: I'm not going to go full fanboy and say that this game is a perfect 10/10. Because it's not. But if you can look past the flaws
column2: it's a superb experience
column3: and the culmination of the Souls Series as a whole. It has some of the most polished mechanics
column4: builds
column5: spells
column6: you name it. It's clear to me that having played the Dark Souls trilogy
column7: and seen Bloodborne and Demon's Souls
column8: that From Soft really have learned from their previous titles and applied that to making this the best of their titles. Bloodborne fans
column9: yall are welcome to disagree with me
column10: but until I get the chance to play Bloodborne for myself
column11: Elden Ring is the de-facto best.

column1: Most of the problems I'm willing to overlook
column2: but the one key one that I want to mention in the review is this: QUEST LOG. PLEASE.
I LOVE how expansive the game is. I love how many quests there are
column3: and I love how many LORE quests there are. What I don't love is how easy it is to skip 80% of them. From Software has never had straightforward quests
column4: and that's one of the things I adore about the game. However
column5: the ability to skip key moments by progressing too far in the game is frustrating. Take Dark Souls 1 for instance. To follow Solaire's quest line
column6: you had to meet him at each. And. Every. Location. He wouldn't show up at the next spot till you'd talked to him at the last one. In this game? It's entirely possible to miss half of Blaidd's questline because of how he interacts with another quest line.

column1: The two solutions I'd propose for Elden Ring 2
column2: or whatever next game From Soft does
column3: is to either implement a quest log (Seriously
column4: there's like a LOT of quests up in here)
column5: and/or restrict each NPC to their locations until you've come by and talked to them. But I will emphasize this: This is an annoyance
column6: not a deal breaker. Frankly
column7: if the Quest Log was the size of a typical Dark Souls quest log
column8: I don't know that I would notice. Just another case of an Open World game being so massive and open that it gets a little overwhelming.

column1: Having just finished my third play-through of this game (The minimum required to get all achievements)
column2: I'm still finding locations I never realized were there. I'm still finding weapons I didn't know existed. And I'm still finding spells I've only heard mentioned in passing on YouTube. And as of writing this I have 245 hours in the game. 245 hours and I'm still finding new stuff.

column1: If you're in the market for a game that you can spend a lot (And I mean A. LOT.) of time in
column2: look no further than Elden Ring. Not the BEST game in the world
column3: but it's certainly the best From Soft game.";248.2;1.0;0.0;90.0;Posted: May 23

TL;DR: This is one of the greatest games I have ever played. Elden Ring is a nearly flawless execution of an open world Souls formula. It is Fromsoft's magnum opus.

I've been waiting for this game since it was first announced. I've been a longtime Souls veteran and Fromsoft has never disappointed. This game is no exception. It's very rare these days for games to not only deliver on their promise
column2: but to be just as good or even better than originally expected. At the time of this review
column3: I've cleared the game with 8 different character builds.

column1: - The Souls formula is kept intact and has a few more quality-of-life changes such as shorter runbacks or the option to go somewhere else if you are struggling with a particular area.
- This game is massive and provides hundreds of hours of content. You'll frequently think you'd explored most of the map and then the map doubles in size.
- You can eventually go to any place you can see
column2: and there will almost always be some sort of reward for getting there.
there is tons of replayability via different builds

column1: - This game respects your intelligence and very rarely holds your hand
column2: which is a great thing. Too many modern games treat you like an idiot.

column1: - If you are new to the Souls formula
column2: this game gives you many tools to make this one of the most accessible entries in the series.

column1: - If you are a Souls veteran
column2: you might find some of the bosses to be among the most difficult by restricting yourself from using many tools.

column1: - Several non-story bosses are reused a few times

I think FromSoft's Souls-Like lineup are the best video games to date. Demon's Souls
column3: Dark Souls
column4: Bloodborne
column5: and Sekiro are all phenomenal masterpieces. The way they continue to catch lightening never ceases to amaze me
column6: creating borderline heroine addicting worlds
column7: themes
column8: and gameplay loops. That being said
column9: I'm not going to suck off FromSoft and disregard the issues this game has
column10: which are many.

column1: This game is a mega mashup of all of their previous games
column2: which means you will be seeing a lot
column3: and I mean A LOT of reused assets. I don't think there's anything inherently wrong with a company reusing something they've already created
column4: but my issue stems more from the reusing of already reused assets. I've played all of the Souls games
column5: multiple times. I have seen the Vanguard turn into the Asylum Demon
column6: the Asylum Demon be set on fire
column7: then the Asylum Demon set me on fire
column8: then it cool down and turn into this decrepit Asylum Demon
column9: then the Asylum Demon morph into a tree trunk. Normally
column10: I'd let this slide
column11: but when I see him 7 times more
column12: in the SAME game
column13: let's just say it gets old rather quickly. This goes the same for dungeons
column14: what's the point of boasting non RNG based dungeons if the good majority of them are the same mini-bosses and littered with the same god-awful golems (which are ALREADY a reskinned enemy) over and over again. Of course there are a few exceptions to the dungeons
column15: some have neat gimmicks and on rare occasions
column16: NPCs. I have a hunch that a lot of these instances were placeholders that FromSoft never got around to finishing.

column1: Piggybacking off of my last statement
column2: this game feels unfinished. Of course this is due to the mind boggling size of the game
column3: even after I beat it I've found several locations/questlines I've missed
column4: thinking that I 100%'d the game. The closer you get to endgame
column5: the less things seem to matter. SPOILER TERRITORY: For example
column6: after Radahn is defeated
column7: Limgrave gets a significant change
column8: but everything almost seems unchanged when the Elden Beast is slain. I've seen two different endings
column9: and aside from like a thirty second cutscene
column10: there's almost no in game effect
column11: I mean even some of the characters don't recognize that you've become a lord or whatever ending you've chosen. Truth be told
column12: it doesn't really bother me that much
column13: I don't know what the hell is going on and to say that Elden Ring has a ""story"" is the equivalent of giving a bunch of chess pieces some lore and calling the chess board a book. But to spend countless hours collecting these random curses littered around them
column14: violating a man with a scat fetish several times
column15: just to find out that if I chose his ending versus hot gluing the head of the boss I just defeated makes no difference in the world is kinda disappointing. Come to think of it
column16: the only reason I wanna see the different endings is to laugh at my character
column17: who just looks like a depressed banana.
