column1: A word of warning: This game does NOT hold your hand.

column2: this game will test your reflexes
column3: your tactics
column4: your memory
column5: and your patience. All of which can be stressful. However the community is mostly sweet
column6: and the amount of kindness I've received from other players is astronomical. From soft games get a lot of flack from the loud minority of try hard ""git gud"" community
column7: but even in DS1-3 this was never the case.

column1: Even when invaded most invaders were willing to go with my mimic shenanigans and join in. It's been really fun.
Lore is peppered throughout the game in conversations
column2: item descriptions
column3: and visual story telling as per the usual in fromsoft games
column4: and it is just as good here. There are very high moments in the game
column5: like reuniting people that were separated
column6: and really really steep lows
column7: like releasing a monster that kills and mutilates a rather nice npc.

column2: and there are many ways to utilize multiple weapons at once. However: your attack animations will play out fully before the next attack will execute. With fast weapons like claws
column3: this isn't an issue
column4: but with high level spells
column5: incantations
column6: and even large weapon attacks
column7: this MUST be taken into account when you fight or you will suffer.

column1: There are many things to find tucked away in small areas of the map
column2: plenty of hidden little things to find
column3: and lots of fun to be had.

column1: The only thing I'd like to request from Fromsoft...Just make a optional co-op mode without the summoning. People have been asking for this since DS1 and it continues to be the case. We love playing with our friends
column2: so just let us

column1: FROM Software's largest Souls-like to date impresses on almost every level - it simultaneously innovates the open-world genre with its laid-back approach to guidance despite nearly every inch of the unimaginably vast map being filled with content
column2: and still retains the core values of the ""Souls"" Action RPG genre that has earned it brand loyalty beyond measure.
balancing issues on the PvP angle has promoted a very stale meta
column3: encouraging use of phantoms and certain weapons/spells above everything else. If the servers are ever restored to their previous six-man functionality or even improved further beyond

column1: This game is tons of fun. I have really enjoyed my time with it
column2: however it feels incredibly unbalanced at times. Some boss fights are exceedingly hard to do solo
column3: but then summoning a spirit ash completely trivializes the fight. Repeats of certain boss fights and re-using of assets gives the impression that the dev team was rushed to fill in the world. Some late game overworld enemies do more damage per hit than late game bosses. Speaking of late game bosses
column4: the final fight is the most ridiculous I have ever done. Running around for 45 minutes and dodging 6 insta kill attacks for the chance to land exactly one hit on the boss felt like poor design choice. You should be able to summon your horse for this fight. That said
column5: the combat and magic system in the game is really well crafted and gives players a myriad of play styles to choose from making replays more interesting. The world is huge and feels fun and exciting to explore most of the time (late game area being an exception). The lore is sparse but draws you in and makes you want to know more about the world. The world building is really one of the strongest aspects of this game
column6: no surprise there. Overall I give the game an 8.5/10. One of my personal favs of all time
column7: but not without flaw.";225.9;1.0;0.0;62.0;Posted: May 22

column1: Where do Is start with this game? Here's what I don't like about this game.

Garbage Bosses with quality all over the place. endless attacks with no punish windows and the character feels like they're the Chosen Undead fighting Inner Isshin but can now jump. They didn't fix some issues with traversal and the fall height killbox is the same as other souls games. Horse combat is really mediocre. The dungeons and catacombs are all garbage and really gimmicky. The endgame is a complete wreck with tons of balance issues across the board and amplifies everything I didn't like about this game.
Why you should buy Elden Ring
The bosses are some of the best in the series
column2: when they are good they are GOATED. The open wold is breathtaking and amazing to explore with something new around every corner
column3: even the seventeenth time. The combat feels great when it works. The first 2/3rds of this game is one of the greatest games ever made. It is well worth the price of admission. Everything negative just melts away when I look back at his game. Elden Ring is an 9/10 game that provides a 10/10 experience from the first playthrough to future ones. Does it have issues
column4: yes

Fantastic game. As a long time fan of the souls series
column2: this game was everything I was hoping for and more.

column1: The are some issues with the pc version
column2: mainly occasional stuttering and crashes. Personally
column3: I have not found these frequent enough to not enjoy the game. Specs follow.

column2: but I don't enjoy it as the way the game was intended to be enjoyed. Kill a giant creature? Great! Rewards! Do more! Feels like how most of the 10 or so friends playing this game enjoy it. When I am playing it I am thinking about the characters within a ruined world who are all struggling for some sense of happiness
column3: that through difficulty and death after death
column4: I am able to offer them. I have only enjoyed this game most when I met a character
column5: and got excited that I got to see another human being. Most of the game is not this however. I get minor joys from traveling and beating a boss feels annoying and pointless to me. The rewards in this game are not great big rewards all the time. Most of the time you are getting minor bonuses for hard fights. Sometimes a cool reward is an exciting thing for me but I never felt that consistently as
column6: when you get to a certain point
column7: you already have all that you need. Most people don't even bother going and fighting bosses blind. Everyone just looks up online where the best items and gear are making the exploration and discovery virtually pointless. The moments of joy in the game
column8: I call joy because they are intense feelings of happiness you get from trudging through difficulty after difficulty to get there
column9: but these joys are far and in between long hours of play. I love open worlds but I also love characters in them. This world feels empty. I barely see any other people and when I do its completely possible I might miss them or kill them
column10: or trigger a fight with them by accident. When I go to places I know people are just to get some modicum of life out of the game
column11: someone to talk to (whether I liked them or not) They always give the same dialogue or are just not there anymore. The game on its own is hard to play not just because of its high difficulty cap
column12: but its way of handling this world and experience is very lonely and dead. That is intentional. This game is supposed to feel that way. Like holding a torch and swinging it in the dark looking for more embers to keep the light going while water rains from above at any random moment
column13: you are fighting the darkness trying to reach some safety
column14: some happiness. That happiness feels all the stronger and more powerful for it. My problem with this game is that on my own I would never have figured that out. I had to look a thing or two up online as well to enjoy it. This game is not for everyone
column15: and it does not feel like it was made for me
column16: but I found some enjoyment in parts of it. I love succeeding in character quest lines and discovering where their stories go. Which is rough because we all know the game barely lets you see them
column17: and their quests are more difficult than the boss monsters of the game to follow. Mostly because you have to fight those boss monsters only to realize that your friend was in a different castle
column18: location
column19: an entirely different continent after MANY HOURS OF JUST LOOKING BECAUSE THE DIFFICULTY CURVE WAS NOT HARD ENOUGH. This game is frustrating. If you are ok with that
column20: and can learn to see a boss kill you on screen
column22: that boss has some cool moves. I respect that I died."" and move on
column23: this game is not for you. You will enjoy this game if you like bosses
column24: fighting and killing all my beloved friends. So if you enjoy killing characters for items this game is for you
column25: because killing is all you will do. I will hate you though and I will invade you and rip your organs out. If you played this game for reasons like me? Don't. It gets very lonely when you have no one to talk to. At least I can talk to my friends about this game. That's the only way it was bearable. Good game mechanically. Not for me. column1: Personally I find it one of the best gaming experiences I've had in quite some time (maybe since Dragon Age: Inquisition or Mass Effect 2)
column2: but for its own more unique reasons. Direct comparisons even to other ARPGs aren't quite 1:1.

column1: In terms of how it compares to previous FromSoftware games
column2: it's definitely way more ""open world"" than anything before
column3: and lots of people are upset about that aspect because ""er muh gahd
column4: I gotta ride my horse for a few minutes to get places!"" but in reality I spent just as much time in the overworld and wide open spaces as I did dungeon crawling in tight corridors and labyrinths. It's a great balance.

column1: The level of excellence with regards to the exploration on the overworld and the design of everything
column2: including the dungeons and labyrinths
column3: can't really be overstated. And the story... It doesn't overwhelm you with NPCs and side quests
column4: so every tidbit you get is immersive and leaves you wanting more
column5: with a level of mystery I've not experienced for a long time in an RPG... maybe ever? GRRM's involvement is not overtly obvious
column6: but knowing he was involved makes it clear that it was a very good decision overall to have him help craft the world of Elden Ring.

column1: Elden Ring surprised me. This game is brilliant.
I'll get the main complaint out of the way - the optimization. While it seems that they've fixed some stuttering
column2: the FPS still plummets in some areas/bossfights. Besides that
column3: there are other issues with the port
column4: but I myself don't have them so I won't mention them.

column1: I went into Elden Ring only hearing about it a month before its release
column2: and I didn't really have any hype for it
column3: and I had no expectations. I did buy it a day after it's release though
column4: because I wanted to experience what it's like to play a FromSoft game at it's peak. Particularly because of the messages :)

column1: What struck me first when I started playing ER was the jaw-dropping open world. The many beautiful landscapes in the world of ER blew me away. Witnessing the massive changes in some parts of the world was also incredible. There are many unique areas
column2: each with their own color schemes
column3: enemies
column4: storylines and interesting lore. You can see multiple of these other areas in the distance at any point when exploring the open world. The cutscenes are magical too
column5: and I've probably screenshotted something from all of them.

column2: but gets much better if you read through the lore. It's relatively straightforward otherwise. There are multiple endings
column3: of which some are copies of the main ending. Still
column4: I recommend checking them all out.

column1: There are many NPCs all across the world of ER
column2: all with their own goals
column3: morals
column4: and interesting questlines. You should definitely try to find as many of them as you can. One detriment to this is the fact that the questlines are usually very very vague
column5: and you will most probably need to use an online guide to complete them. It's insanely easy to loose track of where anyone is in the world.

column1: ER has an enormous amount of bosses
column2: many of which are smaller
column3: mini bosses. They can be pretty hit or miss. Some always get me excited
column4: but some of them are very annoying and not fun to fight against. The mini bosses do start to get copy-pasted later in the game - I didn't have a problem with that
column5: but I can see why someone would find that repetitive.

column1: Now about the thing I like the most: The story bosses. The main bossfights in Elden Ring are all . That's because of their cinematic presentation
column2: the various movesets of the bosses
column3: the multiple phases of the fight
column4: the interesting lore behind the fight
column5: or because of all of the above. Even the worst of ERs bossfights are miles better than bossfights from many other games. They all feel very grandiose and the fights are just incredibly satisfying. I would love to talk about each of them in particular
column6: but I don't want to spoil anything.

column1: Another great thing about ER is the build variety - there are tons of weapons
column2: shields
column3: weapon abilities
column4: effects
column5: sorceries
column6: incantations
column7: armor sets
column8: items
column9: summons... There's bound to be something for everyone.

column1: ER has some good quality-of-life improvements over the earlier FromSoftware games. Things like Summons
column2: Torrent
column3: Ashes of War
column4: Guard Counters
column5: the map
column6: savepoints visible from a distance
column7: etc are all a welcome addition in my book.";133.3;1.0;0.0;269.0;Posted: May 22

column1: Elden Ring is one of those games you really get involved in
column2: you are fully mmersed in the story and the amazing world has so much to offer. The game can be as hard as you want it to be
column3: but the difficulty scaling of this game is a side show compared to the lore that this game brings. This game has revitalised the open world formula that we are so used to and i am so glad to have played this game as it is AMAZING. 9.5/10
column4: some repeat bosses
column5: map could be clearer at some regions
column6: but overall Game of the year 2022. Highly recommended to anyone who likes adventure games.";138.1;1.0;0.0;39.0;Posted: May 22

column2: just put Dark Souls 3 in an open world with some extra stuff and call it a day.

column1: Elden Ring is a game where I am not exactly sure where I should put it when it comes to a rating of 1-10.
Regardless of what I think about it
column2: I still enjoyed it and had a great time playing through it for the first time
column3: but alas
column4: my desire to replay it is non-existent. Once I got my final achievement to 100% it
column5: I dropped it.

column2: and it's downsides
column3: just like any other game ever made
column4: and in this review
column5: I will attempt to share my views and thoughts on it.

column1: -There's a big world out there to explore
column2: and as it's open-world
column3: you have the freedom to explore on your own pace and go wherever you want. You can make it hard for yourself by rushing to the first boss you see and trying to fight it while likely under-leveled and under-geared
column4: or you can stop to explore the world and come back to the boss once you've gotten some gear upgrades and level ups.

column1: This allows each playthrough to be just a little big different depending on the paths you choose.
-Exploration is rewarded. There is a lot of different kinds of dungeons scattered around the world. They remind me a lot of dungeoneering from Runescape. You enter a dungeon
column2: fight some monsters
column3: solve some puzzles
column4: fight a boss at the end and get loot. It's always interesting to find one and wonder what kind of loot you'll find.

column1: There's also these smaller little dungeons that hold a chest inside but with no enemies
column2: but these require you to have a key item which you can find while you explore the world or purchase from merchants.
but it is a welcome addition regardless.
allowing for lots of build variety. There's your basic weaponry which are still powerful and can be infused with the ashes of war to provide different weapon arts
column3: and then there's your unique weaponry
column4: powerful and equipped with their own unique weapon art.

column2: other than for the ashes for war which I found to be a decent addition
column3: but it is a plus regardless.

column2: the spirit summons are a cool
column3: although somewhat controversial addition. Torrent
column4: your steed
column5: is there to make traversing the world less slow and painful
column6: and there's even a crafting system that allows you to put some resources you gather to use.

column1: You have new spells like the madness inflicting ones
column2: and new ailments like the blackflame which saps away your opponents health for a short period of time.

column1: The satisfaction of beating a boss is still there
column2: so if that's all you need from this game
column3: go ahead and buy it.

column1: -The world feels empty in some areas. For example
column2: the lake by the academy is so barren that it's just a W key simulator. There's a reason you get fast traveling right from the get-go
column3: otherwise it would be torturous.

column1: Not to mention that often you wont even be able to fast travel since some random enemy you didn't even know existed within a kilometer radius somehow is in combat with you.
-Mostly pointless crafting system. In my over 100 hours put in the game
column2: I never used the crafting system more than once
column3: and I was only testing it out. It feels like an after thought to me
column4: giving the player the ability to craft some basic consumable equipment out of scrap they'll find littering the game-world.

column1: I read somewhere that there's about 120 bosses in the game. Now ask yourself and don't lie: How many of those do you think are unique rather than repeated bosses
column2: different bosses mashed up together
column3: gank bosses
column4: or normal enemies made into bosses?

column1: Not to mention the fact that the unique bosses seem to be designed around you using spirit summons
column2: and purposefully delay their attacks so that learning their move-sets and timing is mandatory.

column1: -Armor is still useless. It's just like Dark Souls 3
column2: armor is there only for the looks
column3: and barely makes a difference at all. Poise is still a broken mess
column4: and the defenses and resistances just don't matter.

column1: Your better off going naked into battle so you wont be getting heavy load.
-The traditional Dark Souls quest-design does not work well for this game.

column2: you would likely come across the npc's naturally as you progressed since it was a more linear game
column3: but since Elden Ring is an open-world game
column4: the chances of you coming across that npc that you just talked to in the game world are very slim. Using Google is almost mandatory for this game if you want to do all the optional questlines.

column1: I never played PvP so that's why I didn't mention it in my review.
I'd still recommend the game if you're an old fan of From
column2: but if you're only just looking to get into the souls-franchise
column3: I wouldn't recommend starting with this.

column1: Dark Souls and Bloodborne are still my favorites in the From Software catalog.";109.3;1.0;0.0;107.0;Posted: May 22

column1: Okay....where to start! With 19 hours of game play. Firstly
column2: what a fantastic game visually. This is my first souls game and I have to say it's a love hate relationship. I am on PC and bought an Xbox controller because I was having trouble with the key bindings
column3: however the controller didn't do it for me so I went through and worked on the keyboard and mouse bindings until they felt good for me. Go with what works for you
column4: but persevere with it. I have been playing through the very early stages of the game over and over
column5: 1. because I keep dying
column6: 2. It helps to level up and if you are new to Souls games it helps to get your moves down and get that muscle memory working (also
column7: I'm old).

column1: Target lock - Learn to toggle your target lock on and off or adjust your settings to suit.
Take your time and check everything out
column2: it's pretty cool. Enjoy yourself
column3: this is the most important thing
column4: because honestly its a game.

column1: It would have been good to choose a first time player level for a beginner though
column2: I get what they are trying to do by coaching you along the way and you sure will get a lot of hours out of it. I'm not fantastic with reflexes and I have died A LOT. I probably wouldn't buy or try out another Souls game because of this. In hind sight I would/should have waited for the price to drop.";20.9;1.0;0.0;58.0;Posted: May 22

column1: This game is truely a Hard Core RPG masterpiece. The way i felt playing this game married how I felt playing Skyrim and Dark Souls 3 for the first time. Although it may be slightly easier than your previous From Soft games
column2: that doesn't mean it's necessarily a bad thing. If you are worried about value
column3: I have easily sunk 200 hours into each playthrough of this game with a different build each time
column4: and both runs (even though they featured the exact same enemies) offered two extremely different gameplay styles. With the vast options of weapons/incantations/sorceries
column5: I see an easy 3 play-throughs before you can even properly grasp a majority of the play-styles. And with a fairly forgiving re-spec system
column6: you can change your build more than 7 times in one play-through so you aren't locked into a build you don't absolutely love. If you've been hearing your friends talk about this game
column7: but haven't decided if you will pick it up
column8: please give this game a try.";231.2;1.0;0.0;185.0;Posted: May 22

DISCLAIMER FOR NEW PLAYERS: BE AWARE that this is a souls game. People I know IRL and some reviews I've seen have dismayed at the difficulty of these games. Research before you buy! This is such a fantastic game
column2: and while I've had difficulties with other games in this franchise
column3: I've personally found this game to be far more new player friendly in its format
column4: and its sad that people are trying to hack and slash through a game that will punish you for doing that.

column1: + fantastic graphics and thematics: its on the dull side
column2: but it suits the world and lore

column1: + Combat is pretty seamless: its slow
column2: but it keeps you on your toes
column3: think before u slash

column1: + Difficulty is just right: on the harder side
column2: but if you cant beat a boss or enemy
column3: level up or miss it until you're powerful enough

column1: - Not many cons for existing players who understand the game BUT:
-- Steep learning curve that leads to rewarding wins
-- No hand holding: this includes story (and side) quest lines having to be remembered
column2: etc
if you cant handle dying multiple times to the same miniboss and always end up rage quiting
column3: DON'T buy this game. Its not the hardest game in the world but its definitely not ""regular"" difficulty

column1: + Great souls game for new players and veterans alike

column2: story and thematics

column1: + Open world allowing a more personal adventure
- The difficulty and learning curve can be annoying
column2: but offset by the rewarding wins

column1: P.S. comment any concerns and I'll try to answer when I can! also be careful with the player messages
column2: I bought a dog and I've found out they can live for 60+ years 0_0";38.0;1.0;0.0;44.0;Posted: May 21

column1: The combat is fair but difficult if you're new to this. This is truly a great ARPG. Best thing about FromSoft games is the world-building and lore behind everything. You'll wander into a world without knowing anything

column3: watching youtube videos and scavenging wiki pages.

column1: It'll trully take you into its world and lore. The fact the builds

The game that keeps on giving. The amount of quality content stuffed into this game is unfathomable. When you think you've seen close to everything
column2: something new opens up. It's absolutely flabbergasting the amount of care and effort that went into building this world
column3: although many assets are clearly recycled from earlier games. (Not a bad thing per se.) This is one of those rare games in the genre that rekindles that awe and sense of discovery that I felt when playing pen&paper RPGs as a young child

column5: it's the true successor to Dungeons&Dragons as a concept.";75.6;1.0;0.0;1461.0;Posted: May 21

column1: The gameplay is polished with a bunch of quality of life improvements that haven't existed in previous games in the Souls series. These range from new options/abilities in combat
column2: a massive arsenal of weapons
column3: subweapons
column4: skills
column5: skill customization and magic
column6: to smaller stuff like checkpoints that reduce travel time between attempts at the same boss fight
column7: or no stamina consumption outside of combat.

column1: Huge world to explore that had a whole lot of areas that left me in awe.
Coop works great for random matchmaking if you want to help out bosses. HOWEVER if you plan on doing a whole cooperative playthrough with a friend
column2: you should inform yourself about the restrictions and how to avoid getting absolutely clapped by players that actively go out of their way to make a newcomer's experience miserable.

column1: Enemy design is a bit more diverse than in other Soulsborne games
column2: but sadly there's a lot of re-used bosses and minibosses
column3: which break the immersion (especially with named bosses showing up several times).

column1: There are numerous bugs that range from ""funnily awkward"" to bugs that have you reboot the game (or even an entire playthrough because a key event isn't set properly).";145.3;1.0;0.0;325.0;Posted: May 21

I would classify ELDEN RING as one of the best game experiences that i have ever had. It combines both open world and Dark souls into one game. And if you have ever played The legend of Zelda Breath of the Wild
column2: an open world game that shares similar game mechanics like: Parrying
column3: dodging and guard countering you will most likely enjoy this game too. If you have enjoyed playing other Dark Souls games you will very likelly enjoy this game too. ELDEN RING has a ton of secrets and even an area that you access via an hidden coffin. It is just crazy how much content this game offers with a ton of weapons and variety of different abilities that can give you an upper hand on your enemies. If you don't like a specific weapon type or want to change your build

Elden Rings is a deeply difficult experience. The flip side is that mastering the combat feels profoundly satisfying. the open world straddles the line between “secretive” and “aimless
column2: ” and winds up on the wrong side a little too often.
You Could Say. To Test Myself
column3: To Better Myself
column4: To Fell Ever Greater Foes”

column1: It's a hard but good game.
Elden Ring is a rewarding experience if you're willing to invest time into it
column2: and you have a high threshold for frustration. It's extremely challenging
column3: it's very user-unfriendly
column4: but patience and willingness to learn from mistakes will win out in the end.

column1: Elden Ring earns the high rating it's received by others. It's setting a benchmark for open world games to come
column2: and is a huge step forward in the natural evolution of the ""Soulsborne"" genre of games. It's more accessible and approachable than its predecessors
column3: so if you're put off by the reputation of punishing difficulty that the Dark Souls games have built up
column4: this may still appeal.

column1: Even though From Software's other ""Soulsborne"" games haven't been strictly linear even back as far as Demon's/Dark Souls
column2: Elden Ring gives you plenty of places to go if you find yourself somewhere you aren't ready for yet. If you feel underpowered in a new place
column3: you might just be! You can always turn back
column4: look elsewhere
column5: or spend some time getting comfortable with clearing out the areas that you've already been to before. The ""Guidance of Grace"" is more a suggestion than a rule - it tells you the shortest path to the next major step toward the end of the game
column6: so don't be afraid to get sidetracked.

column2: especially since inevitably whatever killed you is guarding your only way to get back whatever you lost on death
column3: but you can often just grab your runes and run. Rest at sites of grace regularly
column4: spend those runes when you have enough
column5: and also there's no shame in getting on Torrent and running like hell when you're overwhelmed (or just want to get to the next site of grace).

column2: this game can be a chore. It's essentially designed that way. The boss fights will feel unfair
column3: and losing over and over can start to feel boring. You will likely die to even the low-level bosses a lot while you're getting your feet under you. I beat my face against the brick wall of one optional boss for weeks
column4: trying
column5: dying
column6: going elsewhere
column7: then coming back later to try again. Use all the tools in your arsenal: Summon Spirit Ashes
column8: Customize and use the Ashes of War on your equipment
column9: and don't listen to anyone that tells you you're playing the game wrong.

column1: Your mileage may vary. I'm not a fan of the way From Software has designed their multiplayer
column2: as the PvE co-op mode opts you in to the PvP mode automatically
column3: and with high-level players preying on novices constantly
column4: this encourages trolling
column5: but it's calcified within the genre so it's unlikely to ever change.

column1: Like other From Software Soulsborne games
column2: co-op multiplayer requires you to summon other players from their respective worlds as ""phantoms"". They can then journey with you through a limited zone
column3: so long as that zone's ""area boss"" is alive. When you're playing together with friends
column4: exploring the world is great. Having a party member to watch your back and fight enemies side by side is amazing
column5: and I'd love to play the whole game with uninterrupted co-op.

column2: the interruptions are baked right in - exploring outside the limited zone requires all cooperators to leave the host's game
column3: independently travel to the other side of the ""fog wall""
column4: and be re-summoned in the new zone. Cooperators are also automatically dismissed on the defeat of an area boss
column5: and of course
column6: while in multiplayer
column7: you're under constant threat of PvP players invading your session with the intent to kill you. There's no opting out of PvP short of just disabling multiplayer altogether
column8: or finding another
column9: unofficial means of blocking connections from other players
column10: so it's difficult to just have a casual
column11: ""cozy"" co-op multiplayer session.

column1: But there are players who like that
column2: so I guess that's for them. More power to 'em. I've played 90 of my 93 hours of the game entirely in solo
column3: and enjoyed it (frustration notwithstanding).";95.0;1.0;0.0;1554.0;Posted: May 21

column1: I've played and beaten all the Dark Souls games and Bloodborne
column2: but I had a bad feeling about this game since I played the beta in November. It's a mediocre RPG
column3: if you want to call it that. The exploration is bland (it was fun at first but became increasingly more of a chore). Strange - most games simply cannot nail exploration
column4: yet it's a bit of surprise this one couldn't. The combat is pretty good - significantly better than DS3
column5: although not as good as DS2 or 1. The graphics are far too green
column6: and they do this trick wherein some places look extremely nice
column7: like Stormveil
column8: but other places look like trash. I've noticed that some games do this and it's a little confusing on the eyes. Like in some areas Fallout 4 looked excellent
column9: and in others it looked like mud. The quests are dull and mysterious to the point in which they become uninteresting. One problem that I really have with the game as well is that for a large number of the items you need to do research on how exactly to get them. In DS2 I randomly came upon Havel's armor and used it for the rest of the game
column10: along with the Mammoth sword. No research necessary. Elden Ring isn't trash
column11: although it is a disappointment. I'd say DS2 is best (lol unpopular view)
column12: then DS1
column13: Bloodborne
column14: Elden Ring
column15: and then DS3.";64.0;0.0;1.0;43.0;Posted: May 21

column1: Look if you like the Souls games from Fromsoft you will almost certainty like Elden Ring. It takes all the same complexity and combat and puts it into an open world that is spread far and wide. You're build may be great for one area and be more challenged in another
column2: but those varied experiences make this game feel even better. Knowing I'm doing something my way with my own path is something incredible. You may find exploring to reveal too many enemies or dungeons that feel the same. But since you can basically go wherever you want you can just press on ahead. A good rule of thumb because there is so much content is to just be done with an area when you no longer feeling it and maybe you come back later or you don't feel the need. Even when you find a dungeon you clear in a few minutes the experience you acquire means you are always progressing in some way. Just don't force yourself to keep doing some part or area you dislike to avoid burnout with a game this big and you'll probably enjoy your time playing.";118.7;1.0;0.0;203.0;Posted: May 21

column2: initially hearing how difficult/frustrating their games are I was a bit put off
column3: however after watching a few reviews and guides I thought I would give it a go.

column2: I can say this is a very immersive game
column3: extremely challenging
column13: at times however the reward for beating X boss fills you with a level of achievement.

column2: so many places to visit and secrets to discover. The weapons/magic are varied
column3: so you play how you want
column4: build your stats that suit your game play style. After several hours of progression you come to a point in the story that also allows you to switch up your style and reset your stats so you can try new a new weapons build. The variety of NPC's and side quests area also a great distraction from one of those bosses that may be causing you grief
column5: go explore for a while
column6: get some levels and head back with a new talisman/summon/spell that might help you.

column1: Overall the game has been built with time
column2: care and attention

column1: Let's make one thing clear: I have no problem recommending Elden Ring. It's a gorgeous
column2: beautifully-designed game
column3: with a world chock-full of secrets that begs to be explored in-depth. However
column4: I can't just recommend it flatly. I need to provide forewarning
column5: or at least an explanation as to why it might not be the game for you.

column1: In short: it's a matter of balancing and replayability.
Enemies in Elden Ring are tough - VERY tough. Even standard foes can potentially burn through your health bar fairly easily. Bosses will kill you outright in 2-3 hits
column2: and their combos start at 3 attacks minimum
column3: and the first hit will probably stun you so the second one is a near-guarantee hit. This is compounded by the fact that the AI is reading your inputs. You're not just getting randomly attacked while you're trying to heal
column4: the enemies are waiting for you to try to heal before smacking you down. Add in the fact that most bosses (and more than a few standard enemies) both are extremely quick and possess arena-wide area-of-effect attacks
column5: and you've got a recipe for a game that very much erodes the idea of FromSoftware's formula of ""tough but fair"" gameplay.

column1: The end result is a game that's at odds with itself. With dozens of weapons
column2: weapon skills
column3: spells
column4: armor sets
column5: talismans
column6: and spirit ashes
column7: Elden Ring should be a veritable wonderland of experimentation
column8: with no two characters sharing the exact same build. And yet
column9: because the bosses are so difficult
column10: and the weapons that are effective against them are so good
column11: everyone winds up getting pigeonholed into using roughly the same items and having the same stats. Yes
column12: the bleeding katana with the mimic tear and the kamehameha laser are all well and good
column13: but not if it means that there isn't any place for my bladed pizza wheel to feel useful
column14: let alone effective. Also
column15: remember that anything less than 60 Vigor will ensure that bosses can (and will) kill you outright in a single blow.

column1: Then there's the added issue of going back for another run. New Game + mode is nothing new
column2: but the game takes away a LOT of your resources in the process. Your vendor unlocks - the ones you tracked down in the wilderness and delved into dungeons to acquire - are lost when you start again. Moreover
column3: so much of the game's joy is derived from exploring/unlocking the map and taking the plunge into the unknown
column4: but the map stays unlocked
column5: along with all its landmarks. Sure
column6: it's fun to visit the spots that once gave you so much trouble as a higher level so you can steamroll that standard knight who killed you twenty times before you finally got him
column7: but that only stays fun for so long. Not to mention the part where the damage scaling on enemies and bosses feels off (see above).

column2: yes
column3: Elden Ring is a great game. It's in a league all its own and it absolutely earns its place as one of the greatest open-world games of all time (at least in my opinion). It just suffers from some balancing issues that I don't see being reconciled anytime soon - the problems are too interwoven with the game's core. I recommend checking it out
column4: but I definitely wouldn't blame anyone for choosing to put it down out of frustration.";195.0;1.0;0.0;135.0;Posted: May 21

TLDR: Search on youtube ""let me solo her Malena"". That's the game in a nut shell. If you like what you see then you will enjoy this game (controller is a must however).

Kind of a 3D Mortal Combat arcade fighting game (extensive twitch muscle memory when mashing buttons is a must) with very light RPG elements and lots of exploration (this is were the Asian culture of the developer comes out) though very much of it is repetitive. It's essentially a console game that works quite poorly on PC (don't even attempt using a keyboard and mouse - as a matter of fact the game's input tool-tips by default assume you are using a controller).

The combat has a bunch of contrived mechanics slapped together that are probably in place to account for the limitations of a console controller (can't control vision and also hit XYBA buttons at the same time - I am using a steam controller - etc.). As a side note
column2: I don't play console games because I find the controllers subpar compared to a keyboard and mouse.

column1: Veterans of PC FPS games are REALLY going to struggle with the camera movement
column2: the controls and the combat mechanics. Be prepared to forget everything you know and learn something you will only use in the ""FromSoft"" games. There's nothing else quite like it on the PC market and that's probably for a very good reason.

column1: You got stuff like rolling (dodging) into mob abilities and take no damage as long as you do it at the right time (they call this immunity frames)
column2: you can jump to avoid some ground aoe (even though the particle effects clearly engulf you visually) and so on. In addition there's some very sadistic input requirements some are just stupid some are likely driven by the use of the controller. For example to dodge in a specific direction you have to hold down the direction button for at least a second BEFORE pressing the dodge button
column3: and to run you have to press and hold the dodge button for at least a second - all this in a game were dodging/sprinting in the right direction at the right millisecond is vital. I thought maybe they are trying to simulate inertia and mass
column4: but that's not the case as you (and mobs) can do a 180 turn on a pin head when rolling or running when using the mouse.

column1: And then there is dodging. Lots of It as Boss combos can be very long (6-7 moves or more). This game should really be called Elden Dodge. Yes there's stuff like parry and blocking but their usage is extremely limited when fighting a boss (again mainly because of the length of the combos). A boss fight consists of 3-4
column2: up to 8 or even more consecutive very well timed dodges followed by one swing. Rinse and repeat until boss is dead.

there is essentially no character customization in terms of stats. As a matter of fact it really doesn't matter what class you start with as they will end up identical if/when you max all their stats. Spells
column3: weapons and armor cannot be customized in any way (you do have 5-6 types of arrow damage and more arrows that do same type of damage just more of it). Weapons can be upgraded (it's a straight forward damage buff) and can be tweaked with abilities (called ashes of war). There are lots of weapons but for the most part only a handful of classes (15 weapon classes or so?). The class gives the weapon it's move set (what it does when you swing it). Each weapon can have up to 1 ability. Most do come with one. An ash of war allows you to change that one ability and also change the damage type (and the stat with which the damage scales
column4: but it's not really important).

column1: Quests are limited (this is no way an Elder Scrolls Game). The story and characters are very Asian. The lore is definitely something to behold as GRR Martin (he got hired for this game) is a master lore builder
column2: but a complete failure when it comes to story telling (that's why he keeps killing all his characters in his books
column3: because he can't tell a story to save his life and he needs to make room for new characters and the lore surrounding them).

column1: There is a lot of fake hype surrounding this game. Going in I heard stuff like ""best mounted combat in any game ever"" etc. Don't be mistaken
column2: this game's combat mechanics cannot begin to compare with stuff you find in titles like ""For Honor"" or ""Mount & Blade"". And what it has is weird
column3: contrived
column4: awkward
column5: going into a direction all of its own. And just another example of how awful and contrived the controls of this game are (again probably driven by the fact that the input scheme is designed for a console controller): You cannot turn your mount around AND stand put in a given spot (say atop a cliff). Not with your normal controls. You CAN do it IF you use an item (looking glass) which provides zoom vision. In an exploration game... where cliffs and falling are an important mechanics.";45.6;0.0;1.0;99.0;Posted: May 21

column1: After more than 200 hours and 100% the game
column2: I feel confident enough to post my review about Elden Ring.
Elden Ring is the culmination of everything FromSoftware has learned from previous titles. Combat
column3: boss design
column4: level design
column5: lore
column6: etc while adding new elements to the mix. Although this is not my favorite game in the series
column7: I strongly suggest you play this game if you have the chance.

column1: If you have never played a FromSoftware title
column2: I think Elden Ring is a great way to start playing them. Elden Ring has many options available to the player to make the experience easier or harder when compared to other FromSoftware games. Not only that
column3: but I assure you this is like nothing else you have ever played.

column1: If you are a Souls Veteran
column2: this game feels very different from other Souls games. While a core aspect of previous entries was that dark fantasy element
column3: Elden Ring has more of a epic fantasy feeling (which is not a bad thing
column4: just different. Although I prefer a more dark atmosphere.) That combined with bosses that feel more artificially difficult or simply underwhelming and not challenging
column5: very few tracks from its OST that stand out
column6: repetitive optional bosses (quantity over quality)
column7: dungeons that feel more like a filler to artificially expand the time you will be playing if you choose to do so (not the main dungeons
column8: those are fine)
column9: the same quest system present in other titles that does not work as well here due to the open-world nature of the game
column10: and a much more watered-down coop and PvP system
column11: Elden Ring is a downgrade from what made games like Dark Souls and Sekiro memorable. That being said
column12: the game does a lot of things good: offers a variety of builds to the player to choose
column13: a huge open-world game that does not feel empty
column14: extensive and interesting lore
column15: sense of discovery and exploration superior to other games
column16: amazing world and level design
column17: etc. While not a bad game at all
column18: Elden Ring feels anticlimatic. There is much that could have been done better but considering the magnitude of the game
column19: it seems those elements were neglected. That being said
column20: Elden Ring is not a bad game and you should definitely play it if you have the chance. I am a huge FromSoftware fan and I am simply somewhat dissapointed with the game. After all
column21: this is just my opinion. Play the game and judge it by yourself.";227.2;1.0;0.0;63.0;Posted: May 21

Elden Ring is the absolute pinnacle of modern video gaming and shows just how masterful a triple-A title should be. Ubisoft
column2: Activision
column3: EA and all the other major studios have an awful lot to improve upon with their dreary repetitive ""live service"" microtransaction riddled games that have been plaguing the market for an unreasonably long time now.

column1: The Lands Between are an utterly beautiful and absolutely desolate and hostile environment that players will have to traverse in their quest to simply restore the titular Elden Ring by any method they see fit. You are briefly introduced to other well-known Tarnished characters through a cutscene
column2: pick a starting class all with their own starting equipment and stat distribution and are sent on your merry way into the open world (please don't attack the golden horse-rider straight away) after a brief tutorial zone.

how you play and what order you do things in is almost entirely up to yourself. You can scour every nook and cranny for lootables and things of interest or beeline straight for the demigods and their shards. The buildcrafting is excellent and you constantly find new equipment and upgrade materials to further build your character who you will grow quite attached to
column3: especially for a silent protagonist.

column2: the bosses are the true epitome of what this game has to offer. Learn attack patterns
column3: distinguish the perfect time to strike back and slowly come to find your perfect playstyle with combos of melee weapons
column4: ranged weapons
column5: magical spells
column6: armour and talismans
column7: along with dozens of consumables including buffs and status infliction items. Enemies are tough and some are blatantly unfair (looking at you Runebears) but with practice comes experience.

column1: There is far too much to cover in a short review but if you have been looking for an amazing singleplayer experience with a great story told in small sections through examining the world and items
column2: a brutally satisfying combat system and a simply vast amount of exploration then Elden Ring is the game for you!

column1: Easily Game of the Year for myself
column2: and one of the greatest video games ever produced.

Elden Ring is a fantastic game with stunning visuals and intriguing story. This is my 3rd From Soft game and the first one that I was able to get into properly. I did not beat this game but I did enjoy the vast majority of it. Because of the size of the game I got burnt out
column2: and for the time being I am done playing
column3: but the hours played for the money spent is worth it.

column1: I think many many games can take notes from Elden Ring and what they have done to create better open world experiences
column2: as they do it better than most. It's helped by the lack of markers on the map and quests. These keep the player immersed in the world rather than turning the game into a grocery list.

FromSoft does once again fail to deliver accessibility for other players that want to experience a fantastic game without massive time commitments to perfecting the skills necessary or burrowing through the massive volume of content. I recommend this game to anyone who likes being forced to think and figure things out
column3: and to players who like a challenge. If you want to finish a game without dedicating huge sums of time
column4: this is not the game for you however.";60.1;1.0;0.0;131.0;Posted: May 20

I love this game. It is the kind of game that I have been craving for years. I have played many of FromSoft's games in the past and I am very well aware of the performance issues that comes with their PC ports. Day one
column2: when I got it
column3: my frames were ass. One simple change of changing it from fullscreen to borderless windowed and I was set. I had very few issues after that (invisible enemies only happening when I had been playing for far too long) and the ride I had with this game was beautiful. This is the first Souls game that I have played on day one and going in with no idea where anything was or what to expect was magical. Even with my hundreds of hours into the game that I already have I am still discovering new things and interactions and that just tells me that there was a LOT of care put into the details of this game. Elden Ring is a truly beautiful and well-designed game. This is the first From Software game I have played since the original Dark Souls
column2: which at the time was one of my all-time favorite gaming experiences.

column1: The world is absolutely stunning: My first playthrough I was in awe of the landscapes you happen upon
column2: some of which you aren't even expecting. They were so great I ended up actually buying the looking glass just to be able to more fully experience the views (and take countless screenshots).

column1: The game really brings back some beautiful memories of some of my most beloved gaming experiences: Back when quests consisted of actually reading the items given to you and not just constantly following a quest marker. Having said that
column2: I must admit that if it wasn't for the online wiki
column3: there are a number of quests I would have never figured out how to continue. This is unfortunately in part to the open-world nature: Many quests are somewhat ""linear"" in that they continue from place to place along the path that the game may expect you to follow
column4: however since you can decide
column5: for the most part
column6: to skip around areas or follow towards main opponents without checking every curve and corner
column7: they are still very easy to overlook.

column2: voice acting
column3: and overall sound of the game are astounding. As someone who usually plays games for the gameplay and not the story
column4: I found myself actually listening to the characters. I suppose it helps that the ""dialogue"" was short during each encounter
column5: but it really added to the experience of the world
column6: and in some cases
column7: a true care for the characters.

column1: I don't remember much from Dark Souls and haven't been keeping track of the other games to compare crafting and upgrading functionalities (where present)
column2: but I generally liked the approach here. What I somewhat disliked was the inability to use ""sword grease"" on the special weapons. I guess it makes sense
column3: but I would have loved for it to still be possible
column4: even if then tremendously nerfed
column5: if nothing else then for the asthetic. :)

column1: Despite my love for the game (not including multiplayer
column2: which I am now starting on after getting all achievements)
column3: there are two very big annoyances:

column1: 1. Despite my fast computer and great graphics card
column2: the game still crashes on a regular basis. When it doesn't crash completely
column3: there are still significant stutters
column4: that just so happen want to occur in the middle of boss fights or during plattforming
column5: leaving me almost guaranteed to die.

column1: 2. Lack of ultrawide support: Part of the reason I didn't play multiplayer was because of the ultrawide fix requiring disabling anti-cheat and playing exclusively offline. This made the game absolutely beautiful and a treat to play
column2: but it blows my mind how little effort From Software seems to put in their PC ports: That was the reason I haven't played anything since Dark Souls after switching to PC gaming
column3: and it's depressing to see that it's still the case
column4: despite the fact that the ultrawide fix (even if offline only) was made available practically instantly after the games release.

column1: Aside from those major issues though
column2: the game is tremendous and a lot of fun to play. It is so much fun to try new play styles and explore the game in a whole new way by searching for different talismans or focusing on incantations or sorceries over weapons

column2: depending on the build you can have a drastically different experience and difficulty.

column1: To make fights easier you can also use ash summons which is an interesting system
column2: I think. You can find the summons spread out in the world and its fun finding new ones.

column1: The levels and Legacy dungeons are fun
column2: the open world looks gorgeous
column3: but feels a bit stretched out at times.

column1: Recycled enemies get kind of boring after some time. Unfortunately there are also a lot of identical looking dungeons (catacombs and caves). That kind of sucks
column2: it doest take long to get tired of those layouts. also in late game caves previous bosses are used as normal enemies
column3: which can get really annoying since they also have really big health pools and killing them isnt rewarding.

column2: especially later on
column3: have very large health pools and deal insane amounts of damage
column4: even with relatively high vigor (>50) you can only survive a hand full of hits from enemies. Especially annoying for the reskinned soldiers/knights. However with them you can at least guess they will be stronger if they have a new colour. There are several enemies
column5: like crucible knights
column6: that look identical
column7: but have vastly different health pools
column8: which can get frustrating if you can not properly anticipate their strength beforehand.

column2: I wish it was less of an open world and more focused levels
column3: since those tend to be the best and most interesting. Like Sormveil castle
column4: the Academy or nokron eternal city.

column1: Despite the problems you can have fun with the game and its easy to respec the character if you feel like your build doesnt work or you want to try something else. Also: Dont try to see everything in the first playthrough
column2: I did this and all the identical catacombs with annoying enemies almost killed the game for me
column3: just do what is fun to you. There is a NG system
column4: so no need to 100% first playthrough.";181.8;1.0;0.0;369.0;Posted: May 20

Just to clarify this review may come off as negative because I only want to complain about the things that annoyed me or that I disliked. However in spite of that this game is definitely worth playing and has around 150 hours of content or more. This game is one of the only games where I actually want to look in every corner of the world
column2: read every item description and discover the secrets behind the world. Discovery is one of the funnest parts about Elden Ring where every boss gives you a unique item and some of the areas you see are really interesting and beautiful.

column1: Some combat additions they added that I liked a lot were the new crouch and jump attack
column2: bringing back power stance weapons (although its automatic) and the ability to fight and travel on a horse.

column1: Firstly I'd like to address a hopefully non-issue in the future
column2: Computer Performance Issues.

column1: Currently in the game I am still getting the occasional lag spike and choppy frames
column2: this is not nearly as bad as how the game was first released however these issues still make boss fights incredibly annoying and frustrating at times since every second counts. I'm using an alienware m15 for reference so pretty decent specs.

column1: The swamps were really diverse with different colours
column2: styles and Caelid was really cool however they were all mostly empty and had little reason to explore. Swamp of Aeonia you can just cheat your way though on a horse. Lake of rot looks amazing
column3: however its completely devoid of content
column4: there's no reason to stay there other than beating a repeat boss.

column1: When killing a main boss instead of just fading away instead there should be a final critical hit. Almost every boss already has an inbuilt stagger/parry stun
column2: it would be much better and realistic if we finished the boss with a critical hit.

column1: There are few colossal sword options and they are just not really that viable.
You should be able to duplicate any remembrance at any walking mausoleum. There should also be another reason to knock down these walking castles.
There should be more caves and special areas
column2: these areas should also be more diverse. Limgrave perfectly encapsulates this but as you continue through the game its like they forgot to add more content and make it unique. Its like they went from Limgrave to Raya Lucaria then to Caelid and so on until areas like consecrated snowfield which are gigantic empty plains in a sense. The fire giant mountain top is probably the worst case of this in the entire game. However this is only in terms of special areas to explore with unique items
column3: pretty much every area is really well designed with beautiful sights and great use of elevation
column4: it just needs to be filled better with more diverse enemies
column5: etc.

column1: There are incomplete npc questlines and cut npc quest content which are crucial for lore world building and hinting important areas of the map.

column2: well designed and unique
column3: you want to interact with them however the game tries to make this as difficult as possible. It is basically impossible to finish npc questlines without a guide because npcs just randomly appear in different places without any hit or indication. Also npcs are still the same as other dark soul games they just stand in a specific spot and never move unless if they are hostile. Interacting with specific npcs will allow you to summon them to specific boss fights which is a really great feature however this should extend to them travelling the world with you.

column2: now lets address the ♥♥♥♥ show which is Fia the Deathbed Companion
column3: the Loathsome Dungeater and the Ever brilliant Goldmask. They are first introduced in the massive epic introduction at the start of the game and for each one you as the player interact with them and help them achieve their goals
column4: which is tied to the Elden Ring and consequently the end of the game. Fia
column5: Dungeater and Goldmask are great characters with great designs and dialogue however the only good/complete questline is Fias which feels fitting for the magnitude of her character. I will give a very high level summary just to show why her questline is fitting for her being an endgame npc. Essentially to complete her questline
column6: you search for clues of death
column7: go to the deepest part of the world
column8: fight and defeat an ancient dark dragon and mend the rune of the deathbed prince. Meanwhile Dungeater's quest is just release him
column9: to then kill him
column10: feed him and hear him howl which is incredibly disturbing however unfitting of such a defiled
column11: disgusting and infamous character. If Dungeaters quest is garbage I don't even know what to say about Goldmasks
column12: the only notable thing about Goldmasks quest other than running across the entire continent is discovering a mystery which you solve using another npc (turtle pope). It shouldn't be more enjoyable reading people on reddit discuss their character then actually experience their questlines. And when you think it couldn't get any worse just watch the endings for each of them
column13: complete disappointment
column14: I discuss this further below.

column1: You can go through a lot of trouble to save Melina by using the flame of frenzy and then Miquellas needle in the special area
column2: but you will still never see Melina again which is kinda lame considering how there's no other reason to get flame of frenzy early in the game.

column1: --| Elden Throne endings (Biggest letdown of the game)
At first the game had a lot of dialogue and npcs but slowly it just became another ds4. The endings for Elden Lord were especially disappointing
column2: very lackluster and similar
column3: like they could've at least had fia stand by your side as an apparition or melina after using miquellas needle. The only storytelling they did right was rannis questline where quest progression was clear and it unlocked new areas.

column1: When interacting with the world NPCs ask you to become their champion
column2: their elden lord and support their cause. You take allegiances with a side and progress their questline to get the ending they desire. However when you go through the trouble of completing their quest and reach their ending all you get is a lame cutscene which hardly shows the consequences of your actions or where the world is heading (and spoilers they all die
column3: just cause
column4: there's literally no one left who you supported). The endings could have been much better
column5: its really a shame that so much potential for great characters like fia and dung eater was wasted. The endings should have been more unique like Ranni's or Frenzy Flame
column6: seeing how the new ruling faction influences the world.

column1: In summary my main complaints are the npc questlines
column2: elden throne endings and lacking diversity as the game progresses. They botched some great characters big time in my opinion.";152.8;1.0;0.0;91.0;Posted: May 20

Elden Ring is a natural progression from the previous titles that FROM Software has made. The developers did a great job of taking the best parts from previous ""Souls"" titles
column2: adding a dash of Bloodborne to the mix and then marrying it to an open world that is truly fascinating. There are interesting things to see no matter where you go in the world and the game provides a sense of freedom that is a welcome change for the series. Although many people ran into technical issues with the game during the launch window
column3: the devs have done a good job of patching out most of the bugs. The bottom line is that if you like the ""Souls"" series
column4: then you will find a lot to like here . It's an extremely well-designed game and the developers were clearly very passionate about making their vision a reality.";94.9;1.0;0.0;979.0;Posted: May 20

column1: Before moving forward with this review
column2: it's important to know that like many
column3: this was my first FromSoftware game. I wasn't gonna play it
column4: but it had pulled so many of my friends in and hearing that it had co-operative multiplayer pushed me to give it a try. I'm glad I did because this has certainly been one of my favorite games I have ever played.

column1: Usually this is where I would put the story part of the review
column2: but..erm...have you ever played a FromSoftware game? The story isn't given to you straight lol. For a bare bones explanation from what I gathered
column3: the world is kinda effed and the only way to bring some sort of balance back is for someone to become the new Elden Lord. Unfortunately
column4: you're gonna have to fight through a whole bunch of powerful people to get there. You think you have what it takes
column5: Tarnished?

column2: where to begin? For starters
column3: ER is a beautiful game. I found myself really enjoying how different areas of the game looked. The very beginning of the game is in this strange
column4: stormy
column5: crumbling area
column6: and then you're in a cave
column7: and then you in some very nice green pastures. Each area of the world is very distinct and moderately sized. I love how if you describe what area you're at just by the description
column8: players can instantly tell where you are. Rotted looked area with big birds
column9: dogs
column10: and rot? You're in Caelid. Watery area with lots of crystals
column11: crabs
column12: and shrimp? You're at the Lakes of Lurnia. Between underground city with stars and ancestral spirits? You're in the Sofia Well. Kudos for the developers making every area memorable and beautiful to traverse.

column1: There is a fair amount of customization as well. While the character creation can feel bare compared to other games
column2: the sheer amount of weapons
column3: spells
column4: and items you can wield and use are enormous. Depending on how you build your stats
column5: you can make some unique and powerful builds. Some of my favorite things to see is how my friends and other players would build their characters. You wanna dual wield large weapons? Go for it. Wanna have dual claws like Wolverine? Done. Wanna carry two whips? No problem. You will have to find the gear of course
column6: but just the amount of creativity that players can have in this game is amazing.

column1: The online aspect of the game is what drew me into playing it. You can summon people to help you explore the area and dungeons
column2: but many randoms will gather around boss doors to help you fight. While there are helpers
column3: there's also PVP. Players can invade your world and make things quite miserable for you. While I don't mind the PVP since I grew up playing MMOs
column4: the only thing I found annoying by it is that invaders are unaffected by monsters. This usually ends up with them trying to pull a monster to fight you so they can get easy hits/kills on you without a fair shake. Other than that
column5: I didn't really mind it. Yeah it sucked sometimes when they would invade at inopportune moments
column6: but that's the price you may have to pay.

column1: Bosses have been so memorable! FromSoftware is known for their crazy bosses and they didn't pull their punches here. Most bosses get recycled and reused in the many MANY dungeons you find out there in the world. The big story bosses however
column2: they are a sight to behold. Each fight is unique and learning your timing
column3: when to dodge
column4: and when to strike is crucial. Most times if you die
column5: you'll spawn right outside the room so you can immediately try again. The bosses all have this ""just one more try"" energy to them when you're trying to learn their patterns. One interesting thing I loved is how different bosses are difficult to different players. Since my friends and I were playing we would often say: ""I beat boss X on my first try last night?"" And they'd say. ""Seriously
column6: took me at least 10 to beat them
column7: geesh!"" Same thing with weapons and equipment. The weapons I'd use
column8: my friends didn't like and vice versa. It really speaks to the diversity and uniqueness of how you can tailor the game to your liking.

column1: Before I get to the gripes I just want to point out that almost every weapon or enemy you see can be yours to wield if you can find it. You can farm certain enemies for their armor sets. Complete many dungeons to get summons of the various enemies you face including some mini-bosses (not the big ones
column2: breathe easy there
column3: friend). You can even find powerful spells that some of them use as well. The sky...err...Urdtree is the limit!

column1: Now for gripes which aren't too many. For starters
column2: this game will NOT hold your hand. If you find yourself lost
column3: explore around first
column4: then consult a guide. The world is enormous and there are many story lines and quests you can do
column5: but the game will not tell you how to do them. What was fun for me was I figured most of the quests with my friends and we just shared information and locations with each other. My second gripe is the summons. You can only use them in specified locations where you see the icon on your screen and this was quite annoying to me. I know purists will say that you should just ""git gud"" and not have to rely on them
column6: but I still think this is gripe worthy to add to the mix. Summoning friends for co-op was iffy at times. You can set passwords so you can find them faster
column7: but there were days where we'd wait for awhile and the golden mark would not show. And lastly
column8: the difficulty. This is not a gripe
column9: but more like a warning. Yes
column10: this game is very popular and fun...but for a new player it's gonna be hard. Your skills will be tested
column11: you might open a trapped treasure chest and find yourself stuck in a dungeon unable to find your way out. You may be stuck on a boss for a few days *grumbles*. However
column12: I recommend you keep pushing and keep trying. Summon random players
column13: go grind runes and level yourself up
column14: keep on failing and learning the patterns. The victory is worth it!

column2: I'm just repeating what you probably already know but this is a fantastic game. I have poured in over 100 hours
column3: was stuck on a boss for a week
column4: and only rage quit maybe once. And I'd do it all over again. The gameplay was so statisfying
column5: the world was beautiful and immersive to explore
column6: and beating tough bosses with friends or by myself pushed me to make it to the end. This is a great FromSoftware game to start you off with their franchise because it has a lot of features to help ease you into their world. I'm eager to try their other titles now that I have played this
column7: and I'm sure many new players agree. Get ready to die a lot
column8: the road will not be easy. But you are different from the other Tarnished. If I became Elden Lord
column9: then I know you
column10: yes you reading this
column11: can do it too! Thanks for reading!

column4: a lot. This game does not hold your hand. If you are struggling with a boss
column5: try exploring out in the overworld. Get stronger and try again later. This game might just be the best game released in the last five years (since Breath of the Wild) in my opinion. It will be hard to go back to any older souls type games
column6: this game set a very high standard. I patiently await the release of DLC for this game. This game is well worth the money.

So I've never played a Dark souls game or rather anything from FromSoftware's developers before
column2: but these are the things that I like and don't like--
like everything visual about this game is awesome

column1: -The combat can be fun imo depending on the enemy that you are fighting and build you are
-Open world is fantastic with places to discover or look at and hidden items are all over the place
-I personally like games that you can sink a lot of hours into and this is definitely one of them
-I like all of the boss designs and the story although a little confusing at some points
column2: was very interesting and I liked the fact you can become Elden Lord that's a pretty sick ending.

column1: -So many ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ choices when it comes to customizing your character from looks to abilities and sorceries or weapons. Which I enjoyed very much to see which weapon or spell may work better for an opponent or maybe using a shield could help
column2: or just the fact you can make your character look like a dofus.

column1: -I like the risk and reward that comes from defeating bosses
column2: the rush you feel after losing 3 or 5 hours of you life is amazing
column3: or the pain you suffer after risking the beans and losing 200
column4: 000 runes then you want to kys. But thats just like every other fromsoftware game so thats a +

column1: -AOE attacks imo are very annoying in this game
column2: some bosses like to spam their AOE attacks a couple times which can be frustrating

column1: -INPUT I really don't know the specific term but in the game when you attempt to heal or cast a spell/sorcery the enemy is programmed to read that input of you healing/spell/sorcery and immediately attack you
column2: while you are in the animation of healing/ casting a spell/sorcery. Which is very annoying.

column1: -You get one-shotted a lot for basically anything under what is it 40 vigor i think.

column2: you will not get a break or if you do you better capitalize on it
column3: for the godskin duo they would both execute various moves and combos at me at the same time but I mean that was with pretty much every other team of 2 as well.

column1: -Some things just seem unnecessary will fighting bosses for ex: imo when fighting commander Naill
column2: when he summons the two knights to fight for him that ♥♥♥♥ is just annoying not even interesting or fun to fight consider the knight with the 2 swords is a mega chad. Melania's heal just seems stupid to me when they also add an undodgeable combo(Waterfowl Dance) that she can use anytime while fighting you. Okay so some people can dodge it but I bet the majority can't which is fine I guess when you can just cheese her with Rivers of blood katana :D.

column1: -Balancing as a whole in terms of weapons and bosses seems weird sometimes ( some bosses are insanely easy for a mage build but then for a samurai could be insanely hard vice versa.) For example
column2: the tree sentinel can block magic such as glinestone pebble and fire it back at you
column3: but then for lets say Godrick I got him on my second try using mage but took me like I would say 45+ tries on my first playthough using a samurai build.

column1: I did really enjoy this game and was probably one of the better games I've played in 10+ years

Well I cannot add much her that has not already been said; except this is a very well polished game indeed.

I am over 500hours in and am still finding new things to do. I love the new game plus modes that make the enemies harder each go around. I love all the different styles of character. For me this is my favourite open world rpg ever.
I have Aspergers and am very fussy about details and the effort put into this by From Software is simply stunning.
This is also the first pc game that I have managed to play with an xbox controller as I get cramps and twitches in my right hand. Worth all the extra effort for me.
I have struggled a lot this year with my multiple disabilities; and can honestly say that this game has been a saving grace (lol).
