column2: the PC stuttering issue isn't completely fixed
column3: but I've only noticed it a few times
column4: and it's never hurt my game play. As far as I can tell it usually only happens when I first start playing
column5: or when I load in to a new area.

column1: With that out of the way
column2: I love this game. It's not without it's flaws
column3: but it's a blast to play.

column1: The bad: It's easier than older From Software games (especially Sekiro)
column2: which for most games you might not take as a demerit
column3: or it might sound like it's a game for kids. It's not *that* easy. It's still got a stiff difficulty curve
column4: but it really depends on how you play. If you want to play organically and just follow the world while challenging what you find
column5: it's gonna be a rough ride. If you find a grinding spot
column6: look up item locations to find the best gear
column7: plan out a build you'd like to fight with
column8: and spend time farming items and runes
column9: then eventually it will go from challenging to an easy ride until you hit the next area you might want to be in. Next is the grind. If you're the latter type of player and prefer to grind and level
column10: well... The next problem is how grindy it can be. Levels can provide only a tiny fraction of what you need to progress
column11: and early game enemies only give you a sliver of runes each while still being difficult to take down (I'm looking at you Stormveil Castle)
column12: so getting somewhere comfortable for less skilled players will be a slog without looking up guides. I seem to find enemies that are harder to kill in the early areas than in areas later in the game
column13: but they only give you a tiny amount of runes in comparison (50 vs 1000). Because of this enemies end up feeling like damage sponges. Even the mobs tend to suffer from this in higher level areas. They're not difficult to kill
column14: they just take a looooot of time even with a developed build.

column1: The good: When you get bored of grinding
column2: breaking away and exploring the massive open world is an amazing experience. There's lots to discover
column3: beautiful views (even if the graphics aren't top tier
column4: the design and implementation is amazing and should put other
column5: more expensive
column6: games to shame)
column7: and plenty of events and characters to meet. And all of this is done in a dynamic way
column8: providing the player with a natural encounter with NPC
column9: world event
column10: or even a unique item. Each encounter feels like it has character and purpose. All open world games could learn from this
column11: and hopefully they do. Sometimes scripted events that are well written work way better than a copy/paste event algorithm. The map is basic
column12: but that means it encourages the player to find routes around
column13: and discover new areas and NPCs. While pieces of the map are missing
column14: it's done in a way that makes sense
column15: leading the player to find them on their own and making the map look like it's patched together. There's no radio towers to climb
column16: no copy/paste quest to unveil the map
column17: no section blocked behind a story event (well... maybe
column18: I'm not exactly finished with the game). And there's alternate paths and secret areas all over the place. Each one carefully planned and laid out. In both the open world
column19: and inside boss and mini-boss castles/dungeons as well. If there's one complaint I have it's that a lot of caves and dungeons feel a bit copy pasted sometimes. But this is From Software's first foray in to an open world
column20: and those dungeons and caves aren't the main focus anyway. Despite that flaw
column21: it's still done better than most (if not all) other open world games. Combat feels fluid and responsive
column22: and play styles can be adapted to any weapon or skill
column23: leading to a pretty big variety of combat options. Most armor options within a given category (light
column25: heavy) seem to be more about style over different functions
column26: leading the player to not have to worry too much about finding the perfect piece of armor to protect them from a specific enemy and giving skills
column28: and spells more weight when it comes to combat. I'm fairly certain this is the norm for From Software's games
column29: but with all the options in this game it just feels more evident.

column1: If you enjoy From Software's games
column2: this might be for you. Even if you're a veteran looking for a challenge
column3: there's still ways to do that
column4: even with some parts that seem designed to make the game easier. If you're new to From Software's games
column5: this might be for you too. There's ways to explore
column6: learn
column7: and make things easier for yourself as you adapt to the difficulty. It's a rewarding game
column8: in many aspects
column9: from the combat to the exploration. There are still moments of what I like to call ""artificial difficulty""
column10: where an enemy is placed in a blind spot
column11: or somewhere that they have a clear combat advantage. Moments of ""If I knew about that
column12: I wouldn't have died there"". It's one of my repeated complaints of these games
column13: and I wish they'd back off on doing it. The enemies present enough of a challenge in most games
column14: so implementing this just seems like they heard ""FS's games are hard!"" and decided they had to find a way to make it feel more unfair. With the message system
column15: a lot of these events aren't so bad
column16: and most events are avoidable once you know how the level designers think.... Which makes it even more glaringly obvious. But that's always been a minor complaint.

column1: One final complaint: The messages are immature a lot of the time. Players of older games still think they're relevant by posting a ""try jumping"" or ""rolling required""
column2: and some messages are just Im14andthisisedgy body humor. Though you should always heed the messages about dogs. They're important.
and grow to greatness.";119.9;1.0;0.0;252.0;Posted: May 19

column1: Elden Ring is a poorly optimized console port that is ruined by the forced install of Easy Anti-Cheat. If you prefer not to play games that are excessively difficult and that have the Dark Souls formula of saving only at bonfires with respawning enemies and way too many difficult boss battles then this game is NOT for you. Easy Anti-Cheat causes the game not to work with ANY trainer and it can also cause the game to even stop loading. There is also no campaign or true levels. You just wonder around from boss fight to boss fight with no idea if you are making any progress or not. I also could not play this game in 4k resolution because of constant frame rate drops. 1080p looks grainy and I was still getting frame rate drops using an RTX2080 and i9 processor. There is also no resolution slider and all of the game commands and instructions are for a controller and not a keyboard. I seriously regretted this purchase and promptly refunded.";0.7;0.0;0.0;118.0;Posted: May 19

column1: It is my opinion that Elden Ring
column2: as of now
column3: is Fromsoft's Magnum Opus. Think of Elden Ring as a conglomerate of all their games combined into one
column4: with twists and changes here and there.

column2: with huge varieties of enemies we've never seen before
column3: as well as some old classics.

column1: - The dungeons all felt different for the most part.
- There's a TON of weapon and spell options. There's a playstyle for everyone.
- The bosses were challenging and well designed.

column2: and the characters are all extremely memorable.

column1: - The soundtrack is one of the best
column2: only outdone by DS1.

column1: - PvP is fun and the community is pretty hilarious and friendly for the most part. Be aware that I have had some very bad sports
column2: META build users
column3: duel rule breakers
column4: etc
column5: but that's to be expected as the internet brings the worst out in people. Don't let the griefers ruin your fun. There's more positive people than there are negative out there.

column1: - I've just about 100%ed the game at 170hrs
column2: only missing one or two of each legendary items for the achievements. I didn't realize that until I already started NG+
column3: so I'm going to have to really work for that sh*t again which is painful. Don't be like me -- hunt for everything BEFORE starting NG+. It will literally save you dozens of hours. It was one thing to miss something in other Souls games
column4: but Elden Ring is longer than Ron Jeremy.

column1: - There are (6?) endings to the game
column2: a few are just variations of the same base ending
column3: and then there are two others that are completely different. I have one of the three ending achievements. Follow your gut and do what you'd like -- don't let tutorials dictate what ending you get. Be spontaneous
column4: you won't (maybe) regret it ;)

column1: - I have spent seven real life days in Elden Ring
column2: and I still want to play more. Most games I average around maybe 50hrs of playtime
column3: and that's over a span of years. This game is like heroin. The only game more addictive than this is Factorio
column4: If you don't know what I'm talking about
column5: then good. If you do know what I'm talking about
column6: I'm sorry for you.

column1: My only real gripe with this game is the invasion system. Unlike previous games
column2: you can only be invaded while playing co-op
column3: so for someone like me who primarily plays solo
column4: invasions have become a huge rarity. I miss being invaded and destroyed by some META duel-katana bleed build sweat that wears an obnoxiously huge hat
column5: as odd as that sounds. I don't know
column6: maybe I'm in the minority here.

column1: TLDR: My favorite game by FromSoft to date
column2: and I've played all of them extensively.

Few things you should know before getting this. It punishes you mercilessly for mistakes. It rewards you just enough to keep you wanting to beat the crap out of that one thing you can't seem to beat... yet. The PVP that comes as part of asking a friend for help is so far beyond frustrating to those that don't want it that I have thought long and hard about how many times I want to punch the developers in the face. Those that are 'loyal' to the dark souls games appear to defend this. Personally
column2: I @#&^ing hate it beyond all. So
column3: be warned.

column1: There's not a whole lot about this game I can talk about that hasn't been talked about to death by this point
column2: especially as this game has somehow drawn in a sizeable amount of newcomers to the franchise but just in case for the other Dark Souls/Bloodborne veterans out there it's like this; take any of the other games you knew before and think bigger. You now have an open world vs the more strict dungeon crawler nature of the other games with the addition of a dedicated jump button (no more run jumps only)...and of course the welcome return of power stancing from Dark Souls 2 making dual wielding weapons viable again. Beyond that it's your usual Miyazaki game with Berserk references galore and lore details largely told through item descriptions love it or leave it. If you haven't gotten this game yet...do it...you won't be sorry.";300.4;1.0;0.0;184.0;Posted: May 19

column1: Its absolutely gorgeous in its scale and world building and I'm actually speechless.

However there are some issues with a fact that there's no such system that would somehow make the player level kinda... ""scale""? so that more bosses would be relevant later on. Progressing as a character is good but coming later on to some lower level locations and doing some encounters makes them less valuable in terms of the experience. Not sure what kind of system could fix that (definitely not the default world scaling) but its an issue that should be considered in the upcoming titles.

Also didn't really like the great runes feature as I thought about it as it was something big but quickly realised that this is just worse version of an ember from ds3 (worse because ember actually made a difference as an additional heal during the boss encounters while this could make our character stronger making me feel like I'm not playing at my 100% whenever I die and don't want to waste another one.

To sum up - the Elden Ring is an insane game and an awesome experience but I wouldn't agree that its totally better than DS3. Even with similar formula it differs a lot in the experience that it provides and I totally love both of these equally.

column1: Elden Ring is an incredible experience. The world is huge and begs to be explored to the fullest. I spent hour after hour walking
column2: riding
column3: sneaking and prowling around the different regions in the lands between. The combat is challenging - it requires practice
column4: patience and perseverance and sometimes even leaving the fight for later once you are stronger and wiser. The game really draws you in and if you are someone who loves open world exploration then this is the best of the best.

column1: My only real gripe with Elden Ring is a personal preference for the way the story and quests are done as I prefer at least some form of direction and Elden Ring often lacks even the most minimal hints at where or when a questline will continue. The open world nature also makes it extremely easy to go beyond points of no return for quests or to completely miss an NPC who moves location to somewhere you've fully explored previously. There are also a huge number of weapons and spells which aren't that good or viable but that is off-set by the fact that there are so many options you can effectively use.

I finished my first playthrough at just under 170 hours and it was one of the most immersive gaming experiences I've had. I would highly recommend Elden Ring to anyone who enjoys open world games and would rate it 8/10.";194.0;1.0;0.0;116.0;Posted: May 19

column1: If you are worried about the difficulty based off its predecessors
column2: know that this is the most accessible Souls style game fromsoft has ever created. The open world design gives the opportunity when faced with a hard boss to take a step back and find ways to improve yourself without being forced to mindlessly grind away levels to overcome the hurdle.

column1: While the game is easier than previous souls games it still has enough difficulty to present an entertaining challenge. Beating a difficult boss is extremely satisfying and feels like overcoming a true challenge.
TL;DR This is one of my favorite games ever made and you should play it!";360.3;1.0;0.0;124.0;Posted: May 19

column1: I'm pleasantly surprised by the game. It has some new features not seen before in Souls games. Crafting

column1: The graphics on HDR are beautiful
column2: with colors coming to life and any cave sections very atmospheric with pitch black passages to go through. The world
column3: of which I've seen only a little yet
column4: seems to have lots to explore. There are a lot of optional bosses also
column5: and lots of crafting items to collect.

column1: The combat seems a little more fast paced than in older Souls games
column2: which is a good thing. Normal mobs can ruin your day if you aren't careful. The bosses are definitely more of a challenge than in DS 2
column3: which I completed previous to ER.

column2: on AMD 5800x
column3: 3090 and an M.2 SSD I have little complaints. An occasional short stutter maybe once a half hour which does nothing to ruin the experience. Your mileage may vary
column4: though. Possibly wouldn't play well on a barely minimum spec PC.

column1: At first I wasn't planning on buying this
column2: but now I'm glad I did. If you feel you're getting wrecked time and time again
column3: slow down your playing and think more what you're doing. Learn from your mistakes and use the tools available to you!

column1: You have to finish watching the cut scene. You’ll go through a character selection screen
column2: then your character will be about to be executed
column3: when a dragon shows up and saves you.

column1: Pick whether you want to join the imperial legion or the rebels and go with one of the two guys who saves you. What follows is a pretty quick and easy dungeon crawl that serves as a tutorial.
Then you’ll want to go to the first town
column2: but on your way
column3: you might want to stop by a small mine with a few enemies on the side of the road for some gear and some easy ore to mine.

column1: Eventually you’ll talk to the Jarl of the regional big city (Whiterun) and he’ll have you basically go on a quest to retrieve a golden claw or something like that from another dungeon. In that dungeon
column2: there’s a some zombies and then a big spider but it’s not too hard overall.

column1: When you’re done with that and get your rewards
column2: you’ll kill a dragon
column3: learn your first shout
column4: and the game will open up a bit. Make your way toward Riften
column5: a city across the map. (You’ll probably want to hire the carriage outside Whiterun as otherwise it’s a long trek by foot and you probably won’t be able to afford a horse yet.)

column1: Ask around Riften about the thieves guild
column2: you’ll eventually find them in the sewers. Do the opening quests and get your thieves guild armor.
head back to Whiterun and start grinding your pickpocketing skill. You can savescum if you need to in order to pickpocket hard to get jewels
column3: etc
column4: but get your pickpocket level as high as possible. Do the same for your lock pick skill.

column2: go to Belethor‘s shop but don’t buy anything. Just wait
column3: then follow Belethor home after he closes shop.

column1: Pick the lock and sneak into his house after he goes in but don’t let him see you. Eventually
column2: you’ll hear him start cursing under his breath a lot in the other room.

column1: Sneak behind him into the room and you’ll see that he just bought Elden Ring for PS5 but doesn’t know what the ♥♥♥♥ he’s doing so he’s just fighting with the first boss on a horse in limgrave and dying over and over again.

column2: pickpocket the game from him (it’s weird
column3: he has the game equipped on his way to bed). Then once you have it
column4: you should be able to stick it into his PS5 after he goes to sleep and boot back into the game. You might need to create a new character and go through the tutorial again to get to Limgrave though.""";165.5;1.0;0.0;404.0;Posted: May 18

This game is exceptional. I don't play a ton of singleplayer games and I've never touched a soulslike game before this so I wasn't sure if I'd really enjoy Elden Ring; I was so wrong. The open world
column2: the characters
column3: the combat
column4: all of it was amazing. I spent 133 hours (I like to take my time
column5: don't judge me) on my first playthrough and enjoyed every minute of it.

column1: If you're hesitating to buy this game because you're worried it might be too hard I'd say worry not. It's not like the game isn't difficult
column2: enemies hit hard and can be unforgiving at times
column3: but rarely did encounters feel genuinely unfair. For every challenge that Elden Ring throws at you it offers a solution
column4: be that a weapon
column5: a spell
column6: an ash of war
column7: a spirit summon or even a craftable item. I wholeheartedly recommend embracing as many of these tools as possible and finding out what makes the game fun for you. This game definitely asks a lot of you
column8: there are rules about the pace and feel of combat you'll only understand after some time playing
column9: but I promise that if you're willing to learn a bit
column10: meet the game halfway and play by its rules
column11: you'll have a great time.";158.9;1.0;0.0;23.0;Posted: May 18

column1: This game is good. I've also played Sekiro
column2: Bloodborne
column3: and every Dark Souls except for 3. In comparison
column4: Elden Ring is considerably more polished than most of these games in many ways.

column1: I do have a few gripes. The difficulty is not so finely tuned. The beginning of the game was very easy except for a few encounters
column2: but the last few bosses might as well be a different game in terms of difficulty. I don't think that making these easier would have improved my experience
column3: but maybe making the difficulty more uniform might have. Also I found the side dungeons (catacombs and caves) to be frankly unimaginative. By the end I was skipping most of these. Lastly
column4: the quest experience is just not good. I want to interact with the NPC's in the world
column5: but then they disappear and often to a place that you wouldn't guess. The Dark Souls quest formula made sense when the world was more or less linear and you'd stumble across someone. But Elden Ring is huge. It doesn't make sense to have a quest system like this without any quest journal or map markers of any kind in a game this large.";232.6;1.0;0.0;39.0;Posted: May 18

column1: ♥♥♥♥♥♥ Amazing game every complained about how hard it was and how some bosses are unfair or to aggressive or to passive. I like to look at it like this its a hard fair and fun game with allot to do. have many many ways to play and enjoy from being a high dps dagger build to an uber tank with duel giant shields boarder line immune to damage. this game isnt hard every boss can be dealt with and every problem has an actual solution that the devs didnt just pull out of nowhere. yes there can be some issues with story being to fast or short depending on what your doing but then again there is an actual new game plus. personally. i feel like a souls game only starts once you his new game plus. thats when things get hard but still in a fun way. you have no real excuse to not want to play this game other than you dont like the story rich yet mostly earned type or story telling if you treat this like dark souls your will struggle if you treat it like bloodborne or sekiro its gonna feel to slow at times. just play this and learn. i promise you wont really regret it unless this type of game just inst your cup of tea or coffee.";25.5;1.0;0.0;475.0;Posted: May 18

column1: Firstly there NO MICRO-TRANSACTIONS! NONE AT ALL. Once you pay up
column2: that's it
column3: play and wait for DLC Campaign. This is a trial and error type of game. Do your research on from Software Games before you buy.

column2: this is the easiest of the Souls Series Games ( it felt a tad bit gentler than the other 12 previous years with from software
column3: I didn't even need the vaseline this time....LOL) It is also the largest game they have made to date. 1st play through took me roughly 85 hours till credits ( If you work
column4: have family and a life; that's about 1 to two months to reach credits) and I am yet to explore all the secrets. It's open world with heavy emphasis on Exploration. If you don't explore then it will become a challenge. The only issue as of now is still the balancing ( Stuttering has been fixed) . As I said
column5: Explore and things become easy as you tend to level up fairly quickly (assuming you are holding on to/recovering those runes). Sometimes too easy because you might end up being too overpowered when it's time to tackle main story bosses. This only lasts up until late game phase.

column1: In late game and endgame phase
column2: everything ( Especially Bosses) becomes more overpowered than you and it will become a challenge if you don't utilize every arsenal From Soft gives you( that means if you don't co-op
column3: you will typically become a master after facing a thousand deaths) . Bosses will two tap you sometimes and enemies take and DEAL a lot of damage in these stages. Broken builds and exploits have been slowly getting patched out
column4: but they still exist. So far that has been the easy way to tackle things in the late game phase. Apart from co-op and broken builds
column5: you have to rely on buffs and need to know how the buff system in Elden ring works if you want to reach the credits. There is no shame in looking up a guide ( I only recommend after you have been completely stumped so as to enjoy the Elden ring experience).

column1: Pvp balancing is still broken. You will run into broken builds that demolish you in seconds. There isn't much I can say about it. You can choose to play the entire game offline
column2: though it makes it harder to some extent as you will miss out on secret items that others have found.

column1: In terms of how much content you get
column2: it's a lot. The map is ridiculously huge
column3: with multiple Biomes. The story is not as vague as previous From software titles if you read through the descriptions ( It's still vague though )but since this game is so large you will end up looking at lore videos online to connect everything together. I actually understood more after I finished the game. The trailers started make sense after i had experienced the game
column4: this includes the intro Cinematic. There is too much to say about this game so I will end it here.

column1: No micro transactions. Still a From Software title ( Trial and Error) but easier(Do your research on soul series if this is your first time). Huge amount of content to explore. Balancing issues need to be looked at. Good game ( and addictive). Worth your money. Waiting for First DLC campaign";128.5;1.0;0.0;78.0;Posted: May 18

I bought this game and had my expectations quite high. Elden Ring fully succeeded them and now is probably my favourite game of all time. If you are planning on getting this game and you are reading this review.

The only downside to this game is the stuttering once in a while but that changes from location to location and i did not notice it that much so it will not effect your experience. This game just seems perfect to me. The open world is amazing
column2: im not usually a fan of the open world genre however the open world theme is perfect and really adds on to this amazing game. The game does not make you go from one location to another completing the main missions as you can do it however you want.

column1: As you first start in the game you are not given any guidance but if you look at a direction you want to go you can go on for hours. The difficulty is is hard on most bosses except the few. You probably can't kill many bosses first try which is what i really love about this game as you have to adapt and download there play style.
Exploring is my favourite thing in this game as i was going a woods and i found this elevator
column2: i wont say but it was beautiful and shows that this game has really good graphics aswell as the awesome game play.

column1: If you are struggling with the game
column2: there is no difficulty slider but there are certain weapons and summons that are OP but i recommend not using them as i prefer to struggle with a boss and kill it as it is more rewarding.

column1: I could spend hours on this game at a time and not get bored. There is also a massive amount of replayabilty included with the vast amount of weapons that you can acquire.
Overall i recommend this game as i think it is a once in a generation game. If this doesnt win game of the decade im not sure what to think.
The FPS on PC is noticeable. Got a refund";1.3;0.0;0.0;25.0;Posted: May 18

I've been a fan of the franchise since Dark Souls 1 on xbox. Elden Ring is without a doubt the best
column2: most fleshed out
column3: and most evolved version of the Soulsbourne formula.

column1: Without going into to much detail
column2: this game evolves on almost everything from the former games.

column1: Blocking is more viable and there is a guard-counter attack system.

column2: you can change the weapon skill for free at rest sites which allows much more flexibility and experimentation.

column1: Probably the most impressive thing about Elden Ring is that
column2: despite the massive world and great amount of content
column3: there are basically no drops in quality throughout. Nothing really feels rushed or half-finished
column4: there are no areas which feel lazy or poorly designed.

column1: A couple of optional bosses re-use enemies
column2: similar to the Stray Demons in DS1.

column1: While a lot of the changes made in this game add more depth to the combat system
column2: a lot has been done to support new players to the franchise and there are more tutorials and information provided to the player. Additionally
column3: I think this is probably the best Soulsbourne game for a full co-op playthrough
column4: due to the improvements to multiplayer.

column1: If you've never played a Soulsbourne game before
column2: this is the perfect game to start with.
From and Miyazaki have made a masterpiece here!";211.0;1.0;0.0;170.0;Posted: May 18

column1: This is the first time a From Software game seems to be transmitting a message of hope.
The Lands Between are broken and are just a mere shadow of a long-lost glorious past
column2: an empty and cracked husk filled by the darkness of eternal unrest. The struggle of the world seems fated to be forever endured by its inhabitants
column3: stuck in an endless cycle of life and something that only bears a faded resemblance to death.

column2: something seems to be in motion
column3: and this time
column4: the tarnished isn't just a moth drawn to someone's else flame
column5: tricked into doing their bidding. The world may be dead
column6: but for the first time
column7: the protagonist actually has the power to do something about it. The road is harsh and filled with peril
column8: but through time and effort
column9: the world can be mended.

I finally beat Elden Ring. It was an incredibly fun game to play: An extremely customizable experience with a sizable challenge in a vast open world with a rather cryptic story and appropriate music. It kept me playing for about 150 hours
column2: and that's a lot to say. Breaking it down:
what a freaking fun game. Definitely gameplay is what makes a game
column3: but when you only have gameplay and several other elements like UI
column4: Story and netplay are weak
column5: it is hard for me to give a 10. However this game is definitely worth playing 150 hours and buying. Strong recommendation

column1: The gameplay is superb. It is so much fun to explore the world
column2: to build your character to your liking
column3: to struggle to foes and eventually overcome them. To discover random things. Truth be told is pretty hard (or extremely time consuming) to find out stuff without some Googling. It's still pretty rewarding when you find out things that you didn't look for online
column4: so try to keep Googling to as little as you can to break through.

column1: The game is flexible enough to let you change most of your choices as you walk through
column2: and you can make the game work towards your gameplay.
but the difficulty is a bit overhyped. It is not 'exclusive' to elite gamers
column3: and it is not really that hard. It makes some fairly silly decisions to preserve this aura of eliteness like not allowing you to pause. It has some curve
column4: but that's it. Most of the inaccessibility comes from abysmal UI design (This is my first souls-like game).

column1: I need to set a subcategory just for this
column2: because it is downright terrible. I feel this game gets a lot of free passes from reviewers and fans of the genre because it is 'a souls game' it is 'the way from software does things'
column3: or it is to 'make it harder'. There are advances in game design that this game plainly neglects.

column1: * How come in 2022 you have to rotate through all your spells or skills to get the one you want. Seriously? Never heard of wheels to select or other more modern alternatives?
* Bookmarks in the map? Super basic support. You want to delete one
column2: you need to find it in your map first or walk next to it. Wait
column3: you don't want to delete it but you walked next to it? Sorry.

column1: * Map overlay. Non-existent. I respect the minimalist UI
column2: but having an option to show the map is basic
column3: especially when watching the map does not pause the game. It does not make it harder
column4: it is just a hassle.

column1: * Dialogs that prevent you from taking action. Yeah
column2: I know that I unlocked the swordstone
column3: now let me beat those skeletons
column4: please?

column1: * And well... just the lack of basic guidance. That just makes the game unfriendly to people new to the series
column2: for no good reason. It's not hard
column3: you just have to Google stuff. I don't want to look online how to play my game.

column2: plenty of details and it looks gorgeous on a 4K display. That said the game has plenty of hiccups even on a RTX 3090. These are not necessarily resolution or settings dependent
column3: and it will have hiccups regardless of your configuration which sucks. HDR is fairly mediocre
column4: I even believe Windows 11 Auto-HDR does a better or at least comparable job to the game's native HDR.

column2: I doubt I will remember more than one or two tunes in a year or so. However
column3: it plays very well to the atmosphere and it is in general well done.

column1: I appreciate good story in a long game. This game barely has any story
column2: and that is even if you go and read notes behind each item
column3: do the quests
column4: and even look a bit online to fill in the gaps. Most of the charm of the story comes from the fact that it is hidden and you have to discover it
column5: but that is just a crutch as the story is pretty bland.

column2: you want my rune
column3: I will kill you""
column4: the main antagonist barely talks. The closest to a decent interaction is one of their minions. And don't let me get started with those extremely disappointing endings. The game expects you to do a bunch of long quests
column5: just to see a few different words in some of the endings
column6: AND has the nerve to ask you to do a full playthrough to see each of them. (Don't do that
column7: backup your save file). Note: The quests are fun and rewarding on their own merit
column8: but still...

column1: There is some amount of world building
column2: and the quests are engaging(although fairly depressing). However there is little character growth. The only characters that are interesting are Ranni
column3: Melina and maybe Gideon. Frankly
column4: I don't think I will remember much of the story in a year.

column1: This game is so fun to play with friends. It is so fun that you can almost overlook how terrible the netplay implementation is.
You cannot really expect to play with your friends
column2: without them disconnecting half a dozen times per session. You cannot expect to understand how the somehow redundant mechanisms work without googling. Also you really cannot expect a low latency experience.

column1: It is a shame because going and fighting precisely overleveled bosses when you are carefully downleveled makes for a very fun shared challenge. Having some random person invade you while you are trying to beat the boss... is surprisingly fun and refreshing.
I really hope they patch the performance on PC
column2: and fix the graphics. That may bump the game to a 9. I have no hope of them improving the UI though.";160.0;1.0;0.0;63.0;Posted: May 18

column1: I love this game. While it's not perfect
column2: it lives up to the hype in every way (unless we're talking about multi-player
column3: but more on this later).

column1: With a massive (and I do mean massive) open world to explore
column2: one can spend hours and hours and hours poking around what can only be described as a gorgeous
column3: well crafted landscape that rarely fails to surprise
column4: which lends itself to a true sense of awe. In this way
column5: you can stumble into some of the best fights I've ever experienced in any game
column6: ever
column7: seemingly out of nowhere. Truly delightful.

column2: in true FromSoft fashion
column3: having no animation canceling. Basically. you have to commit to each swing of your sword
column4: or spell that you cast. It's great in that you're forced to know what you're doing
column5: and truly learn and puzzle out the algorithm of each new foe
column6: applying the skills of your particular build as near to perfection as possible. Also in FromSoft fashion
column7: even low level enemies can wreck you in short order
column8: even if you're high level
column9: so you have to constantly be on your toes
column10: and must take each mob seriously (hell
column11: sometimes even singular creatures).

column1: I wouldn't say that the Area Bosses are the most interesting
column2: and I generally use the AI helpers to speed through them
column3: to get to the more interesting stuff. Evergols(sp?) are a particular favorite
column4: and some of the random dungeon bosses make me wish I could fight them again and again.

column1: Where this game takes a big sh*t is in the multi-player. It does have a lot of potential
column2: and if FS addresses some of the more egregious problems
column3: it could be great. But as it stands
column4: not so much. In fact
column5: it feels like an after thought.

column2: I can't tell you how many times I simply DC in the middle of a fight
column3: which feels awful. When that's not happening
column4: it's incredibly hard to get in the flow
column5: as you can be invaded by a rival player at literally any moment. While there are well demarcated hot spots where you're more likely to encounter so called 'bloody fingers'
column6: server lag often leaves it difficult to land hits
column7: and while they can take environmental damage
column8: monsters do not agro to them. You are allotted additional support
column9: in the form of other players in the roll of hunters
column10: but this doesn't really make it any more fun.

column1: I love testing my meddle against other players
column2: but in my opinion
column3: PvP should be opt in
column4: between interested parties
column5: a la ESO (which does this so
column6: so
column7: so well). As it stands
column8: you and your hommies can be in the middle of a great fight
column9: and some ass-hat will come along and f*ck it all up. Even when they die
column10: it doesn't feel truly satisfying
column11: because it breaks the normal flow of the game. It's just poor design in my opinion.

column1: Other aspects of MP are odd as well. For example
column2: as a support player
column3: you don't lose your runes when you die
column4: but you immediately get booted back to your world. Personally
column5: I would rather lose my runes
column6: and re-spawn in the host world (mostly just to keep the flow going). Lastly
column7: there's no spectator mode
column8: which is truly a bummer. If you die in a host world
column9: you get booted immediately
column10: and can't even watch them finish the fight
column11: win or lose.

column1: Overall I would HIGHLY recommend this game
column2: save the multi-player (if only for your own sanity).";268.7;1.0;0.0;39.0;Posted: May 18

column2: first off
column3: this game is extremely good. The world is immersive and deceptively deep
column4: and the scale of this game is incredible. I don't just mean the size of the map
column5: but the incredible versatility of the environments and the sheer mass of buildings and geography are intense to say the least. It looks beautiful and plays like a dream. The gameplay is extremely polished
column6: and I don't think I've ever seen cleaner hit-boxes.

column2: this game is in SERIOUS need of balancing. I'm nowhere near the end of the game
column3: but I still get routinely 1/2-shotted by some bosses I'm definitely leveled enough for. I'm also in full heavy armor and using a shield with the Barricade Shield ability. Even so
column4: you'd think I wasn't playing a tank based on how much damage I take. Quite frankly
column5: it's absurd. It's not as if the game is too difficult
column6: but rather that the game is far too punishing for the tiniest of mistakes.

column1: This isn't a problem on all bosses though. Margit is a great example of a perfectly tuned and incredible fight
column2: assuming you approach the encounter without grinding too much (or too early
column3: for that matter). It's a fantastic skill check to see if you are ready for what the game has to offer.

column1: Not all bosses are as well tuned as Margit though. If you want to make a game difficult
column2: don't just crank up the damage the bosses deal and call it good. That's poor game design. A difficult encounter should push you to the limit of your skill and make you better at the game than you were before
column3: not just stun combo you into oblivion if you dodge 0.00001 seconds too early. It feels really cheap sometimes.

column1: I know this sort of critique is likely to licit 25 variations of ""git gud
column2: but this is the one and ONLY problem I have with the game.

column1: It's an astounding title and I can't wait to play it more
column2: I just wish the difficulty was more rewarding to an increase in skill rather than level.";102.4;1.0;0.0;50.0;Posted: May 18

column2: or lies on launch. There are glitches and bugs but most games of this scale have those but they don't take away from the play-ability for me that i have found. I want to show off that hard work. This should be the standard for games. I want more games to be like "" Here is what you need to do. column2: but this is probably the best game I have played since Witcher 3 or Divinity 2. However it is not for everyone. While difficulty might be a little turnoff for some players (Most people playing this game are looking for a challenge anyway)
column3: The biggest reason you might not play this game is commitment. You have to dedicate a lot of time to learn about the game mechanics and game knowledge that are niche to the souls series. Even as a veteran of the dark souls 3 this game was a tough slog
column4: and my first playthrough was over 90 hours long. However
column5: anyone that can find the time and is willing to take up the challenge will find their time rewarded very well
column6: especially if they continue to play beyond their first playthrough for the pvp and build crafting. This game will definitely get DLC near the end of the year or early next year
column7: which will make this game even more replayable. The game is worth every penny and then some in my opinion.";232.4;1.0;0.0;36.0;Posted: May 17

Elden Ring was a fantastic experience and is undoubtedly game of the year for me. I would rate this FromSoftware title a 9.5/10 and put it at my third favorite from the series. I loved the fact that the game was very open. This allowed my first playthru to be extremely unique and engaging. As with most Fromsoftware games
column2: a lot of the story/lore is found passively thru the items you find and usually minor dialogue from NPC's. I have minor gripes about the game such as the reused boss skins and/or minor bosses with very similar or same move-sets as others but this doesn't really take away much from the experience as a whole. This game was everything they promised and more. If you like any souls-type games and the idea of an open world
column3: this is a must-have game for you. Elden Ring an excellent starting point if you are new the series as I found this to be the easiest title in the franchise. If you enjoy this one then definitely check out Demon Souls
column4: Dark Souls 1-3
column5: Sekiro
column6: and Bloodborne.

This is FromSofts best game to date.
The combat is buttery and smooth with wide variety of weapons
column2: spells and trinkets that create a wonderful web for potentially very diverse builds. It is intense and spectacular with a niche for every player and playstyle. Magic is more interesting than ever before without feeling overpowered as the game offers a huge selection of various spells and incantations with varying effects.

column1: The game itself looks absolutely stunning and is packed with content and secrets at every corner and the locations all hide a huge amount of very intriguing lore as well as unique encounters and locations. Exploration is extremely rewarding and fun as the world while punishing is very fun to navigate and particularly in the early and midway stages of the game I found myself captivated and drawn to explore every inch of the areas laid out in front of me.
The games lore and storyline is compelling and extremely well written as well as implemented perfectly and generally seamlessly into the world.
Bosses are a mixed bag in this game and their quality is vastly inconsistent compared to other FromSoft games. While some are in my opinion some of the best ever made such as Dragonlord Placidusax
column2: Morgott The Omen King and Mogh Lord of Blood
column3: many severely suffer from being simply too big to fit on the camera thus making their moves unpredictable and frustrating to deal with
column4: turning combat into a wild scramble to deal damage and roll away which is made worse by the trend of delayed attacks and rollcatching moves in this game.

column1: Furthermore some bosses (looking at you Godskins) are copy and pasted throughout the game and while some may see it as a tasteful recurring enemy with a variety of combinations
column2: others may feel them to be lazy and unimaginative.

column1: NPCs are interesting and their questlines are rewarding and fun but due to the non linear and spacious nature of the game it could use better indicators as to where to go
column2: although I will say the developers have been very attentive to the complaints of the players regarding that and have marked the locations of NPCs.

column1: It saddens me to say that the PVP is quite simply horrendous which is a shame especially in a game with such potential variety for interesting and unique builds
column2: there are perhaps 2 or 3 builds that can found in the online world
column3: and all of them using weapons that are essentially similar in nature. Katanas and bleed reign supreme and whilst I do not judge any method of playing in single player
column4: the clear advantage that certain builds and weapons posses make for a very unfun PVP experience comparatively to other games such as DS3.";379.3;1.0;0.0;52.0;Posted: May 17

column1: One of the best games I have played in years.
I do not regret spending +200 hours playing this game
column2: because it's simply fun to play.

column1: It's undoubtedly not an easy game
column2: but its difficulty doesn't come out of cheapness
column3: but rather punishment for not adapting to the intuitive and superb mechanics of the game itself. It's the essence of 'Git Gud' mentality
column4: learn and adapt to overcome the obstacles thrown at you
column5: or continue to fail again and again. But what makes Elden Ring
column6: like other 'Souls' games so fun to play is that you are rewarded tremendously for overcoming your obstacles - by the end of the game
column7: you are strong enough to even conquer Gods and nothing feels as satisfying as coming into New Game Plus and squashing a Boss who troubled you for hours beforehand within mere seconds.

column1: I admittedly have been a Souls fan since the Armored Core days so there is bias to my assessment - however I also understand why this game does not appeal to everyone for whatever reasons
column2: and that's okay - I loved this game
column3: and perhaps you will too.";232.4;1.0;0.0;226.0;Posted: May 17

If you are new to FromSoftware games
column2: start here. There are so many ways to play Elden Ring with dozens of viable builds
column3: even if you find it hard you can make it easier by exploring the map. Whats great about Elden Ring is
column4: unlike previous Souls-likes
column5: you don't have to keep throwing yourself at a boss that your struggling to beat. You can comfortably explore the giant map to get better items
column6: level-up or even just get experience with the mechanics. This game's difficulty is tied to how you decide to play. You can easily beat the game with max level weapons
column7: high level in stats and spirit summons which assist you in battles.

column1: If you are a souls veteran there's no doubt that you will love aspects of this game. But
column2: you will also realise that it's an open world Souls-like which naturally comes with issues in progression. If you miss a boss (which is very easy to do)
column3: you might come back later and absolutely destroy it which ruins some of the challenge that draws you into these games. In this way it deviates from the normal Souls-like formula. You might experience running into a hard boss and wondering if you should push through the challenge or go level-up more. Both of these scenarios have consequences as you could beat the boss to early and find the next area of progression to easy
column4: or leave to level-up only to come back without a challenge. Going into Elden Ring these are aspects that you have to accept. Not everyone will have such a similar experience which was a highlight of previous Souls-likes.

column2: this game is a big treat. I was interested in it for awhile
column3: unknowing what it really was except hearing that it was made by the devs who made the Dark Souls series. It was because of that I ended up picking up Dark Souls III about six months before Elden Ring's initial launch date before postpone
column4: mostly to both feel out the genre and if I would really enjoy it and see what the hype was about this series I've long heard of but never played. I found myself enthralled by it
column5: and even anticipating Elden Ring by that matter. If Dark Souls III was really good
column6: Elden Ring would be too
column7: right?

column1: In truth? I found myself even more fascinated with Elden Ring. Immediately
column2: I rushed out without doing the tutorial and took to the world
column3: exploring without care. I'm no fan of open world games by any means
column4: I struggle with that level of freedom and general overwhelming amount of things they throw at you just in your peripherals. And yet
column5: with Elden Ring
column6: it was vastly different. It didn't bear down and give me too many things to do at once. It doesn't saturate my perception of the game nor does it force me to go my way. I was smart anyways and knew I needed to level some before I ran off to fight the Tree Sentinel
column7: or further bosses. And unlike DS3 I am not forced to go in one direction ultimately
column8: and I can go anywhere I please. Is Margit giving me trouble? Well
column9: there's always the Weeping Peninsula.

column1: I also appreciate the flexibility you can get in this game for builds. It felt like it was a little less open in DS3 with what I can pull
column2: and although there are definitely meta-builds and quality builds
column3: Elden Ring at any rate has given me the option to play with almost anything it throws at me
column4: and to me at least nothing feels wasted. It also feels more lenient even despite the more fine-tuned mechanics. Feels like I cant get away from panic rolling like I was able to in many fights in DS3. Not as much
column5: anyways.

column2: I actually found this game to be fairly understandable in lore and direction. Still
column3: a long shot from other RPGs where you'd get your handful of story
column4: but it was at least comprehensible in a single playthrough without having to resort to YouTube videos
column5: wikia
column6: etc. and I appreciate that. It just requires a little bit more deep searching
column7: which this game really encourages anyways. This game is as in depth as you are willing to dig into it.

column2: it's incredible how big the game is. After barreling through Stormveil
column3: and seeing Liurnia
column4: it was astonishing that it opened up into another massive sprawl of land that seemed to go without end. And then beyond there. Hoping that if they do DLC
column5: it easily matches the fidelity these places seem to have.

column1: My only big gripe however is the multiplayer. And
column2: specifically not the issues with invasions or what-not
column3: I love those. It's fun. I just wish it was more like DS3 is all. I miss having my 3 white and gold boys
column4: having a few aldrich boys and purples running in out of nowhere
column5: having a swell ole time with several players was just a fun chaos for me. It's understandable why Elden Ring is capped 4 per lobby (including invaders)
column6: but I would appreciate a wider amount of peeps. Really hard to play this game when you have more friends than summon slots.

column2: writing this review after defeating Elden Ring
column3: definitely one of my most favorite games of all time. It just...again and again surprised me
column4: and made me fall in love with it more and more between the fun interactions and getting lost in this world. Hope to see more for this game
column5: but I'm not gonna worry about that anytime soon
column6: still enough here to stave me off for another few months.";127.9;1.0;0.0;81.0;Posted: May 17

column2: this game was delivered as a finished product rather than something unfinished or unstable. so many big budget games these few years have released in a state that should be considered unsalable and sadly in so many cases unsalvageable. this has happened for so long that i fear our standards have lowered and become more accepting that any modern game shouldn't be expected to be finished on release. game's like Elden Ring prove that mindset wrong.

With a new IP by FromSoftware
column2: I anticipated new ways to get ambushed or bamboozled
column3: and the game did not disappoint in that regard. However
column4: there was one trick I was positive would not work on me. Never again would I see my character mauled to death by a damn chest with teeth
column5: for I knew by now how to identify the fiends before they could strike. And so
column6: I smacked every chest I came across as I began my travels throughout the Lands Between
column7: but there were no mimics to be found anywhere. ""Aha!"" I thought to myself
column8: ""This must be yet another ploy by Miyazaki to let down my guard
column9: and when the complacency sets in
column10: then a mimic shall strike and bite my face off!"" But I
column11: in a rare instance of foresight
column12: would not allow such a thing to come to pass. I continued to smack every single chest I stumbled upon
column13: so certain was I that somewhere out there was a mimic waiting in the most unlikely of locations. I would be ready for it no matter what
column14: but alas
column15: no such encounter ever came. For that
column16: I give the game a 9/10.";150.4;1.0;0.0;141.0;Posted: May 17

Id describe this game as a modern Skyrim with polished Dark Souls 3 themed gameplay.
The map is HUGE which makes it a pleasure to freely run around to just explore for hours.
I also love that theres sooo many unique weapons to find/collect and sooo many bosses to take out.

Point is this game has plenty to keep you busy for many hours and thankfully its much more forgiving than the previous FromSoftware games that seem to all have a reputation of being extremely difficult.
I havent played much PVP so I cant give a proper opinion to that regard but the two times i did fight in PVP i was quickly killed by players who seemed to have superior lvl/gear

After beating the game for the first time
column2: I feel I can finally leave a review.

column1: Elden Ring from the time you step out of the tutorial is a huge and beautiful open world. The world can be bright and vibrant
column2: or dark and gloomy or even just scary. Every area is unique and different and makes you want to explore. This is certainly a game you need the wiki up at most times in order to get everything you may need. The NPC quests are not tracked and easily missable or messed up without proper planning or research. The bosses will sometimes require you to know a specific weakness to make them easier. However
column3: with enough head banging on the wall approach
column4: you will be able to prevail regardless of build. Can't speak on the pvp as I only invaded 3 times (required for a NPC quest) and my experience was being jumped on by three players at the same time. I will say I tried to be summoned by other players to help them with certain bosses. Every time it was choppy
column5: laggy and I would die to invisible damage or be kicked because of the connection. The bosses
column6: for the most part
column7: were amazing and cinematic. Had my anxiety at peak levels
column8: hands shaking and everything. There was a great sense of accomplishment after downing a boss after a straight hour of trying. Overall
column9: amazing game
column10: amazing world
column11: amazing bosses
column12: memorable NPC's. I don't regret a single minute of my experience.";121.5;1.0;0.0;9.0;Posted: May 16

column1: Elden Ring is created by FromSoft. A game studio that is well-known
column2: and also notorious for the difficulty of their games. Difficulty that has encouraged most gamers to stay away from their games. So
column3: with 12M+ Sales. Will this game be your point of entry to the mind and creativity of Miyazaki? Find out below!

column1: Is the game difficult like other FromSoft ""souls-like"" titles?

column2: Elden Ring is the easiest game out of them all. With the ability to choose go wherever you want
column3: the game motivates you to defeat its bosses at your own pace. Coupled with access Spirit Ashes
column4: Multiplayer Friendly Co-op
column5: and easily farmable items. Defeating bosses has become easier now more than ever. How you build your character is also important. It's the primary number in the game that will dictate how easy or difficult your experience would be. All in all
column6: stats
column7: summon chance
column8: co-op and items can be considered as difficulty slider. If you're feeling bored of how easy the game is
column9: you can handicap yourself by not using summons
column10: co-op
column11: or items to make it harder. Do note that bosses still require a certain amount of skill/effort to be defeated. You cannot just spam the attack button without reading boss inputs or you'll retry bosses over and over and over again. Speaking of bosses...

column1: How difficult are the bosses compared to other FromSoft ""soul-like"" titles?
If you use all the tools (summons
column2: items
column3: upgraded weapons) and strategies (using specific tools to exploit weakness
column4: cheese strats
column5: spamming OP ashes of war) and have the right build (scaling your vigor to the areas of the game
column6: not having an all-around build) the bosses can easily be dispatched without trouble
column7: and they'll be easier than other games in the ""souls-like"" franchise"". However
column8: if you plan play in a classic Dark Souls playstyle
column9: and try to solo a boss. You'll be in a world of pain. The bosses are designed to be fought with a summon
column10: hence
column11: solo'ing a boss will immediately increase the difficulty of the fight. It is heavily not recommended to solo the bosses in the game if you are new to the ""souls-like"" genre as it will definitely turn you off.

column1: Elden Ring is an open world game that is full of items
column2: dungeons
column3: and enemies. You can traverse 85% of the map after completing the tutorial at your own risk
column4: only gate keeping the rest of the map (endgame) from you if you haven't killed 4 mandatory bosses. That's right
column5: to get to endgame
column6: you just need to kill 4 mandatory bosses. A very minimal required kill count compared to previous FromSoft titles. Every spot in the game is not wasted space
column7: as most of it is filled with either items
column8: enemies
column9: or useful weapons/armors.

column1: You can create a ton of builds in this game. From magic based
column2: to bleed
column3: to frost
column4: to lightning
column5: to the basic quality builds found in older games. Unfortunately
column6: respecc chances are very limited and requires killing a certain boss for the mechanic to be unlocked. So
column7: if you're new to the game or ""souls-like"" games in general. I recommend you follow a build in Youtube. Remember
column8: the difficulty of this game on your build and playstyle. If you ♥♥♥♥ up your build
column9: chances are high that you won't be having a great time with your game. So make your 1st play through stress free by reading a spoiler-free build guide!

column1: Endgame content is very rushed. Bosses are overtuned and can oneshot to 3-shot you no matter how high your vigor is. Making trading damage very unviable. They also contain animations that give them hyperarmor. Making them immune to stagger. This makes playing a pure strength or quality build in the end very difficult.
Hit boxes against bosses are very precise
column2: which requires precise attacks. Yet player hit-boxes can easily be hit
column3: no matter which boss you're fighting
column4: leading to very unfair situations
column5: and bad trading chances.

column1: How bosses act in the game is very RNG dependent. They can either be really really passive
column2: or really really aggressive. Unlike other ""souls-like"" games. Bosses in Elden Ring seems to have no ability timer
column3: allowing them to just spam whatever ability they want. This either will make the boss experience very
column4: very easy
column5: or very
column6: very hard.

column1: Input-Reading in the game is very blatant and is triggered by: healing
column2: casting non-invisibility magic
column3: and firing arrows. Whenever you do these actions
column4: bosses immediately become aggressive or do an attack that is undodgeable because you're stuck in an animation. So be sure to be very far from them if you do those actions.

column1: For a modern game. There is no quest log is no built-in quest log. If you forgot a character to talk to
column2: chances are high that you will not complete their quest line.

column1: Combat alleviation: Use summons to alleviate the combat system flaws found within the game. They will serve not only as a chance to deal double damage to the boss
column2: but also a distraction for your to heal
column3: buff
column4: or strike.

column1: Missing quest-log alleviation: Use side-quest guides in the internet to look where to go next for the quest. Others are recommending to use a pen and paper and jot down notes that they have found in the game. But I don't recommend it as it is an outdated way of storing information in an Open World Game. We need to force FromSoft to put a quest log in their next Open World Game. (No quest logs for their linear games would be just fine
column2: but no quest logs for open world just sucks)

column1: The story is told in the opening and the ending cutscenes. The Rising Tension
column2: Climax
column3: Falling Action of the game will depend on you. Like other ""souls-like"" game created by FromSoft. Do not expect the straight forward narrative story-telling of other games. If you want to know the lore of Elden Ring
column4: and want to make sense of the opening and ending cutscenes
column5: PAY VERY CLOSE ATTENTION TO THE DIALOGUE AND READ EVERY ITEM DESCRIPTION. It requires effort and research to determine the lore of the game
column6: even then
column7: players are given vague descriptions that make it impossible to fully and factually determine the lore of the Lands Between. All FromSoft ""souls-like"" games have a ""story""
column8: but if you cannot put the effort into combining pieces in a puzzle that you know lacks pieces
column9: then you can just disregard that the game has a story to tell you.

column1: It's not really that great and detailed compared to Western Titles such as RDR2. If you can overlook it
column2: then you won't have a problem with the game.

column1: You can now play online without worrying that you'll be invaded unlike other souls-like games by FromSoft. Also
column2: unlike in Dark Souls
column3: expect that weapons in this game are unbalanced because of how FromSoft designed bosses. So
column4: expect that people will have META OP builds that'll one shot you.

column1: Elden Ring is the newest ""souls-like"" title by FromSoft. It is an open-world game that does not waste any space in its map. It's full of content to be discovered
column2: and used by the player. It is the easiest game compared to its predecessors yet will still challenge newbies and veterans alike. Stat distribution
column3: builds
column4: summons
column5: co-op
column6: and items can either make the game way easier than it is or be extremely difficult
column7: hence I call it the game's difficulty slider. Since the gameslider isn't tangible
column8: you need to have a feel for it
column9: and adjust accordingly to hit the difficulty sweet spot setting for a better gaming experience. Due to its flaws. It is not recommended for newbies to solo bosses in their 1st playthrough. On the other hand
column10: newbies are recommended to seek a build guide in order for a smoother gaming experience
column11: as builds is the primary determinant of difficulty in the game. All

column1: Everything you've heard is true. This game is hard. This game is beautiful. This game is as rewarding as it is punishing. This game is amazing. When you run Stormveil Castle you might see why some sites ranked it as a masterpiece.

column2: but do have some good points coming up. Having played Demon's Souls and Dark Souls 3
column3: I will say that this Elden Ring improves a few things that bothered me.

column1: Here is the rundown that I'm okay giving after 100 hours.

column2: I want to give a shout out to the Level Design team
column3: because wow. Textures and details aside
column4: the actual level design for places like Stormveil Castle is completely nuts. 11/10 these people need a big promotion.

column1: 2) Music is a big ooof. Don't get me wrong
column2: it's high quality; it just doesn't work as well as I want it to for me personally. I have a lot of respect for the composition team
column3: and I can't quite put my finger on what it is
column4: but it doesn't have the ooomph or the hummability that say the Demon's Souls main area had.

column1: 3) Elden Ring makes it easy to acquire basic weapon upgrades
column2: to the point of being able to buy them (smithing stone tier 1 and tier 2) with effectively infinite money. Number 1 thing that stung in Demon's Souls was the crystal worms (which contained a crafting material) that would disappear FOREVER for that playthrough if you missed them. Haven't found that yet here
column3: so 10/10 already. Big win here.

column2: it is also very satisfying. It's like if you combine Elder Scrolles and Thief and Hitman. I am notoriously bad at mechanics-driven games such as this
column3: and I will say that even though I die A LOT I always enjoy the challenge of hunting down my lost loot. It's like a search and rescue mission every 2-46 minutes.

There are probably two types of people who might be interested in Elden Ring: there are the souls-series fans that have already played and probably beaten Elden Ring by now
column2: and there are the people on the fence about it and are worried it'll be too ""hard-core"" for them. I'm going to try and make a review for both types of people here.

for those new to the series. Elden Ring and basically every other souls-series game are really just action rpg's that have an emphasis on discovery. What I mean by this is that this game will rarely straight up tell you anything. The story is extremely detached from your character feeling more like you're just someone in the world rather than the ""main character."" The fun in the story is in just figuring out what it really is (or watching youtube videos that do it for you). Not just the story though
column3: the game hints at your objective
column4: but won't lay it out in simple blunt terms like most games. You won't get a way-marker on where all of the main bosses are
column5: instead you have golden lines from the checkpoints that point in the direction of the nearest one. You're meant to figure out all of the fine details of everything with the game. You aren't told that many upgrade materials are found in mines
column6: you eventually figure it out through some common sense and/or pattern recognition whenever you enter a mine. You aren't told you're under powered for a certain boss
column7: you just figure it out when you can barely do damage to it and it one-shots you. You aren't told that 90% of your damage is really based on how upgraded your weapon is rather than your level
column8: you're shown it. I could go on
column9: but I think you get the picture. What these games offer is a sense of wonderment and discovery
column10: not too different from older NES/SNES games but with more modern game design sensibilities.

column1: For those who get the souls-series and want to know what Elden Ring offers that the others didn't. That is mainly a much more open world with surprises behind every corner
column2: and a much more diverse and powerful magic system with the game designed around you using the FP bar on something rather than having certain builds easily avoid it. Unfortunately
column3: the game suffers from a few technical issues most notably with multiplayer co-op. Often times
column4: if you're trying to play with a friend
column5: you can only reliably be in their game and vice-versa for a few minutes before the game kicks you back to your world sometimes. Other times
column6: it works great. It's very inconsistent.

column2: the game itself has a few balance issues
column3: and repeated content most notably in bosses. The balance of the game takes a hard spike around the second half requiring you to have at least 50-60 vigor to not be one shot by most enemies
column4: and the amount of runes you get for defeating certain ones is all over the place
column5: with some insanely hard ones dropping pitiful amounts and easy ones dropping an insane amount. It's never impossible
column6: but it starts to require you to do cheap tactics to handle certain encounters reliably like exploiting the AI
column7: slowly killing them with ranged attacks when they can't reach you
column8: or using one of the many imbalanced weapons that do WAY more damage than the rest. Next
column9: the bosses
column10: many people hear Elden Ring has 83 bosses and thinks ""wow
column11: that's a lot"" when really so many of them are copy/pasted with VERY minor alterations that in reality it only has about 20 if I'm being generous. Now
column12: it wouldn't be as much a problem if it was relegated to just the end of side dungeons
column13: but many of these repeats happen in the main game levels too. The weird tree thing is used so often in the game that it might as well be a mini-boss. For regular enemies too
column14: you start to notice the repeat just with higher damage and health. Where in other souls games
column15: you'd start to feel burn out on repeated content after replaying it 3-4 times
column16: Elden Ring already gave me that feeling before I beat it the first time. Makes it much more of a drag to replay for a different build that you end up just running past most enemies because you can't be bothered to kill the same thing for the 1000 time.

column2: it's one of the best games I've ever played and I do recommend it despite the amount of criticisms I threw at it just before. Though I still think I like Bloodborne more.";218.2;1.0;0.0;307.0;Posted: May 16

column3: but it's storytelling plays a big part. The characters are distinctive with a very good accent on their personality. Graphically it is really good
column4: the game is colorful with very well designed locations. Every mission has unique map
column5: so it won't get repetitive or boring. Music and sound is clear
column6: memorable and quite catchy. Great voice acting! ""Titanfall 2"" introduces some simple but rewarding game mechanics. It may not be anything new

NOTE: I base this review on the solo experience with the Campaign as a whole.

As someone who has spent nearly 2000 hours at Apex Legends I became curios about this game when I heard about it being so extremely good and worth it just for the campaign alone. I started the campaign and played through it on Master difficulty (hardest). Of course it wasn't easy but it was useful to do the training course and beat the time for the achievement to get better at the movement.

column2: graphics and and atmosphere overall.

column1: Great and intersting story which I would say the setting looks something like a mix between Halo and CoD series. Nice bosses and challenging enemies while still feeling fair and well balanced.
Fast paced fps with amazing gunplay and movement.

column2: enemies and characters and abilities being so familiar as an Apex Player. While mechs aren't in Apex Legends they were very nice too.

column1: Hackers ruining the multiplayer of Titan Falls so for the solo experience I can't find any cons.

Titanfall 2 is a solid 10/10 and one of the best games I've played in any genre. While I exclusively base my review on the campaign I have no doubt that when the multiplayer works properly that the same can be said about it.
Its well worth the asking price even if you play the campaign quickly on a low difficulty
column2: I only played it on Master once and went back to clean up some achievements but it was an amazing experience.

column1: You won’t necessarily feel alcohol’s impact on your body right away
column2: but it starts from the moment you take your first sip.
you’ve probably had some experience with alcohol’s effects
column3: from the warm buzz that kicks in quickly to the not-so-pleasant wine headache
column4: or the hangover that shows up the next morning. Since those effects don’t last long
column5: you might not worry much about them
column6: especially if you don’t drink often.

column1: Many people assume the occasional beer or glass of wine at mealtimes or special occasions doesn’t pose much cause for concern. But drinking any amount of alcohol can potentially lead to unwanted health consequences.
People who binge drink or drink heavily may notice more health effects sooner
column2: but alcohol also poses some risks for people who drink in moderation.

column1: Temporary effects you might notice while drinking alcohol (or shortly after) can include:
a sense of euphoria or giddiness

column2: vision
column3: and perception

column1: loss of consciousness or gaps in memory (often called a blackout)

column2: like a relaxed mood or lowered inhibitions
column3: might show up quickly after just one drink. Others
column4: like loss of consciousness or slurred speech
column5: may develop after a few drinks.

column2: like nausea
column3: headache
column4: and dizziness
column5: might not appear for a few hours
column6: and they can also depend on what you drink
column7: how much you drink
column8: and if you also drink water.

column1: These effects might not last very long
column2: but that doesn’t make them insignificant. Impulsiveness
column3: loss of coordination
column4: and changes in mood can affect your judgment and behavior and contribute to more far-reaching effects
column5: including accidents
column6: injuries

column1: This is where it all started
column2: or well almost. Titanfall 2 is the definite experience if you are looking for big burly unrelenting mecha combat since the BattleTech franchise has been on a slow burn since the early 2000s and we won't ever get a remake of SHOGO (+_+). The multiplayerside of things have sadly fallen due to mismanagement from EA (surprise!)and as far as I know servers are to blame. It used to have a ton of interesting modes with by far the best high octane combat seen since Quake 3 Arena swept me away in the dawn of time. The mechs are varied with intriguing loadouts that get the blood flowing and so are the regular gunplay as the titular pilot
column3: another name for the souped up space marines of the Titanfall universe. For those into moving down hordes of federalist douchebags there is the obligatory CO OP anti-horde mode where you together with 3 compatriots defend a beacon from the amassing throng of evil that is the IMC
column4: it is fun
column5: or rather was. I have not touched the multiplayer for over a year..

column2: and I have a lot of love for the multiplayer part
column3: the single player campaign is absolutely amazing. It could have been stellar if not for the fact that the only playable character is the generic template white dudebro that is not really a chosen one but actually he is. He just happens to inherit a Titan via some iffy battlefield promotion and goes on to become a legendary space marines in just a nick of time (I know about the “secret” training
column4: ok?). Captain Fancypants aside
column5: the game oozes personality through the bonding of said bloke (Jack Cooper
column6: blandest name ever) and his friendly neighborhood titan BT. BT is your friend
column7: your companion
column8: your lover
column9: your life and dare I say it one of the main reasons to play this game. The bantering between Cooper and BT is gold and all in all the progression in the campaign is perfection. The game pits you against a mercenary crew of Apex Predato pilots (some went on to Apex Legends fame) as well as the combined forces of the IMC and takes you through some really otherworldly scenarios as well as a fabulous array of locales to affect with mechanical mayhem and good dose of pew-pewing. All in all it is glorious..
