column1: Here's a longshot of a reference
column2: but this is what someone envisioned when they made Metal Warriors on the SNES
column3: but couldn't due to technical limitations. The fantasy of being able to run around as a soldier
column4: and hop into a mech seamlessly and cause larger chaos/carnage. When you're running around as a human
column5: you can sneak around areas with tight parkour action (and with a ton of guns that feel great to use and most have their own unique identity) -- and while you are fragile in your human form
column6: you still can take enemies ranging from infantry up to enemy mechs if you're careful. While in your Titan
column7: you are someone less mobile
column8: but have a plethora of weapons/abilities available to you (think of a MOBA where you have a bunch of additional abilities that you can use on cooldowns)
column9: IN ADDITION TO your weapons. Your mech can switch between a large variety of loadouts
column10: all which have their uses for different situations
column11: although you could in theory use your favourite loadout the whole time too.

column1: Titanfall 2 someone blends a ton of great ideas together
column2: and does them all to high proficiency.

column1: Music has a good orchestral score -- well composed
column2: but kind of what you would expect (I don't mean to call it forgettable
column3: since it's very evocative in the moments and performed well by a real orchestra
column4: but it's ""generic"").

column1: The sound design is fantastic where the guns sound/feel great
column2: being in the mech feels like it packs a punch and like you're running in a hulking futuristic metal power beast.
and is very smooth.

column1: That's all great. More importantly though
column2: the gameplay and story hold up.

column1: While I mentioned above that you have a lot of cool toys to play with
column2: that's all meaningless without the levels being engaging
column3: and they do a good job throwing a bunch of interesting scenarios at you that change up the formula (with some pretty great set pieces).

column1: The story is pretty serviceable -- you're the rebels fighting against the oppression and you lead an attack on an enemy world and a bunch of things happen that you've likely seen a bunch of times. What elevates it is your relationship with your mech and how you go between pilot to mech (in theory you could just not use the mech and fight some of the large scale battles as the pilot) to progress.

column2: the game throws in some curve balls into the levels to keep them feeling different. Interestingly
column3: one level has a time travel mechanic where you blink between past and present
column4: and I immediately thought back to Dishonored 2... it turns out
column5: both games were released within a month of each other: coincidence? corporate espionage? devs working together? In any case
column6: being able to blink back and forth works just as well in this game as it did that one.

column1: I kind of wish the campaign was longer (I beat it in 6 hours on Hard
column2: although it seems 8-10 is typical)
column3: but I can understand that the devs likely had a deadline (seeing as EA is the publisher... nuff said...) -- the levels are chock full of stuff and detail. And while there were a bunch of all out fights on an open battlefield
column4: I kind of wish there were more? Perhaps just add some arena-type sections in between some of the more heavily scripted parts just to add more of the excellent mech gameplay...

column2: I guess the goal is to jump into multiplayer after
column3: which has high praise from the community. There's even something called frontier defense? I'm guessing coop?

column2: because every time I tried playing it
column3: I got ""disconnected from server""... so
column4: a bit unfortunate.

column1: I hope they do go with TF3
column2: because this game truly lived up to the high praise I heard about it
column3: although it seems Respawn moved on to developing Apex Legends (which clearly borrowed a lot from this game: parkour and fast movement
column4: interesting guns
column5: powers). Also
column6: being under the umbrella of EA seems to be a death sentence for excellent dev studios
column7: so I won't keep my hopes up.

column2: a solid A of a game. You'll get your money's worth just from the campaign in case the ""servers disconnected"" issue persists. This is the new gold standard for mech games.";6.7;1.0;1.0;468.0;Posted: May 16

column1: I played this since it came out on Xbox and bought it when it was on sale for cheap. This game is still my favorite first person shooter. I have logged 100s of hours on this and think it is a masterpiece. The pilots feel fast and vicious. The titans feel beefy powerful. The balance in this game is amazing as well resulting in aggressive behavior being rewarded. The customization for each pilot and titan can result in wildly different play styles even on the same titan. I can't write enough kind words about this game and the dev team who kept pumping out FREE dlc
column2: new game modes
column3: and updates that always improved the game.";6.4;1.0;1.0;47.0;Posted: May 16

column2: full achievements in 6 minutes.

column1: Paying 6 bucks for this game was such a crime I paid another 6 bucks. It's a shame what happened to the game
column2: regardless of circumstances
column3: and I'd love to point fingers and say unpleasant things
column4: but it'll only fall on deaf ears.

column2: breakneck-paced
column3: exhilarating. Gunplay is satisfying
column4: TTK for Pilots is CS level low
column5: and speed is your weapon. Titans feel powerful and dominant
column6: but not overwhelming
column7: and they're not slow
column8: lumbering walking tanks. Adding in all the movement tricks available raises the skill ceiling to the moon (not that they're practical to use in MP).

column1: Graphics: 8/10. It's Source engine yada yada
column2: but it doesn't look old. Sure
column3: there might not be RTX and 4K textures
column4: and model clipping happens rather often
column5: but there's not a frame that takes you out of immersion. Models are well detailed. Animations are fluid and of excellent quality.

column1: Story: 7.7/10. It's a relatively cheesy story
column2: and some parts of it are debatable. Nonetheless
column3: it is paced quite well
column4: ramping up the tension alongside stage difficulty
column5: and ending in a sky-high climax. One of the oft-praised points about the story is the connection to the protagonist's Titan
column6: and how masterfully the connection is built throughout the story
column7: and I must agree.

column2: delightful sound effects
column3: distinguishable gun sounds
column4: skilled voice acting
column5: combined with capable sound mixing. The double jump jet sound will never fail to activate my neurons.

column1: You won't regret playing this game
column2: unless you have very heavy motion sickness. Just buy it on sale
column3: EA doesn't deserve this money
column4: then Google Titanfall 2 Northstar if you're interested in multiplayer.";10.3;1.0;3.0;84.0;Posted: May 17

column1: If mechs give you more than a passing interest

column4: you have a very competent but incredibly straightforward shooter that's focused on cloaking
column5: wall running

column7: and there are some other gimmicks in the story like time travel that make parkour interesting for like 3 minutes before you move on to something else. I left the game each time feeling like I mildly enjoyed it. It really has no flaws to speak of. It just doesn't do anything new or interesting. The mech combat is just ok. The parkour is just ok
column8: and the shooting is just ok. Other games of this caliber focusing on a single one of these aspects instead of all 3 at once will surely be better.

column2: to follow this up I want to go through why. I redownloaded Titanfall 2 Last night hoping to go have a good time with my friend: he convinced me to redownload so we can goof around in a 1 on 1 match where we'd beat the snot out of each other.

column1: I go through 3 hours of redownloading the game when I finally get to the menu. It should be a straight shot to the Multiplayer - even straighter of a shot considering that this would be a 1v1 between with a friend.
I am unable to access Multiplayer. I don't mean that the server list is empty
column2: I mean that I cannot press the Multiplayer button. I've spent over seven hours today just trying to find fixes to get around this issue. I've gone to a 6-Year-old forum post trying to find a fix to this issue. When that failed I decided to verify the game files
column3: hoping that it was still something that I might be able to fix without a heavy commitment on my part: I did that for a second time with no discernable effect.

column1: I decided to hell with it and uninstalled the game so that I could reinstall it
column2: wasting another 3 hours hoping to try and get it running again. I finally get back in and find that nothing had changed. By this point
column3: I download NorthStar hoping to circumvent the Respawn Servers
column4: which did fix a few issues: Namely finally getting the game to register it was connected to servers
column5: and allow for the information that would display on the righthand side of the menu screen to reappear.

column1: It didn't do a thing. Multiplayer is still locked out for me
column2: and I am stuck in an infinite search for the Respawn Servers. I hate this. I shouldn't have to be expected to run loops just to get my own game working just so I can play a match that at most would likely last 33 Minutes. What I hate most about all of this is that I LOVE this game: I've played through the campaign around six times already
column3: and I have nearly all of the achievements for this game - and on top of that while trying to wait to see if the servers would show themselves I decided to play it again
column4: getting halfway through it as of the time of this writing.

column1: I'm just frustrated that this game: which I know was working prior to me uninstalling the game for space
column2: will let me access the Multiplayer perfectly well. I also know that as of late the game servers have been under attack by petty vindictive manchildren who are incapable of having any agency or power in their own lives and have turned to DDOSing the servers to deny anyone the ability to play.

column1: I am fairly certain that the servers I'm a part of are not undergoing a DDOS attack: I've been checking the Steam Forums and Reddit Forums for solutions all day and I haven't seen any indication of a server-wide attack denying people access to the Multiplayer.
I hate what I've done here in making this review
column2: but I feel it's warranted for the time being: if you go ahead and decide to buy this game I really hope you don't regret it: I've gotten mostly nothing but enjoyment out of it all. However
column3: as of right now this issue has left nothing but a foul taste in my mouth.

column2: I do not recommend buying Titanfall 2 if you were hoping to play the Multiplayer
column3: in any capacity. For the current situation
column4: I'd only buy the game for its Campaign. I genuinely hope for the future that whatever it is that's causing this issue that appears to be affecting me is resolved.";41.4;0.0;0.0;112.0;Posted: May 21

column2: Even made me cry at the end.. Anyway here is a plant based pie recipe I think you will like

column1: A Proper (Vegan) Cornish Pasty with a flaky
column2: buttery
column3: rough puff pastry filled with tender veggies enveloped in a rich
column4: thick
column5: flavoursome sauce.

column2: peeled and diced into 1cm cubes
peeled and diced into 1cm cubes (yellow fleshed rutabaga)
chopped
peeled and diced

column1: 20g cornflour mixed with enough water to form a paste (approx 20ml)
Sift the flour and salt into a bowl.

column2: cut the vegetable shortening into small chunks into the bowl. Rub it loosely into the flour; you want to see chunks of shortening throughout
column3: you don’t want to work it into breadcrumbs.

column1: Make a well in the mixture and pour in the ice cold water. Mix it for a minute or two until you have a rough dough.
Cover your pastry and refrigerate it for 1 hour.

column2: turn it out onto a lightly floured surface and roll it in one direction until it is a rectangular shape
column3: roughly 20 x 50 cm. Don’t overwork the dough
column4: you want to have a marble effect with visible streaks of the vegetable shortening running through it.

column1: Position the dough rectangle in a portrait orientation in front of you.
Imagine the rectangle in thirds; fold the top third down to centre
column2: then fold the bottom third up over it. Please see the recipe video for a visual demonstration.

column1: Turn the dough a quarter turn to the left.
Roll it out to around three times its length and then fold it again as you did before - the top third over to the centre and then the bottom third up over it.
Cover the dough and place it back into the refrigerator for 1.5 hours.*** During this time you can cut up your veggies and make your gravy.
Combine the gravy ingredients into a small saucepan and whisk until it has reduced and become thick.

column2: take your gravy off of the heat and leave to cool. As it cools it will develop a jelly-like consistency which will make it easier to add to your pasties.

column1: Once your pastry has finished chilling for the final time
column2: roll it out
column3: fold it and turn it as you did before and then roll it to around 1cm thick and use a small side plate (approx 18 cm) as a guide to cut out four circles. If you want monster pasties
column4: use a dinner plate (approx 25cm) to cut out 2 large circles.

column1: Being careful not to overfill your pasties
column2: add your mixed vegetables on one half of each circle
column3: add three teaspoons of the cold gravy over the top of the vegetables (evenly spaced) and 2 teaspoons of dairy free margarine per pasty. Add six teaspoons of the gravy if you're making monster pasties.

column1: Brush a little water or dairy free milk around the edges of the pastry and fold it over. Crimp the edges by folding them over slightly. Please see the recipe video for a demonstration.
Cut three air holes in the top of each pasty and brush the top with the dairy free milk.
Put your pasties straight into the hot oven and cook for 40-50 minutes depending on the size you’ve decided to make. They should be ready when they are golden all over
column2: including the base. Be careful - they'll be very hot inside!";7.6;1.0;1.0;29.0;Posted: May 17

column1: Have you ever heard the tragedy... of Titanfall 2?
I thought not. It's not a story EA would tell you. Titanfall 2 was the greatest FPS game ever made
column2: so great in fact
column3: that Ubisoft would try and miserably fail to rip off its finely crafted advanced movement mechanics. However
column4: EA in their greed
column5: released the game right between CoD Infinite Warfare and Battlefield 1
column6: which ultimately led to its death
column7: gone unnoticed by millions of potential fans. Is it possible to play this game...?

column1: NOT FROM EA. The power of modding and third-party clients lead to many abilities some consider to be... UNNATURAL.

column2: I may as well go into more detail. In case it wasn't already clear
column3: Titanfall 2 has the best movement
column4: gunplay
column5: and level design in any FPS I've ever played. Unfortunately
column6: EA had no faith that this masterpiece would make them a mint
column7: and thus chose the least desirable release date
column8: essentially ruining TF2's chance at redemption from its mediocre predecessor
column9: Titanfall. Had it not been from this ruthless corporate betrayal
column10: this game would be so much more popular than it is right now.

column1: This led to the game being hacked to the point of it being borderline unplayable with constant DDOS attacks. Unfortunately
column2: Respawn has done nothing to fix this
column3: instead focusing entirely on Titanfall's slightly less handsome
column4: far more successful estranged cousin Apex Legends.

column2: this gem has gone relatively un-noticed
column3: and those who tried it were quickly turned away by the DDOS attacks and faulty servers. However
column4: regardless of the multiplayer issues
column5: the singleplayer Campaign still offers a truly magnificent experience for the 5-ish dollars when on sale. The story
column6: although simple
column7: works incredibly well thanks to great characters
column8: breathtaking worlds
column9: and mind-bending
column10: evolving level design featuring (but not limited to) parallel time travel
column11: convoluted moving platforms
column12: and ship-boarding action. Giving nothing away
column13: the ending is a real emotional roller-coaster of emotions.

column1: Though the official servers may be beyond hope
column2: there is a solution in the form of Northstar Client. This community-made mod bypasses all DDOS attacks and allows for countless possibilities for custom games
column3: ranging from classic CtF to Infection to some other cursed abominations dreamed up by programmers running entirely on straight caffeine. The downside to Northstar is that all progression is removed
column4: but the game options are debatably better than vanilla
column5: not to mention safe from deranged hackers.

column2: I have yet to play a game that runs and feels as great as this one. TF2
column3: like the other TF2
column4: runs on the Source engine
column5: meaning that basically any decent computer will be able to hit 60fps
column6: even with gorgeous graphics
column7: Movement is perfected
column8: and level design accommodates stunts
column9: shortcuts
column10: and speedroutes. With the intricate system of slides
column11: wall-runs
column12: grappling
column13: swinging
column14: and even bunny-hopping
column15: the skill ceiling for movement alone is extremely high. The progression system is fair
column16: where most guns and equipment can be unlocked relatively quickly
column17: but cosmetics will take a long time to completely unlock. There are microtransactions for special cosmetics
column18: but honestly I just want to throw money at this game so consider it more of a donation and less an exchange. Pilot loadouts offer many combos or strategies
column19: my personal favorite being a speed-oriented ability coupled with a completely random tactical ability to always keep opponents (and myself) on my toes.

column2: just trust BT-7274. He always knows best
column3: since he's done the math. And the math says that you WILL enjoy Titanfall 2.";8.7;1.0;0.0;20.0;Posted: May 20

column1: This game is really really great no lie is being told to ya gents but let me give ya a more detailed review
-the story mode is very short like a cod story but this game did really know how to make it great
the level design is the best thing to talk about in this game I f*ckin love it the story mode can be on the top 5 story games that Iv'e played
-multiplayer is fun once you know how to play but it's not only aim it's also movement jumping here and there and running on the walls is really making the multiplayer mode very great

-frontier defense this mode is like the survival mode in mw3 but it's way better more fun and no riot mofos in it instead there are grunts and the robot lookin things and some explosive spiders but let's not forget the titans which adds the action to it

column2: this shooter is a big pile of crack. Respawn really outdid themselves with the campaign
column3: introducing a movement system so fluid and clean it feels like butter. To chain wall-running to a double-jump
column4: back to a wall-run into a slide all while plugging enemies full of bullets feels great (especially in the last level). This really shines when you choose to play at an easier difficulty. It feels amazing to fly from enemy to enemy with ease. It all just flows. The hardest difficulty isn't that much of a pushover either. It forces you to play more defensively
column5: but there's plenty of times where the platforming will still shine. Just don't be surprised when you turn a corner and get blasted immediately bringing you back to the last checkpoint. The story itself was nothing special
column6: but it was very fun to play.

column2: basically doesn't exist. I shouldn't of had to
column3: but I was forced to download third party servers to play on. What little I played (for the time being) was very fun. Highly polished shooter with pilots flying around all over the place
column4: each of them insurmountably better than I.

column2: this has been driving me crazy for seven movies now
column3: and I know you're going to roll your eyes
column4: but hear me out: Harry Potter should have carried a 1911.

column1: Think about how quickly the entire WWWIII (Wizarding-World War III) would have ended if all of the good guys had simply armed up with good ol' American hot lead.

Basilisk? Let's see how tough it is when you shoot it with a .470 Nitro Express. Worried about its Medusa-gaze? Wear night vision goggles. The image is light-amplified and re-transmitted to your eyes. You aren't looking at it--you're looking at a picture of it.
Imagine how epic the first movie would be if Harry had put a breeching charge on the bathroom wall
column2: flash-banged the hole
column3: and then went in wearing NVGs and a Kevlar-weave stab-vest
column4: carrying a SPAS-12.

column1: And have you noticed that only Europe seems to a problem with Deatheaters? Maybe it's because Americans have spent the last 200 years shooting deer
column2: playing GTA: Vice City
column3: and keeping an eye out for black helicopters over their compounds. Meanwhile
column4: Brits have been cutting their steaks with spoons. Remember: gun-control means that Voldemort wins. God made wizards and God made muggles
column5: but Samuel Colt made them equal.

column1: Now I know what you're going to say: ""But a wizard could just disarm someone with a gun!"" Yeah
column2: well they can also disarm someone with a wand (as they do many times throughout the books/movies). But which is faster: saying a spell or pulling a trigger?
meet Avtomat Kalashnikova.

column1: Imagine Harry out in the woods
column2: wearing his invisibility cloak
column3: carrying a .50bmg Barrett
column4: turning Deatheaters into pink mist
column5: scratching a lightning bolt into his rifle stock for each kill. I don't think Madam Pomfrey has any spells that can scrape your brains off of the trees and put you back together after something like that. Voldemort's wand may be 13.5 inches with a Phoenix-feather core
column6: but Harry's would be 0.50 inches with a tungsten core. Let's see Voldy wave his at 3
column7: 000 feet per second. Better hope you have some Essence of Dittany for that sucking chest wound.

column1: I can see it now...Voldemort roaring with evil laughter and boasting to Harry that he can't be killed
column2: since he is protected by seven Horcruxes
column3: only to have Harry give a crooked grin
column4: flick his cigarette butt away
column5: and deliver what would easily be the best one-liner in the entire series:

column1: Well then I guess it's a good thing my 1911 holds 7+1.""
And that is why Harry Potter should have carried a 1911.";0.9;1.0;0.0;169.0;Posted: May 16

I don't even know where to begin with this game. As a grown man
column2: Red Dead Redemption 2 has hit me right in the feels
column3: and I feel like writing this review is part of the healing process for some of the emotions it put me through. I absolutely love this game
column4: it's a masterpiece.

column2: I'll fully admit that I'm late to the show. I was never a fan of Westerns or the 19th century as a setting
column3: but this game single-handedly changed all of it. The experiences I will detail here will be focused on my singleplayer / Story playthrough
column4: with a brief synopsis of online play. At the very bottom I'll include a tl;dr for those who just want a quicker review.

column1: I bought Red Dead Redemption 2 with no prior knowledge of the franchise and on a whim when I was going through a gaming dry spell around early winter in 2018. Right off the bat
column2: my opinion was that the game was designed with a console audience in mind
column3: but I tried it regardless. While the intro mission was impressive and the graphics were gorgeous
column4: I couldn't get into it
column5: grew impatient
column6: and had the game refunded.

column2: I saw the game on sale
column3: decided I had been too harsh
column4: and picked it up again. This time I played through the entire introduction and strove to acclimate myself to the clunky PC controls. Once it was over
column5: I didn't quite feel it
column6: so I uninstalled but kept the game
column7: this time with the promise that I'd eventually get around to playing it.

column2: I don't know what prompted it
column3: but two weeks ago I reinstalled and jumped back in. The controls were still frustrating and took time to get accustomed to
column4: but this time I gave the game the chance it deserved without letting my mood swings get in the way
column5: and it was then that I realized what a gem I had this whole time
column6: just gathering dust in my virtual library.

column1: Red Dead Redemption 2 puts you in the shoes of Arthur Morgan
column2: a character I had never heard of prior to getting into this series
column3: but I feel more connected to him than I have with any other character in a game
column4: outstripping my emotional investment in all the heroes and villains I've encountered in countless RPG's since the early 2000's. Arthur's journey is as raw and human as it gets and touches upon some existential questions such as the meaning of it all
column5: redemption
column6: family
column7: destiny
column8: and loyalty. The mundane
column9: slice of life details in the game from greeting strangers on the road
column10: hunting
column11: camping
column12: eating stew / drinking coffee
column13: providing for the gang
column14: and various other side activities aren't just there for fluff
column15: they're meant to help you live and breathe as Arthur Morgan and become him. Thus when the events that transpire further down the line come to pass
column16: you feel them as if you the player is going through it all
column17: not some pre-made fictional protagonist you happen to be controlling. I would love to say more
column18: but I don't want to spoil anything for anyone.

column1: Your choices in the game do matter
column2: as there are different endings depending on your conduct. I'm not going to tell you not to rush or take your time. Personally
column3: I felt a bit lost after the introduction and was thrown into this vast world of horses
column4: wild animals
column5: and a gigantic map to explore. It all feels very ""is this it?"" or ""What am I supposed to do now?"" at first if you don't bother with the story. Let it guide you
column6: and explore side activities in between
column7: you won't regret it. I found an early focus on story helped me feel more invested in it all
column8: then I took breaks to work on side activities and exploration.

column2: as you'd expect
column3: a vastly different experience. Regretfully
column4: there isn't a way to just play co-op with friends
column5: so you'll have to endure a world full of the typical crowd you'll often face online. It's kill or be killed
column6: and if you think ""I won't be a ♥♥♥♥
column7: I'll let this person go without bothering them""
column8: expect to get a bullet in the back of the skull once you turn your back. I found that the only way to get anything done in online is to shoot first
column9: ask questions later. Overall
column10: online play can be fun
column11: but it's a hollow imitation of the story mode
column12: and the fact that you can dump real life money into it to get ahead kinda spoils the need to grind and put in effort
column13: or maybe I'm just too old school and have a lower tolerance for that kind of thing at this point.

column1: - Clunky PC controls that take some getting used to and tweaking
- Amazing singleplayer experience. So many easter eggs to discover
column2: the game rewards completion

column1: - Dog eat dog online experience that doesn't do the game justice unless PvP is all you care about or you have friends to tag along with you
- Story will probably make you cry and make you fall in love with Westerns if they weren't your thing prior to this
- You may randomly start saying phrases like ""Ya hear?""
column2: ""My boah"" and ""You're arright girl"" in daily speech
column3: along with a testosterone boost and greater facial hair growth

column1: Imagine one of the better Telltale games. Their first Walking Dead maybe
column2: or perhaps Wolf Among Us. Now imagine that instead of being able to control all of the interesting choices you only controlled the walking around parts in-between. Then imagine the controls for those walking around parts were god-awful.

column1: If you want an ""on the range life"" simulator game then this is probably great for you. Otherwise the controls are sluggish
column2: restrictive
column3: and automated in a way that will screw you over multiple times. Regardless of your inputs the game has layers of automation that will change what you're doing: make you slower
column4: make you jump when you don't want
column5: change your loadout
column6: or kill your horse. The story is fine but it's no better than any old spaghetti western that already exists
column7: except this is extraordinarily ham-handed. Every mission
column8: every cutscene
column9: is extravagently and self-indulgently drawn out to absurd lengths for the content on display.

column1: Then to top it all it's still ridiculously buggy. My personal favorite bug came when I encountered a woman being kidnapped. I shot the kidnapper off of his horse
column2: causing the woman to fall. The process of the fall apparently caused the game to re-classify her as a witness to her kidnappers murder. This made me wanted for murder. I then went to free the woman. The act of freeing her caused the game to add me to the
column3: now empty
column4: role of kidnapper. This made me wanted for kidnapping. But not all of the bugs are grand and entertaining
column5: most are just small and frustrating.

column1: From what I can tell this game earned a good reputation as an ""on the range life"" simulator with good graphics. I cannot see how anyone could enjoy any other part of this mess.";30.2;0.0;0.0;167.0;Posted: May 23

column1: It's mostly a slow game when it comes to game play mechanics. Lots of driving around in carts
column2: horses etc
column3: but while doing so you also get to watch an incredibly beautiful landscape
column4: where each frame could potentially be a painting. Colours are amazing and the environmental effects are very well done. Stylistically this game is near perfect. Story wise it's quite empty and has not much to say
column5: except for some platitudes about the inevitable industrialization and the state owned authority on violence rather than the individual. I can't understand why this game make people emotional really. There is nothing much that resembles any real life connections between the characters. It's all just surface level relationships that are very cliched. The only time I felt this game made some sense to me was the home building sequence at the very end
column6: since all of a sudden the character realized he could be a master of his own fate
column7: rather than to follow a snake tongued leader (Dutch) that was duplicitous and cowardly. Basically the Wild West was a place for liars to tell lies about some future payoff with a big score when all they had to do was to settle down and stop pursuing impossible ideals . Grounding oneself ultimately is redemption.";71.7;1.0;0.0;229.0;Posted: May 22

I only recently had the chance to return to gaming in general (not having a decent pc and work/life got in the way). I should also say that I am in no way a ""wild-west"" enthusiast or ever have been an enjoyer of the genre/theme. This game
column2: is a slap in the face to the boundaries videogame history faced for the last 3 decades.

column1: Details and niche peculiarities of Red Dead Redemption 2 is off the charts
column2: it is absolutely incredible. I have no idea why in this day and age people nitpick to find smallest of imperfections in any videogame without realizing how far the industry has come and how immense amounts of work is being put into these games.
I don't like western style thematic or setting and I'm not very enticed by the whole appeal. The first Red Dead Redemption was also successful in the sense that even though you don't like the genre
column3: you find yourself playing through the game. Red Dead Redemption 2 is so exteremely talented in doing that due to its emphasis on characterisation. They are so fleshed out that you find yourself looking for more interactions
column4: curious about how each NPC will react at your camp or in a town to a simple ""GREET"" prompt.

column1: TL;DR: Buy it on 60% or more sale JUST for the story. Story is amazing and detailed. The Online mode is utter horseshyte and abandoned by R* (still plenty of players). Online has about 8 missions
column2: in total
column3: if you don't buy the Roles at 25 gold + 15 for the BH extra pass (There's 5 roles. That's 49.99 for 150 gold bar pack). Plus there's plenty of the customization content behind the gold paywall. It's designed
column4: just like GTAO
column5: to frustrate you into opening your wallet. Also
column6: y no Undead Nightmare?

column1: I recommend the story mode and DO NOT recommend the online mode. Story mode is beautiful
column2: albeit still buggy at times. Favorite part: Good Arthur is completely different from Bad Arthur. You even get completely new or different cut scenes and the world responds to Arthur differently. Story is really detailed. Still think the story in RDR1 is better
column3: and nothing touches Undead Nightmare.

column2: though. It has Gold as a real money currency you can buy
column3: or gain in game at a jokingly slow rate (0.1 - 0.4 per job/event/Dailies) but all the Roles (5 in total) cost 25 gold bars (that's 25.0
column5: and the Prestigious Bounty Pass is 15. That's 140 gold bars ($49.99 USD) to do ever Role
column6: which you know you will end up buying
column7: because there are like...8 missions for some lady trying to avenge her husband. That's it....8 f**king missions. There are no ""free"" versions of the Roles
column8: so that's online story content locked behind a paywall. BTW
column9: there are tons of clothing items and gun customization options that are paywalled
column10: as well. All this
column11: and zero property
column12: zero bank jobs or ""GTA heist-like"" content and zero criminal Roles in a game where the story mode is a western centered around gang life.

column1: A lot of the money making content is poorly designed. For instance
column2: if you're a trader and you do a long haul (which usually takes about 10-12 minutes to cross the map at full speed)
column3: you'll almost always come upon a shootout between 20ish badguys and two (F**king two) sellers defending themselves. If the two sellers die
column4: even if you are alive and kill everyone
column5: you lose everything in your cart. We won't even bring up why 20 douchebags need to attack two dudes with no valuables (because I haven't delivered them yet) and focus on the fact that you are literally still sitting on the full cart
column6: you can see the items are there and nothing is lost
column7: you can take it right back to camp
column8: but no
column9: they are all now lost in the attack and you have to go hunt all over again THEN wait on Crips to remake the cargo. Which btw
column10: supplies are now on a faster use rate (he burns through animal parts like 50 men are using them) and supply missions now give almost no bar fill.

column2: in typical ""big R* brain"" fashion
column3: the longer you wait to turn in missions
column4: the better your reward. The longer you hold on to a bounty target before dropping in a jail cell
column5: the more you get in cash
column6: XP and Gold. This promotes waiting as a tactic which adds extra risk of dying to other players (and GTAO/RDO players are scum of the earth and will kill you for existing) or the bounty getting away for whatever reason (they can slip their ties
column7: even in the more expensive bounty hunter rope). Any other game would pay you a bonus for getting jobs done early. This games online play is a grand example of R*'s terrible MTX practices and how most of their mechanics are designed to frustrate you into buying gold (or Shark Cards in GTAO) to speed up progression that's otherwise designed to make you wait for better results. These are all purpose designed frustration mechanics
column8: not immersion or realism details. To back this up
column9: you can change the currency type from in game dollars to gold on all weapons
column10: horses and clothing customization items if you don't have enough cash.

column1: I'd not be so mad if they still worked on the game and had more content
column2: but they pulled the RDO team for the abysmally bad GTAV Extended new gen release. Also
column3: unlike GTAO which gets semi regular content updates to this day
column4: this game seems to have been completely abandoned since Halloween 2021 and has about 1/20th the content of GTAO. So they lied about that ""we are 100% focused on RDO right now""
column5: especially when we were told it took ""2 years"" for them to do the new gen GTA. That's 2 years the RDO team was pulled from a project they were ""100% focused on"".";19.6;1.0;0.0;427.0;Posted: May 19

column1: BUY THIS GAME! I'll tell you why:
1. Level of detail. Within' this game the level of detail that portrays across the entire game is amazing. Every single animal has it's own role and life. For instance
column2: eagles swoop and kill prey
column3: coyote's kill in packs and socialise
column4: rams fight for mating rights by clashing their horns
column5: birds coordinate together and fly with one another and so much more. Every animal is capable of something and that's amazing. The landscape
column6: everything moves
column7: 90% of everything is interactive
column8: it's like nothing I've ever seen.

column1: 2. The Storyline. The story is truly amazing and lasts more than 80 hours upon full completion
column2: I'll not ruin it
column3: but I will say you'll never regret learning the story of the main characters! One thing I love is there's no rush
column4: you never have to instantly do a quest unless you started one already
column5: you can relax whilst in story mode and make your own path
column6: story can always be secondary.

column1: 3. Gamemodes. I'm very glad that not only can you play a single player storyline with a full fledged amazing story
column2: but you can also play online with all your friends with a whole different story!

column1: 4. Your decisions matter. Unlike other games
column2: your decisions can actually matter depending on the quest
column3: which I find really cool
column4: you can decide if you want to try keep a good reputation or a bad one
column5: stealing or helping
column6: etc.

column1: 5. No Harsh Death. In the game
column2: when you die
column3: you'll mostly just lose whatever is on your horses back which is very helpful and it takes stress off of you if you're carrying valuable items and die in storyline.

column1: 6. Keep Coming Back. I can't stop playing the game
column2: every time I log on I have tons and tons to do and I never end up getting bored
column3: I play all day for hours on end on storyline and if I ever get bored of it
column4: there's a whole other world in online mode!

column1: 7. Variety. There are roughly 60 horse coats and patterns for you to find as well as 19 horse breeds in total! Whatever your riding vibe is
column2: you'll find your match. There are around 200 different species of animals to hunt and observe
column3: each with their own life and their extremely high-tech coding means they do everything naturally. Sometimes it's so amazing
column4: I saw two wolf packs standing off
column5: muskrat and beavers along side each other like in reality
column6: dams
column7: so much more. And TONS of items
column8: craftables
column9: etc.

column1: 8. Overall. This has only been a TINY bit of the world in Red Dead Redemption 2. The amount of worlds and the HUGE MAP is amazing. This game deserves all it's credit
column2: and all my appreciation. 100% buy this if you have the chance
column3: it's a bit pricey
column4: but it's definitely worth it. I couldn't price it any less
column5: it's so amazing.

column1: 9. Rivals. The game that will most likely rival RD2 is either Microsoft Flight 2020 or Forza 5. Each have their own unique beautiful game graphics and mechanics. I think RD2 is above them
column2: because of the amount of detail it possesses.

column1: 8. Dislike. The only thing I dislike about this game is that in online mode you can't make a solo session. Which is odd considering Rock Star made a solo session option for GTA 5 but not this. It may happen
column2: who knows.

I would recommend this Outlaw video game to people who have good taste. In a world of hunt or be hunted this games story mode brings you through a vast open landscape with many obstacles. INCLUDING FENCES BRICK WALLS AND THE RANDOM ROCKS IN THE MIDDLE OF THE WOODS. But once you get past all of that you go through a crazy story that has ups and downs. It takes you anywhere from the snow on top of mountains to dry deserts
column2: and even swamps full of animals hiding to scare your horse into throwing you off of it and running away leaving you by yourself facing mother nature while looking it into the eye. column1: If you liked the first game chances are you'll like this too. The open ocean has been broken up by icebergs and fragmented into caves underground
column2: and land gameplay has been improved (a substantial portion of the game takes place on land).
inventory management
column3: and resource-gathering all remains virtually identical to the previous game
column4: so it's familiar to returning players and simple enough for newcomers. Warning for old players looking for the same experience:

column1: Base-building is still fun and there have been some improvements
column2: however a mod is still required for snapping buildings and objects onto a grid system.

column1: The story they try to tell falls a little flat
column2: as I felt the best part of Subnautica was never the story but moreover the sense of loneliness and drive to explore.

column1: Scariness? Subnautica had so many moments that had me jump in my seat but Below Zero's fauna really felt tame compared to the original. Frankly
column2: the scariest part of the game is the desperation of searching for an oxygen plant while deep into a cave system.

column1: Overall I would recommend this game to anyone who enjoyed the first
column2: and even if you spend full price these devs are working hard to make the third entry in the series even better than both before
column3: and deserve our support

column1: I would pay $30 again for Subnautica. I somewhat regret paying $15 for below zero.
Everything is worse than the original. I bought on sale and it was arguably worth it
column2: but I found myself wanting to play the first one again about halfway through.

column1: The story is cool enough but the writing is terrible. Dialogue feels canned and corny. There are characters who receive varying levels of development and I found myself most interested with the ones who had the least. I realized this was because I wanted want the original game offered - a sense of mystery.

column2: there is NO sense of mystery in this game. Each ""discovery"" is bookended with dialogue from two characters who
column3: should by all accounts
column4: be interesting... but they're not.

column2: environments are worse
column3: map layout is WAY worse. in the original game I found myself quickly memorizing landmarks and shortcuts between biomes. In this game they simply don't exist. Virtually every sea cave is a walled garden. This makes navigating to specific resources overly tedious and betrays any feeling the environment you're exploring is organic.

column2: if you loved the first game
column3: and this is on sale
column4: then buy. If you're torn between this and the original
column5: go for Subnautica Classic.";33.3;0.0;2.0;181.0;Posted: 17 May

column1: I've taken the opposite approach to this game compared to the original Subnautica. Before
column2: I bought Subnautica in early access and absolutely spoiled everything about the game for myself. I loved the game and atmosphere so much that when any new information came out I would eat it up. For Below Zero
column3: I purposely ignored it though out it's entire development
column4: so I would go in completely blind. Now that I've played through it fully
column5: I can say that there are obvious improvements
column6: but overall
column7: I would say that I enjoyed this game less than the first.

column1: I would say that this game is better visually
column2: in pacing and with quality of life improvements. Overall however
column3: I find that this game has a lot less to offer. The map itself is noticeably smaller
column4: and has a major issue. There are huge landmasses in this game that are an absolute slog to get through. When you're in the water
column5: you can move freely and explore in all directions. It's very liberating and fun to do. In this game
column6: there is less of that
column7: AND you are forced to run around a boring white island for hours that has barely anything of interest. This is the worst part of the game. You feel very restricted
column8: and even with a floating cycle upgrade
column9: exploring the maze of caves just to find way too many materials to hold is so unsatisfying it ruins the game.

column1: The music also lacks the fear inducing ambience the original had. It feels more generic.

column2: I feel the ambience and isolation that the first game was known so well for is lost due to kinda interesting characters that mostly overcrowd this game with unneeded exposition. Your companion is a little too generic and overdone
column3: with the whole ""trying to understand humans thing."" Also your main character speaks all the time
column4: which removes all feelings of being stranded. Some games work better with a silent protagonist
column5: and Subnautica is one of them.

column2: I really enjoyed the quality of life updates. Like the better crafting and the much needed PRAWN suit improvements. However
column3: I still feel this game lacked a major piece of the originals atmosphere and mystery. I give it a 5/10
column4: but I can still recommend it if you enjoyed the first and are wanting more.";27.9;1.0;2.0;60.0;Posted: 21 May

Watching other reviews I was expending this to be a worse game than the original but I underestimated how bad it compares to the original.

It is not a terrible game by any means but it somehow managed to improve on things that either unimportant or that make the experience worse while keeping the core experience literally the same. It's like an expansion that makes the game worse.
- the story. some broad strokes change but in essence it stays the same.
- survival elements (now you have to manage low temperatures as well. woweee)
- Voice acting with varying quality. Did it need it? Not really
- The dialogues. The less said about these the better because they ruin the experience almost single-handedly.

column2: pictures and useless items to craft. There is only one useful addition the Quantum container and that is pretty much taken from mods.

column1: - New biomes and a couple of different creatures that fulfill pretty much the same roles as the originals.
- The ice worm which looks menacing but it's actually more dangerous to your vehicle than you.
- 2 new vehicles and one removed. The snow fox sounds cool but controls awful.
Aaaaand that is pretty much it. The ending is so bad it hurts while mechanically being the same slog as the original.
TLDR: Buy the original and skip this one.";25.6;0.0;1.0;186.0;Posted: May 20

column1: This game isn't even close to as good as the first one. The biodiversity is practically non existent. I would say there are less then 10 unique species. The leviathans are boring. They are literally everywhere
column2: and they are never an actually threat. The only thing you lose when they attack you is a minute of your time. This will happen constantly.

column1: The maps are ugly and hard to explore. I had to use a YouTube video every step of the campaign
column2: because everything is purposely hidden away. Remember
column3: when the first game encouraged you to go forward? This game will only let you move forward if you find specific resources in remote hard to reach corners of the map
column4: with no indication that they are their. Again
column5: I had to use online guides for everything. If you want to progress the story you have to navigate the repetitive hallways filled with leviathans that hide were you are supposed to go or even any indication that you are going in the right direction.

column1: The story is bland and progression is so hard to progress that I didn't really care by the end of it. Ex: One of the characters asks you to find them on an iceberg in a field of icebergs. The only hint is that they are around 1 km west of you. That doesn't limit you search at all
column2: so you can spend an hour or two looking or just consult an online video.

I do not recommend this game. I have recommended the first one tentatively in the past because of the environment storytelling and open world exploration aspects (the soundtrack for the first game is dope AF as well)
column2: but warned against level of resource grind and god awful movement scheme for the vehicles. This game has less of that
column3: is shorter as well
column4: but ultimately has a number of flaws that are unacceptable for me.

column2: the devs STILL don't know how to make a stable piece of software that doesn't crash every ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ 10 minutes. This may be the first issue you encounter. I say may
column3: because others have told me that they haven't experienced any problems
column4: or very few at least. Yet others still have agreed with me that they can barely have a decent length game session. Save files can and do corrupt and back ups of your save need to be made to preserve any kind of progress.

column2: is the utterly horrible design decision with the ice worms towards the end of the game. This part alone is what's brought me to abandon my playthrough of this game. Massive worms that can sense any and all movement on the surface of the ice fields that you must cross to advance the story. You CANNOT skip this. You are soft locked out of completing the game is you try to skip it. The mechanic of having to navigate the ice worms itself isn't the issue (think sand worms from Dune
column3: because the devs certainly were). It's the implementation. They provide you with a thumper
column4: a craftable device that you spike into the ground (kinda like what you see in Dune) to distract the ice worm. Only these thumpers have an 80 metre range and once you move beyond that range you are attacked by yet another ice worm. It is also possible to get stun locked. If you move
column5: you're attacked. If you don't move you can't progress. This would be fine if the tools given to you to tackle this problem actually worked. But they don't. It is clearly possible to complete the game because others have
column6: however it seems more a test of patience rather than ingenuity on the part of the player. Hard pass for me.

column2: movement speed underwater has been lowered. What in the name of every deity ever conceived by humanity were the devs thinking? Smooth movement and a decent level of speed is ESSENTIAL for first person games. In the first game you would glide around effortlessly which made the underwater world exploration a joy to experience (when using the seaglide or the seamoth). Now you're slower and possibly there's more inertia. You get used to it
column3: but it's still terrible.

column2: the vehicles suck dog nads. The first game had the seamoth (a tiny submarine that was like a space ship which you can zip around in fluidly - 10/10); the prawn (a cumbersome mech that walked on the ocean floor and relied on jump jets and a grappling hook for scaling high areas - 7/10); and finally the cyclops (an impressive looking submarine that many people turned into a mobile base
column3: but had god awful controls - 5/10) They all make sense within the context of the game despite my distaste for the last two. However
column4: in this game you get the seatruck (a replacement for the seamoth AND cyclops that is a modular 'train') and the prawn. You know how I feel about the prawn (oh
column5: and I barely got to use the damn thing). The seatruck... sigh... The cabin part is
column6: well
column7: it's fine. Just fine. It does what it says on the box
column8: except you can't fit it in places that it looks like it should fit. The collision box is wonky at best and you'll find yourself clipping things ALL THE TIME. As you add more modules onto the cabin section you'll slow the vehicle down. Understandable
column9: but SSSSSSLLLLLOOOOOWWWWW! Meaning
column10: unless you can tolerate moving at a glacial pace
column11: you'll be fine modding out your seatruck to your heart's content. But if you actually want to get ♥♥♥♥ done because
column12: you know
column13: you have a life to live
column14: then good luck.

Original Subnatica is one of my most favorite games of all times. It was appearent that the follow up game would have it difficult as succeding the original was a tough task.

I didnt manage to finish this game. At one point I just gave up and rather restarted original Subnatica. I will still buy Subnautica 3 when it comes out. But Subnautica: Bellow Zero is simply a downgrade story wise and gameplay wise over the original game.

column2: there are some nice things. Graphic is bit better
column3: the new vehicle that replaced Cyclops was kind of fun
column4: although I miss my Cyclops. Some quality of life improvements were done. Not sure if all are for the better but generally yes.

column1: The negative side is certainly the world or map whatever you call it. Its way more streamlined and limited exploration wise. I didnt enjoy the ground part much either.
The story and overall feeling of the game cannot be even compared with the original. Original game story was so simple (you crash
column2: try to survive and escape) and yet so much better. The atmosphere of the first game is in different league. In my first gameplay of Subnautica I felt totally absorbed
column3: I was stressed about unknown and dangers that might be there somewhere (Subnatica did excellent job creating a sense of danger where in reality was very little of it if you were focused).

column2: worth playing. Not as good as the first one
column3: but it's hard to live up to the immaculate vibes of the first game- especially when you've already experienced the vibes before.

column1: I wish the game would have done more to distinguish itself further from the first
column2: maybe by leaning even further into the story aspect
column3: but even just re-skinning the core game content would have done wonders to at least make you feel like you were doing something different from the first game. Too much just felt like a re-hash of things. I believe the original intention was for it to be a DLC for the first game
column4: and it definitely shows. At least the core game content is already solid in the first place
column5: so this doesn't feel too bad.

column1: The game was definitely shorter (once again
column2: makes sense if it was to be a DLC originally). Part of it was that I'm already a seasoned Subnautica veteran
column3: so I sorta knew my limits and could progress more quickly than I otherwise would be able to
column4: but the game itself was also smaller. Not a bad thing on its own- small games can leave huge impacts when done right- but I feel like they could have made this smaller package pack a bigger punch.

column1: This point might just be me
column2: but I found myself getting lost a lot more than in the first game. Not lost in a good way
column3: like ""oh no I'm on an ocean planet and I wandered too far from my base and now I'm in the middle of nowhere and it's scary""
column4: but more like ""okay I just did this story thing and now I have no idea what the game wants me to do next"". There were several occasions where I actually had to google what to do next
column5: and I'm not the kind of guy who likes reading walkthroughs. The game is sometimes overly-cryptic on what it wants you to do
column6: often vaguely referencing something in some voice line and hoping that you were listening and that you picked up on it and will then go and find whatever they were talking about. I'm all for not holding the player's hand too much and letting them figure things out for themselves
column7: I love the sense of discovery and accomplishment from games who do this right
column8: but things also have to be done in such a way that roadblocks are infrequent and surmountable.

column1: Now that was a lot of criticising
column2: but like I said it's still a good game
column3: just not a very unique one. The first one had a certain magic to it that I felt was missing from this iteration in the franchise
column4: but it was still an enjoyable experience all things considered. I would love to see another installment in the Subnautica universe someday
column5: and I'm once again hoping that the devs embrace the fact that they likely won't be able to capture the exact same feeling of lonesome mystery of the first game
column6: and instead work hard on other aspects of the game to really expand the story.";22.6;1.0;0.0;225.0;Posted: May 23

Subnautica: Below Zero is a spin-off sequel to Subnautica
column2: and like the first game its an open-world survival game with an ocean setting. You play as Robin Ayou
column3: a biologist who travels to Planet 4546B to find more info about the death of her sister Sam. Despite taking place at the same planet as the first game
column4: the region is different
column5: and like the title
column6: many locations are arctic-like
column7: with big icebergs
column8: frozen islands and all that.

column1: The game looks and plays almost the same as the first one. You collect resources and craft items
column2: while exploring points of interests and doing objectives. Most of the gear you have are the same
column3: with some new additions. And for the sea creatures
column4: almost all of them are different
column5: the only exceptions being those small
column6: edible fishes. However
column7: the most notable change is the land biome. On some edges of the map
column8: you have to explore the snowy islands. These are quite large compared to the islands in the first game. But worry not
column9: for you can craft a land vehicle and a cold-resistant suit. Sadly
column10: it seems that the game has less variations of sea biomes compared to the first one.

column2: the game is quite shorter than the first one
column3: around half of it
column4: but involves more characters instead of you being alone. You can even find some audio logs from previous visitors with character portraits. Crafting is also somewhat less demanding
column5: as you can finish the game with the basic Seatruck upgraded only with depth modules
column6: the other vehicles and parts are optional. I'm not really a fan of hunting rare ingredients
column7: especially in a game with no clear map and fast travel
column8: so in a way it is kinda preferable.

column1: While I like the stronger story and the involvement of more characters which makes the world feel alive
column2: the sad thing is that many parts of the story can be skipped. While Robin's reason for being there is to investigate the death of her sister
column3: it is treated like a sidequest
column4: and you can actually escape the planet
column5: finishing the game without even learning a bit about what happened to her if you don't explore the abandoned Alterra bases. I think it would be better if the game forces and leads us to those locations
column6: maybe add beacon signals since they are kinda hard to find. For a game with an objective other than to escape
column7: it just seems weird that it can be ignored and have the backstory progression mixed up
column8: like how I found Sam's last log before her earlier ones.

column2: I think Subnautica: Below Zero is just as good as the first game
column3: stronger in some parts yet weaker in others
column4: but I kinda like this a bit more due to the appearance of more characters. If you already played the first game and enjoyed it
column5: there's no reason to not play this game because it looks and plays almost the same
column6: and you will already be familiar with the mechanics. If you're looking for exploration survival games with a beautiful artstyle
column7: you should try the Subnautica games
column8: but try the first one before this.";23.4;1.0;0.0;416.0;Posted: May 21

column1: After finally finishing Subnautica I was excited to see the sequel. I've yet to finish Below Zero but the story and gameplay has been phenomenal. There are a few plot holes like how some fish have adapted to the cold environment of Planet 4546-B only 2 years later when it should take them 1 million years to adapt to 1°C. The terrain doesn't line up with Subnautica and either I haven't found them or the Degasi Habitats are absent. However
column2: I think this is actually good since we get the opportunity to see new environments and creatures. So far the story has been compelling and it always leaves me curious for whats next. The creatures are very creative but the scare factor isn't there since I already got over the large creatures in the first game. The execution of the story has been great
column3: it put me under conditions that gave the mystery of the game an ominous aura. The idea of the Seatruck was great and very creative
column4: but it's a bit of a recycled idea from the cyclops in the first game. There's a lot more I could talk about but I don't want this review to get too long so I think I should stop here. Overall great game
column5: but so far not as good as the first Subnautica.";130.0;1.0;0.0;57.0;Posted: May 21

column2: no need. Since there is no real need or insentive to build deep bases youll end up with just your main base which is at the surface. no real need)

column1: Though I love subnautica I was deeply dissapointed. The map is much smaller and I expected more from the surface exploration part of the game. The sea truck is a beatiful edition to this game Vs. the cyclops and it was needed too. The cyclops would not work on this far too small map.

column1: Below zero is obviously the sequel to Subnautica but it has a very different fell to the first game. It is a lot more story based and more colourful with less of a sense of being alone. It isn't bad it's just different in the gameplay

and feel. I really like lots of the additions to the mechanics and things i quite like. One of the things i felt was that it didn't have as clear of a progression as the first game but i think that's just me. It can occasionally have the feel of being like a test game but other times it is just as immersive as the original Subnautica. All in all a very good game and i highly recommend to play after the first game but don't expect it to be exactly the same as the first game. It is different but just as good in a different way.";35.3;1.0;0.0;10.0;Posted: May 19

column1: We Were Here Forever is a great 2 player online co-op puzzle game that relies on communicating with your partner.
Best part of the series yet! The storytelling has been improved with cinematics. While there is an overarching story
column2: this game works as a standalone because the focus on the story is about setting the mood for the next puzzle. The puzzles are less abstract
column3: more intuitive and there are more of them. This doesn't mean they became easy
column4: there will still be plenty of moments where you are stuck trying to figure out a puzzle
column5: but they won't be as frustrating to solve. As usual
column6: the puzzles work by exchanging information with each other and figuring them out with logic
column7: some of which reset after a few attempts or by the timer running out.

column1: The game currently has some issues that should be easily fixed. At the end of the octopus puzzle
column2: I was still stuck in the chair while my partner could progress to the next puzzle. Loading up the save for the next puzzle gave a black screen to whoever was hosting. Luckily we could work around this by replaying the octopus puzzle because of the nice chapter select. In some of the bigger puzzles
column3: the FPS takes a big hit
column4: not just on my mediocre PC
column5: but on my partner's beefy PC as well.

column2: this is a fun time
column3: it's more and better!

column1: Play the game from both sides and reach both endings
column2: has a chapter select. If one of you has a weaker PC
column3: make sure your partner is loaded in the game or you'll have to replay that part for the achievement to pop.";12.6;1.0;15.0;3141.0;Posted: 19 May

column3: story and map design yet. One of the best puzzle games out there.";13.2;1.0;3.0;95.0;Posted: 18 May

column1: My friend and I love we were here and we were here together
column2: but this game falls short for us. We experienced almost no bugs (besides the ski-lift) and still didn't enjoy our time. The puzzles feel like they're either 1 guy with all the info
column3: or both players with all the info
column4: instead of an even split that would support communication like with other games in the series. Also can't stand how slowly the game gets at some points
column5: especially the slow long treks back and forth between areas.";8.2;0.0;22.0;54.0;Posted: 16 May

column2: just disappointing. I won't call it bad - you've got your two player puzzling and it works - but for the final(?) game in the series
column3: the one with the longest development time and the one with the highest price tag
column4: it feels a big step backwards from its predecessors.

column1: It's hard to nail down exactly why
column2: but I think it feels too tame
column3: as if they approached this one with the mindset of really making a commercial game (the original was a student project IIRC)
column4: and were worried of scaring away players. There's no tension of having to solve a puzzle before you die to some encroaching hazard (increasingly-panicked chatter on the walkie talkies that can't both receive and transmit at the same time was genuinely one of my favourite parts of the previous games)
column5: and the puzzles are so self-contained - no more running around trying to figure out what you should be doing
column6: instead you're typically sealed in a small area with only the puzzle elements
column7: leaving the experience feeling overly-curated. ""Here's the next puzzle
column8: solve it using these parts
column9: goes the game
column10: ""I'll be waiting to escort you to the next puzzle.""

column2: the puzzles themselves feel worse than in the previous games. Too many of the puzzles have both players simultaneously interacting with the same elements
column3: leading to most of them ending with one person figuring it out and dictating everything to the other player. They feel more like single-player puzzles where the second player only exists to physically enter their half of the solution and maybe answer specific questions about details you know are there but can't see the exact details of.

column1: The few asymmetrical puzzles beyond that seem to blitz through the interesting asymmetrical puzzle solving and go straight to the execution. Rather than collaboratively working out a solution you tend to see what you're supposed to do straight away followed by however much time of just repeating information back and forth
column2: or worse one player is left really bored as their half just has so much less to do.
the asymmetrical part of the co-op puzzle solving was what made the series unique
column3: and to see it stray away from that feels like they've squandered what made the games what they are.

column1: The game's longer than the older ones. There's more story as well
column2: which may be hit-or-miss. I couldn't care less for it as it was the series's mechanics that held my interest
column3: but the friend I played through them with was interested in the story. Either way
column4: the individual puzzle quality has suffered for both. There were a couple I came out of thinking 'that one was pretty decent'
column5: but there's nothing memorable in there.

column1: As I said at the start
column2: I can't outright call it bad
column3: but the development time and the price point both set expectations that the game consistently failed to meet. For half the price I likely would have been satisfied with the experience
column4: but at full price it's just too bland.";11.5;0.0;17.0;276.0;Posted: 18 May

column1: We Were Here Forever the final(?) entry in the series has finally launched but is it as good as the previous ones? No
column2: it's much better! It's a fantastic puzzle-focused coop game and we need more.

column1: -Minor bugs that made us restart an entire chapter.
-Some puzzles like the final one were super easy.
If you played the previous ones
column2: you know there's some story about a king and how he did some bad things and some jester but it never made much sense. Luckily the story finally becomes much more focused and clear as there are finally story cutscenes with dialogue and everything.

column1: You are back at Castle Rock trying to go through the Jester and King's endless puzzles but this time something changes. You manage to escape and find yourselves outside the castle where you find the plans of some rebel families that stood up to the King. I won't spoil more but this time around it feels like there's some actual lore behind everything as well as a proper ending
column2: well except for one minor thing which I did not like at the end. Don't think there was an alternative to it.
this is not some story that will blow your mind or make you emotional
column3: the series was never about that
column4: but I appreciated that they did gave us something better than previous games in this regard.

column2: We Were Here Forever is a coop puzzle-focused adventure game where you and your partner have to progress through really tough puzzles in order to escape Castle Rock and its vicinities.

column1: You'll have parts where you can switch back and forth puzzles with your partner which helps in figuring out certain puzzles but there are also parts where you are both stuck on your selected side and you'll have to coordinate via voice on how to advance forward.
Most puzzles will require you both to really think hard but there are a few such as the final one where they are extremely easy. The last puzzle was a bit disappointing
column2: I was expecting something much more with an ompfh. Overall as I don't want to spoil you with what the game will throw at you in terms of puzzles
column3: there are going to be some path-blocking ones
column4: there's a cooking simulator one
column5: and so many more. They are all unique and different from each other
column6: not once will you get bored. There's also a hint system tho it's mostly useless as it only tells you how to start figuring out the puzzles which anyone with an average IQ will do.

column1: Fun and tough game and I'm curious what the devs can cook up next
column2: assuming they'll still do coop/puzzle games. It's a rare genre so more is always welcome. Perhaps something sci-fi next time such as Portal 2 coop?
voice acting
column3: finally you won't have to look at weird cutscenes without a voice and surprisingly it's really well acted.

column2: no complaints here
column3: and I loved that there was a music type of puzzle as well as one with figuring out words out of sounds. Really well done.

column2: the sound effects such as the atmospheric ones and whatever else are generally quite good
column3: no complaints.

column1: I'll start with the bad real quick which were some bugs that forced us to restart an entire chapter but the devs said it had to do with servers so who knows. There were other minor ones as well but nothing worth talking about.
What's really impressive this time around is the scope of the levels and their design. Long gone are the days of small rooms with puzzles
column2: this time around everything around you feels masterfully crafted like a huge metroidvania-like map filled with puzzles
column3: minus the backtracking. The way the levels and the puzzles are placed and how they work well with each other is perfect. They outdid themselves and I can't wait for what they do next.

column2: it's a bit iffy at times
column3: frames can drop even on a high-end pc to 50s but overall it runs smooth.

column2: performance and tech analysis score: 8/10

column1: If you're a fan of the series then I don't have to tell you to go buy it and if you're new I suggest playing them all tho not mandatory since We Were Here Forever can be easily played even as your first game.";14.4;1.0;5.0;564.0;Posted: 21 May
We Were Here Forever was an extremely fun game to play through but in comparison to the previous game in the series
column2: I'm not sure it lived up to expectations.

column1: Most of the puzzles were unique and fun to solve. Some of them required a decent amount of thinking while others you needed good team coordination/communication. There was one puzzle that we thought was troublesome. Maybe we're just stupid but we thought the clues provided weren't very clear. Also it was the first time we used the ""Hint"" feature in the game and they were literally the most useless things ever. One of them was ""try to use deduction if you don't know where to place these"". Yeah thanks for telling me a basic human problem solving skill.
Personally I found some of the puzzles kind of boring. It just felt for a few of them that 1 person didn't have much to do.
The story was decent. Just the same stuff that's been going on the past few games. It does go more into depth of what's happening but I didn't care much for it.

The biggest problem in the game for us was all the waiting. They make you ride on like a snow lift multiple times that takes a solid like 20-30 seconds for no reason except the 1 time there was a cut scene. There are other instances too where it just takes too long for the game to take you through a pointless ride.
The graphics were great and a step up from the previous game. Soundtrack was fine
column2: didn't really stand out at all. I only encountered one bug where I couldn't see the images on the buttons I was pressing. Quick restart fixed it though.

column1: The final puzzle of the game was super easy. I'm pretty sure this is the last game in the series and for a final puzzle that sucked. Nearly every other puzzle was more difficult than the final one and kinda disappointed.

column2: it was still an extremely fun game and I do think it's worth full price.";15.7;1.0;4.0;495.0;Posted: 20 May
