column1: Me and my partner played the first 3 games together
column2: and then realised the fourth one was releasing soon
column3: we knew we had to get the completionist on the first three before smashing out this one. We were so pumped to get this game the second it came out
column4: and how could we resist that juicy 10% off sale?

column2: I will not lie has been a buggy mess
column3: and it was especially worse when there was no Australian servers for the first few days. However the devs were really onto it and fixed everything as soon as they could
column4: I know my partner wasn't taking any of the ♥♥♥♥ the first few days but then we both realised something in our hearts. We are the smartest
column5: and the funniest
column6: and the best
column7: and the only ones who should be together in such desperate measures.

column1: The best part about smashing out a game so early is that there is no walkthrough
column2: meaning that everything we did was legitty on our titties
column3: which leads me to believe that our brain patterns have been altered
column4: what if we are both genetically engineered to begin with?

column1: I remember playing the first game several times and not knowing about how deep the lore actually went
column2: but when my partner came along for the first time
column3: the one I was destined to be with
column4: I just knew that the one I had been waiting for had finally come
column5: and I opened my eyes for the first time to see how good the lore actually is. As I write this review
column6: I know my partner wants more of this
column7: whether its part of the same series or not
column8: as long as we keep getting more.

column1: I have a bad feeling however that this is the last game of the We Were Here series
column2: they say that all good things must come to an end
column3: however I do know one thing is for sure. This door closes for me
column4: but it has made way for another one to open
column5: the path that I must walk with my partner. And I know that I definitely won't be treading off this path
column6: no matter how long it is I will always stand by my partners side
column7: this series has prepared us for the toughest obstacles that we can now face on our own.

column1: I was asked several times by a few of my friends
column2: ""Who is this mysterious partner you keep referring to? And why are they so perfect?"" Perhaps one day I may reveal this partner
column3: however all I can say for now
column4: is that my partner was a very unlikely one
column5: and that I would have never foreseen being with them like this.

column1: Just the thought of me and my partner having been through so much together
column2: seeing each other leave one behind
column3: as one of us turns our backs and keeps walking
column4: getting separated and coming back to each other. I do know that if I was ever met with a choice similar to the series in the real world
column5: I know what I would pick. But I would not think of them as the ""Worst Friend Forever"". After all
column6: I was always first to get left behind or die each time
column7: and I don't plan on changing the outcome.

column1: All that matters to me is my partners happiness
column2: but how can I make someone happy when they are faced with such a difficult choice? If the time ever comes
column3: I hope that my partner will understand what I have done
column4: and that everything I did was to make this special someone happy. I do know that our ups heavily outweigh our downs
column5: and that is enough for me. I sleep easy at night knowing that the choices I have made for my partner will keep a smile on their face.

column1: To think that in the little time I had with my partner
column2: it feels like we have known each other for years
column3: decades
column4: centuries
column5: hell even eons. There will always be a place in my heart for my partner
column6: whether we drift apart in the future
column7: or if we end up staying together. I know damn well that I prefer the latter of that sentence
column8: but I will keep this up as a memory
column9: so that I may never forget the amazing times I had with my partner. We will tell everyone indeed that We
column10: Were
column11: Here.

column1: Not all the puzzles are balanced. Spent half the game describing symbols while the other person does almost everything/the majority of the puzzling. By this I mean that one person has all the info and the other person just follows orders blindly. There are super long walks and travelling cut-scenes for no reason. Definitely the longest but not the best game in the series (unsure why people are saying it is). There are also game breaking bugs that make you restart the entire section. You're able to fall off the game map into endless oblivion by jumping off one of the ski lifts. For people who enjoy more balanced and challenging cooperative puzzles this is not the game for you.";11.0;0.0;0.0;172.0;Posted: May 23

column1: Let me start by saying that this whole series has been a fantastic experience for me
column2: one I won't ever forget. I can't recommend this series enough and wish to see more co-op puzzle games like these.

column1: The atmosphere and design of this game were on point. You can see that a lot of effort has been put into that
column2: which I appreciate enormously. It made everything even more immersive. The communication between you and your partner was vital and got pushed up a notch to solve certain puzzles (I won't go into details
column3: I don't want to spoil). The puzzles were not too tricky and not that hard to solve either. Some of their visuals blew my mind.

column1: I love how the two characters are together for most of the game. I felt a great sense of freedom due to it. In previous games
column2: it was pretty set who had to solve which part of the puzzle. In 'Forever' it depends on who walked first or opened something first etc. I love the little breaks between the puzzles (where you had to travel from one place to the other). Those made it more immersive for me. The break allowed you to play rock
column3: paper
column4: scissors
column5: talk about your environment or share ideas about what you think will happen next. Were the puzzles gave me a more dependent feeling on each other
column6: the breaks gave me the sense that we were in this together as friends.

column1: Therefore the end hit even harder than in the previous games... It gutted me.";15.5;1.0;0.0;50.0;Posted: May 22

column1: The only gripe I had with this entry of the series is how during some puzzles
column2: one of the players merely provides information to their partner
column3: while the other player is the only one actually interacting and solving the puzzle. It did make the game a bit boring at times having only the option to reexplain information and wait for the puzzle to be solved
column4: an issue not present in any of the previous games iirc (both players used to almost always interact and contribute to the solving of their parts of a level to complete the puzzle)

column2: this game is a good entry in the series. The storytelling was compelling and the visuals/atmosphere were fantastic. Hope to see more :)";4.1;1.0;0.0;248.0;Posted: May 22

I wish this game had some better visual/mechanical updates since the last game but it seems like they mainly focused on the gameplay and left most of the mechanics from the previous one in. That isn't a terrible thing but its a little clunky is certain areas but nothing that will negatively impact gameplay.
EDIT: I also forgot to mention but I wish it had a bit longer play time
column2: me and my partner finished it in about 12 hours. The previous game was around 9-10 for us so I was hoping for 15-20 range.

A truly exceptional co-op puzzle/escape-room style game. The entire series is fantastic.
This game is a major step-up in quality of puzzles
column2: story-telling
column3: and environment compared to the first three
column4: especially noticeable upon entering maybe the most amazing / mind-bending puzzle room I've ever witnessed.

column1: One or two of the puzzles are noticeably worse quality / harder to follow than the rest
column2: made worse when it felt to us that the puzzle had become bugged (maybe it hadn't
column3: though) BUT the sheer quality of the remainder of the game is high enough that these few experiences aren't enough to tarnish my overall experience.

column2: but from my experience with this genre of games this is definitely on the longer side
column3: and each game in the series has been progressively longer; I would not call the length of this game a downside. For the price and given the usual length of this genre
column4: the length is perfect.";10.6;1.0;0.0;570.0;Posted: May 22

I have played the whole series with the same friend and played all previous parts multiple times with others. I love this game and I'll tell you why. (SPOILER FREE)
1) The mystery story telling is super great. You can read extra stuff laying around for extra lore
column2: but you don't have to and it still will make sense to you.

column1: 2) Music and atmosphere is an amazing addition to the story and overal panicky mood while puzzling under time pressure or in spooky places.
3) The puzzles itself were unique and different from the previous games they have made
column2: some more tricky then others and always having a focal point around communication!!! YAAY!

column1: 4) The differences between playing puzzles under pressure and not under pressure is really great and makes it so you're not constantly in panic mode.

5) A big improvement compared to the earlier games is that you meet up more often between puzzles and get to ""swap sides"" so to say. This means sometimes you can be more in the explaining (librarian) role and sometimes more in the executing (explorer) role.
6) In cut scenes you can actually look around and still talk to your friend in game!

1) Most puzzles aren't randomised or reset when you fail. This means that you now know exactly what to do on a next / new try. This makes it harder to replay the game with other friends (than the first one you've played it with). Note; there are some that do reset when you make mistakes
column2: but in comparison their first game it was barely any of them.

column1: 2) If there is anything little else to complain about its the limited way of looking around during cut scenes. Sometimes I couldn't look at my friend
column2: which was sad
column3: but doesn't make me take off any points (as this is a newer feature already!).

column2: on current release there is a couple of levels that seem to have buggy talkie walkies (limited to certain level areas)
column3: but they are super quick on patches and fixes on bugs. So by the time I'm replaying this
column4: I'm not expecting any problems at all.

column1: So 9/10 would puzzle again. Would be 10/10 if it had a higher replay-ability for puzzle resets.";15.1;1.0;0.0;152.0;Posted: May 21

column1: I would say this game is pretty good
column2: but caveat that on a couple of things. One
column3: I played this with a friend and we used Discord to communicate
column4: which means I can't evaluate the matchmaking or in-game communication system. Two
column5: it's May of 2022 and this game is still new and definitely has a lot of bugs. None of them were game-breaking for us on our playthrough
column6: but we did have to restart the game once to clear a softlock and we ended up glitching the ending cutscene out pretty badly.

column1: As a part of the We Were Here series
column2: I'd say it's on par with the previous entry (We Were Here Together)
column3: but for different reasons. This game is visually more impressive and has a greater emphasis on story
column4: and there's less consequences for
column5: shall we say
column6: taking your time in solving the puzzles. However
column7: WWHT had the superior puzzles and more polished gameplay.

column1: Recommend playing the other games in the We Were Here series first if you haven't already
column2: and then picking up this game after it's been out for a few months and the developer has had a chance to patch some of the bugs.
Jack and Rose both could have fit on the dang door. Come on.";8.7;1.0;0.0;139.0;Posted: May 19

column1: An amazing game and upgrade from the previous games in the series. Graphics and puzzles wise. There is a lot less confusion due to missing hints and it is much clearer what went wrong. That isn't to say there weren't moments when me and my friend got stuck
column2: but the instances were far less frustrating than in the last games in the series.

column1: As of our playthrough (finished 6 days after release)
column2: there are still a fair few moments with framerate lag. They aren't super frequent
column3: or at least we didn't pay it much mind. For a person whose first game might be We Were Here Forever or isn't a huge fan of the series
column4: they might be more annoying or frustrating.

column1: A very well-made game. It is heavily inspired by HoMM 3
column2: yet it manages to distinguish itself by introducing a couple of unique mechanics
column3: which drastically change gameplay.

column2: coupled with stack limits allows for a lot of build diversity.
interesting and powerful
column3: if used correctly.

column1: - Visual design is of a very high quality.
- Campaigns present the story pretty well - the musical cutscenes are a nice addition.

column2: there are a couple of areas in which the game could use a bit more development.

column1: - Some minor QoL features are missing. Moving troops from the town defenders to your Hero is a bit of a chore
column2: you can't replay auto-resolve
column3: you can't repeatedly shift-cast spells e.t.c.

column1: - The game lacks simultaneous turns. They might get added later
column2: but so far the multiplayer is pretty slow
column3: especially if you are playing something other than a duel.

column1: - Unit abilities and faction mechanics are too similar. The majority of research upgrades are pretty much the same across the factions
column2: units have a lot of same-y abilities. A bit more diversity would be nice.

column1: - While the campaigns are pretty good
column2: they only cover 2 out of 4 playable in-game factions
column3: and are pretty short on missions - each campaign only has 4 of them.

column2: the game is pretty enjoyable to play right now and has a lot of potential in the future.";109.5;1.0;21.0;213.0;Posted: 16 May

column1: If Heroes of Might and Magic
column2: King's Bounty and Disciples were to have a child
column3: this would be exactly what it feels like.

column1: I didn't expect the game to be so enjoyable
column2: this is the most fun I'm having in turn-based strategy games of this specific subgenre since Heroes V
column3: and it manages to deliver this specific type of chill and tactical gameplay perfectly.

column1: The strongest aspect of the game would definitely be its magic system
column2: it's quite original and fun to tinker with! Your units basically double as mana batteries
column3: each having its own ""essences"" they add to your essence pool every time the unit is to make a turn. You then proceed to cast whatever you want provided you can cover its essence cost
column4: no need to learn spells and add them to your spellbook besides most powerful ones that require a hero skill
column5: it's that simple!

column1: Building system is also pretty good! You quite literally construct additional buildings around your main one and see your settlement gradually growing
column2: going from a tiny village to a giant fortified town with a dozen of stuff and walls around it
column3: which just looks visually stunning. You are also free to choose what exactly you want to build and focus on
column4: no hard limits and no need to construct ""one of each"" in contrast to predecessor games.

column1: Do you want to make a meme build with ten exactly same buildings generating one same unit type and then just overwhelm your enemy with disposable infantry? Go for it! Are you a fan of strong economy? Fill your building slots with lumber mills
column2: gold mines
column3: quarries
column4: et cetera!

column1: If you enjoy very specific army compositions with only some units of your faction involved
column2: nothing can stop you from playing that way
column3: in fact I'd even argue most armies revolve around picking 3-4 unit types to use effectively while the game offers you 8.

column2: as is their manner of storytelling
column3: each mission having a cool short song attached to it. Only 2 factions out of 4 have their respective campaigns right now
column4: unfortunately
column5: but I think they intend to finish other ones in the future
column6: which I'm looking forward to.

column1: What I'm not a fan of and what I'd have personally changed boils down to one single thing that somehow is prevalent in most aspects of the game.

column2: and currently there's not enough to truly call it a masterpiece
column3: although it has great potential.

column2: it desperately cries for more unconventional items since as of now they mostly increase your attack
column3: defense or resource income. I wouldn't call it a bad system
column4: but it's boring.

column2: all characters share same skills that boil down to simple ""melee"" and ""caster"" archetype
column3: while I'd want to see something crazier once in a while. Just anything that can make the system more advanced
column4: really.

column1: - Unit abilities are shared between several factions and mostly revolve around numbers (bonus to attack
column2: defense
column3: buffing allies
column4: debuffing enemies)
column5: somehow the game's predecessors were able to have more total units
column6: yet *less* repetitiveness
column7: all abilities felt much more unique and each unit had an identity
column8: which isn't the case here. Make them stand out from one another more!

column1: - More spells of all kinds. Please-please-please! Spellcasting is the game's strongest point
column2: hence develop it a bit more! I want more synergies and more stuff to throw at my enemies.
more variety of content.
it's a good game with a great future
column3: I'm literally hooked. You all should try it too!";55.2;1.0;15.0;274.0;Posted: 16 May

column1: A really fresh take on HOMM-like tbs genre. The huge one is combat mana system that adds another layer of consideration to composing your armies. First campaign introduces you to all basic mechanics. I especially liked how the last Arleon mission highlights power of magic and initiative.
The game is EA at the moment so there're some bugs
column2: quirks and missing/desired features which will (hopefully) be fixed/ironed out/introduced. There's also a powerful map editor for those who like to explore their creative side so content potential of the game is low-key unlimited.

column1: Sound design is awesome and soundtrack is as good as you will expect from a game with Songs in the title.";97.9;1.0;10.0;210.0;Posted: 17 May

Needs some AI balancing and quality of life features but definitely one to get. Highly recommended.";27.3;1.0;7.0;4250.0;Posted: 16 May

column2: this game runs somewhat parallel to the Heroes of Might and Magic games. There's a similar overland map with Wielders (heroes) exploring and moving to points of interest and towns. Towns and mines produce resources needed to upgrade towns and do research. The combat system utilizes the familiar left vs. right hexagonal grid
column3: with stacks of units moving in familiar ways.

column1: The combat system has some added complexity to it compared to the last HoMM titles I played. Positioning serves a critical role
column2: with several spells focused on moving both friendly and enemy troops around the combat map. Zone of control makes a return from the Civilization games; rather than immobilizing your units it presents the enemy with opportunity attacks against your units if they are just walking by
column3: or running away from
column4: the enemy. This serves as a nice feature to prevent ranged units from endlessly kiting melee units around.

column1: The magic system is a little more restricted than I'd like
column2: but it works for the game. During battle
column3: each stack of troops generates a type and quantity of essence (mana) that you can use for spells. This can be abused somewhat
column4: as the amount generated is based on ; three stacks of one troop each will generate three times as much essence as one stack of three troops
column5: although your Wielder starts with a small stack count and must choose to upgrade how many stacks they can command when leveling up.

column1: I'm definitely going to watch the continued development of this game with interest. If you're looking for a newer
column2: more ambitious HoMM
column3: this might be the game for you.";3.3;1.0;5.0;306.0;Posted: 22 May

column1: I've never played the original Heroes of Might and Magic series so this is legit a fresh look at this game.
It has promise. That's the best I can tell you.
The game comes with 13 maps that you can't edit if you don't want to play the Campaign mode.

If you download maps off of Mod.IO you can't edit them until you go into the game files and copy and past the map file into the file you make for editing maps. No reason for that to be a thing that's a basic function of the map editor why do the maps not go into a folder the editor can read by default?

The AI is terrible. To show off how terrible I had a level 16 hero with a massive army and TWO of the AI's level 3 or less heroes with armies that had absolutely no chance ATTACKED me in one turn. They just ran right into me. The AI in battle prioritizes doing damage and killing units. It doesn't care if it's targeting a unit that isn't a threat it will let your super OP ranged units bombard it and focus on killing weaker units that don't really threaten it. It just cares about dealing damage. That's all.

The Heroes themselves are really unbalanced. A high level caster focused on using the game's magic system can outright destroy entire armies with minimal effort. You can spam multiple spells a turn and it's really
column2: really cheesy. In PVP this can essentially boil down to ""I won because I went first and blew all my spells"" which makes pvp really a moot point.

column1: Some of the spells have wordings that a player could easily misunderstand. If a spell says it damages all Troops it means all troops INCLUDING yours. If a spell says it can jump to multiple troops
column2: it means ALL troops INCLUDING yours. If it gives you two attacks the unit will just blow both if the target survives the first hit even if said target was so mortally wounded it wouldn't have mattered anyway. The spell that pushes things away from you is stopped by the first damage dealing thing the unit is pushed into INCLUDING a CLOUD. Why would I assume the spell that throws a dragon 20 tiles backwards would be stopped by a CLOUD?

column1: To wrap this up the towns also have no real defense at all. They have no baseline defenders and the defense buildings are entirely a waste of time. Defending anything is totally pointless. I ended a game where I attacked the AI's main city and it was being defended by ONE RAT. A SINGLE RAT.
I didn't even know what to make of that.
Long story short the art style is nice
column2: but the gameplay boils down to a random smattering of magic casts against a really inept AI enemy. I understand it's in EA but they want $30 for this game and it's just not worth that in the state that it's in. Maybe some updates will fix that but until that happens I can just review what I have and what I have is not worth $30.";23.8;0.0;10.0;157.0;Posted: 22 May

column2: but I had a hard time figuring out what all the buildings were supposed to do and left certain areas not realizing I didn't control a building in a village (you have to tap on them all independently). Trying to upgrade some buildings that I had resources for didn't result in anything.

column1: I know it's early access and changes will be made and many things will become clear as the game bakes

column3: and I don't believe this is worth the cost in it's current state.";0.8;0.0;7.0;937.0;Posted: 19 May

column2: unfortunately
column3: still more or less a turd. I'm not hating
column4: but a LOT of reviews for this game are positive only due to HoMM nostalgia. Game has potential
column5: but it's not as ready as some would make you think.

column1: As a longtimed Heroes series fan and someone who was really looking forward to this game I'll be first to say: the spirit of HoMM3 is strong in this one. Even though I'm not a fan of pixelart (HoMM3 sprites still look better than those in this game)
column2: I have to admit the level of polish is quite good. Music is especially well made. Base gameplay is solid and you can feel a heart put into creation process.

column1: Should you be rushing to buy this one then? No.
Despite being a small game with pixelart graphics
column2: it struggles with keeping consistent fps even on high end hardware.

column1: Campaigns are short and really not that creative in terms of a plot. Sure
column2: it's a turnbase strategy
column3: but even latest Heroes incarnations could put a good story.

column1: Balance is all over the place
column2: game heavily promotes magic casting
column3: basically forcing you to cast at every possible turn and invest in magic oriented skills. If you won't do so
column4: you'll be blasted to pieces by an AI wielder shooting offensive spells faster than AR-15. Example: in the first campaign you encounter a setup with AI not only starting with more cities (that's expected) but also with a sh*tton of magic resource generators meaning fighting their wielders is a suicide until you patiently try to remove all those external generators first. Or you can simply run 2-3 armies at once into enemy wielder to secure a victory and leave yourself open to attacks from other enemy armies. Fun times. Did I mention that AI has apparently unlimited resources
column5: almost instatly brinding back defeated wielders and coughing up army after army?

column1: Speaking of armies - some units have clear advantages over their counterparts
column2: which you'll discover only a few hours into the gameplay.
you'll get 1 turn to setup your units before an actual engagement and that's if you're lucky. This one might not be a downside for everyone but for me - in tactical turnbased game
column3: it's a huge no-no. If we want things to get fast
column4: we have combat speed and autoresolve for that.

column1: That brings us to buildings. While the whole system works quite nice
column2: some buildings have requirements stating that other
column3: usually rather useless building (e.g. lumbermill) is erected first. The thing is
column4: once you build the building you want
column5: you can simply destroy the required building freeing the space and getting resources back. What's the point here
column6: delaying me 1-2 turns longer?

column1: I'll wait for it to exit EA
column2: then we'll see about changing this review. Good news is - most of problems are a matter of tweaks and adding content
column3: not rebulding the core of gameplay so there's a solid chance the game will come up good.";6.5;0.0;15.0;609.0;Posted: 18 May

column1: I would give this game proper chance
column2: but the thing that killed all my joy is the UI.

column1: I loathe modern games that don’t have proper UI settings. This game has none. Everything is so darn small
column2: that it takes real effort to see text
column3: and clicking requires extra effort. Why is minimap so miniscule? It’s almost useless. Why resource numbers are in font size 6? Why is the troop roster so tiny?

column2: I did not play that much
column3: because I don’t think this game is worth my time at its current state or at the current price tag. Maybe I’ll pick this up on later date at sale
column4: after the full release
column5: if the game gets proper UI settings.

column1: Combat is mediocre plus. I can’t really see myself engaged in it for long run

column2: I've been waiting for this game for a few years. I've just finished the first campaign and in general it has a few key issues. But let's start with...

column1: - Art style is nice. Not the best
column2: but nice. Pixel art is not my thing but models and animations are acceptable. The problem though
column3: due to being pixel art
column4: nothing is too clear (compared to Heroes games
column5: especially Heroes 3). On the adventure map
column6: a lot of buildings are non-descriptive or non-characteristic. But still
column7: they look nice.

column1: - Flow of the game in general is quite good. When you get used to the mechanics
column2: like recruiting units instantly from your other towns with Rally Point or casting unlimited amount of spells per turn is bit different but kinda welcome. The unlimited casting thing has a down side but I'll get to that in a minute.

column1: - Factions are... not very special. Main faction in the first campaign is literally Castle/Haven with a twist. Necros are as expected
column2: skellies and rats. Mercenary faction is pretty bland from what I've seen so far. I think there is also a Fortress faction but I haven't seen much from them yet. They are mostly in the second campaign I think.

column1: - Units are not specifically special either. The game has a unit based mana mechanic
column2: which is different. Each unit has a mana type and they generate that when their turn comes up in combat. Then your hero can cast spells with those mana types (think like MtG mana but creatures generate the mana instead of lands). From what I understand
column3: there are Might and Magic hero types (and we obviously had the Might hero as our main hero in the first campaign) and once again
column4: Might focused heroes suck a bit. More to that later.

column2: especially in the campaign. Even after the latest patch to balance it out
column3: enemy heroes in the last mission of the Castle faction has almost infinite amount of units. I had to restart the mission twice
column4: took parts of the map inch by inch
column5: lost some parts and tried to retake to lost towns again and again... It took literally 10 hours to finish the last mission. I might've got cancer while trying to finish that last mission.

column1: PS: If you can manage to sneak in your hero to the top leftmost town and kill the guy in front of the town
column2: it's over. But enemy's wandering heroes are literal gods with constantly fully stacked armies
column3: sooo good luck.

column1: - The spellcasting. I mentioned this a couple of times but as different and refreshing as it is
column2: unlimited spell casting becomes absolute ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ with Magic focused heroes. You can get hit with 2 Armaggedon
column3: 2-3 chain lightning and a few other fireball-like spells at the same time and lose every single unit while winning. While Magic heroes can do this
column4: Might heroes can... boost troop defences a bit
column5: give a little bit of initiative or grant an extra turn to a unit (which is probably the saving grace of Might heroes).

column1: - Autosave/Battle Save system: After playing Heroes 3 HD+ for years
column2: I really got used to the battle save that let's me replay a battle or take me to the exact moment before I engage the enemy. This game however
column3: doesn't even have a decent Autosave feature. To be fair
column4: it DOES autosave but it usually take you a few turns before
column5: which you need to replay again. I can't even remember how many times I had to replay a ♥♥♥♥ ton of turns just because I forgot to make a quick save. I even had to play a few major battles just because of a simple mistake I made later and forgot to make a manual save. Btw
column6: yes
column7: the game allows you to customize the number of autosaves and autosave frequency in the Options menu but it still doesn't fix anything.

column1: In short... This game has a lot of potential to be a very good one. It may not be a classic like Heroes 3 but it won't be forgotten quickly by the fans of the genre
column2: that's for sure. BUT
column3: I still can't recommend the game in this EA state. It still has a lot of balancing issues and some of the features should be reworked. I'll wait for the full release and if the issues get fixed
column4: I'll probably recommend it then.";15.8;0.0;9.0;868.0;Posted: May 20

column1: This game has excellent potential. It very obviously spawned from Heroes of Might and Magic III
column2: but it feels like it improves on all fronts
column3: except for maybe one. Here's a handful of changes I think are good

column1: - Hero chaining isn't really possible anymore because you're limited in how many heroes you can employ. It's also not as necessary because there's a town building you can make to hire units from across all your towns
- Magic is much more balanced IMO and purely combat oriented
column2: although in some ways it feels a little bit less interesting because in this game you know all spells
column3: it's just a matter of generating the spell points needed to cast them. Magic generally feels less powerful overall (no longer tier 3 hasting your entire army to win the game)
column4: but its still effective and worth investing in.

column1: - Unit stack sizes are now limited. I think this is a good change. Overall your army strength is heavily determined by your stats instead of amassing 2k skeletons.
- Towns are much more simplified. You can only make so many buildings
column2: and your town can't do everything. However you can sell buildings and buy buildings strategically just to meet some requirements and then sell them later. It makes city building more tactical and generally makes different areas more specialized.

column1: My biggest grip with this game is there is no random map generator which is a MASSIVE problem for this game IMO
column2: but I know the devs are working on it and have plans to get it in EA or 1.0
column3: so I'm not concerned about it. However if this game doesn't release without a random map generator
column4: I might honestly change my review.";15.4;1.0;4.0;204.0;Posted: May 17

column2: but not great. There are a lot of good mechanics about this game and it is fun to see how the developers have innovated the spellcasting system. They have also done a good job with making the factions interesting with fun heroes and units. However
column3: in its current state there are some problems with the game. If you are familiar with strategy games and the HOMM-series in particular this game is far too easy. As of now in the Early Access there are only two difficulty modes available for the AI: easy and normal.

column1: Let's be fair cheating is a part of the AI in most strategy games
column2: and I do not mind it as much. I would rather have an AI who is cheating a bit than meet underdeveloped heroes with half my army size. This is happening very often right now when I play a skirmish game.

column1: Another problem ties into the difficulty level a little bit
column2: but not necessarily. One of my skirmish games was over in only 15 rounds and there was no apparent reason as to why. It could be that it managed to capture 3 victory points
column3: but it really shouldn't in such a short time. Likewise I was able to win a game in only 30 turns. Both of these games were on a 4 player map.

column1: The game would also benefit from having more factions.
I am looking forward to the continued development of this game and I really think it can turn out great";10.0;1.0;1.0;474.0;Posted: May 19

column1: It's very rare for a game that's a ""spiritual successor"" to a childhood favorite to live up to that expectation. Often those sorts only seek to copy a formula instead of building upon it
column2: repeating design mistakes the original may have had
column3: and ultimately ending up inferior to the original.

column1: Songs of Conquest not that. Goodness gracious is it anything but that.
This game is a brilliant continuation of the Heroes formula
column2: to a point that I almost want to consider it separately from those games
column3: injecting new ideas into a tried and true formula while discarding outdated mechanics. The pixel-art is gorgeous
column4: the music is incredible
column5: and the basic skirmishes have perfectly captured that same hot-seat co-op fun I grew up with in Heroes 3.

column1: I want to highlight some things about the the combat and magic system here
column2: because I'm seeing in many reviews that people are calling it shallow
column3: or lacking impact
column4: being generally down on many of the systems. This is ABSOLUTELY not true
column5: but I understand many of the complaints. People are trying to approach this as if they're just playing another version of Heroes of Might and Magic. That is a mistake
column6: Songs of Conquest has a different flow than what's came before
column7: and you will not experience it at its best if you don't adapt to it.

column2: the magic system. Songs of Conquest does away with spell points in favor of a Magic the Gathering sort of mana system. There are 5 different schools of magic
column3: each tailored around a specific theme of magic. Order magic primarily revolves around buffs
column4: Arcane gives some fun board manipulation spells
column5: things like that. Each unit in the game is connected to at least one of these schools of magic
column6: giving at least one orb (Basically a spell point) of that school every time they take a turn. The more orbs you have of a school
column7: the more powerful magic you can cast of that school. In addition to that
column8: there's many skills heroes can learn
column9: as well as artifacts to find
column10: that generate additional orbs and boost the power of spells in many different ways.

column2: this does feel a little lackluster
column3: combat spells barely tickling opponents and buffs being barely noticeable. Add to that that spell generation feels far too slow
column4: and you'll be left barely remembering to use spells!

column1: But then you start working *with* those mechanics. While the spells feel lackluster at first
column2: they grow EXTREMELY powerful once you start gaining hero skills related to them. Movement spells like dimension door increase in range
column3: eventually hitting a point where you can instantly dive a backline with slow
column4: hard hitting melee units and delete ranged units before they ever get the chance to fire. A 'pacify' debuff doesn't feel all that great when it only lowers an enemies damage by 25%
column5: but after taking some Order skills on your hero that jumps to a whopping 75%
column6: invalidating powerful units entirely! I have had more fun with this games ""swap unit"" spell than I think I've ever had in a Heroes 3 games
column7: being able to invalidate an enemy players strategies by swapping their frontline of foot soldiers with their backline of archers
column8: then walking up and instantly deleting that stack is something I'll never get tired of.

column1: Adding to that power spike is how you build your armies. Each stack of a unit generates spell orbs
column2: meaning that if you build your armies in a way that they are all producing orbs of a single school of magic
column3: you'll quickly find yourself with more magic than you know what to do with. This is especially fun in Songs of Conquest
column4: as unlike Heroes of Might and Magic you can cast multiple spells on the same turn! Some units act as magic 'batteries' specifically for this purpose
column5: the Baryan's Piper unit is pathetic in combat
column6: but generates two Order orbs and has an ability that gives every ally extra turn priority if it hangs back from battle and plays its music. Split that stack in two
column7: and that immediately gives 4 Order orbs and ensures every other unit in the army is going to move before your enemy gets a chance too. Which
column8: if you followed up on that with more Order producing troops
column9: means that you can pacify any ranged units the enemy might have while charging forward with an insanely buffed front line! It's an extremely addictive system that marries the 'might' and 'magic' systems of its predecessors in a way that compliments them both!

column1: This game builds on its predecessor in other ways. Between adding unit stack caps and allowing no sort of 'Town Portal' map traversal ability for your wielders
column2: the game encourages players to have multiple powerful heroes at once to attack or defend on multiple fronts. The unit stacks make spells more effective
column3: as those armies can no longer grow to a size that debuffs become invalidated. And the elevation differences in battle
column4: while being such a simple idea on paper
column5: completely changes up how encounters function as both sides try to compete for the high ground. Again
column6: the swap spell
column7: it's hilarious to walk up to a powerful unit on the high-ground
column8: trade places with it
column9: and use that advantage against them.

column1: There's so much more I could take about. Bases allowing you to build multiple of the same production structure allows hilarious strategies like building ONLY plague rats and drowning opponents in a sea of rodents. Or how being able to delete and refund structures allows you to rapidly shift from a thriving economy to all-out troop production. But I think I've made my point with this review. Yes
column2: this is a spiritual successor to Heroes of Might and Magic
column3: and yes it is enjoyable in many of the same ways that those older games are. But it is also an evolution of that formula
column4: and trying to play it in exactly the same way is a disservice to the mechanics the game possesses. Just try to keep that in mind while playing
column5: because once pushed to their limits these tools are an absolute delight to play with!

column1: (Just one last thing. Campaign missions (While disappointingly short
column2: I do hope they get expanded in length) end with a tavern minstrel singing a literal Song of Conquest about your exploits in the mission you just played. That's awesome. More of that in every video game please)";16.4;1.0;3.0;115.0;Posted: May 18

column1: On of my favourite aspects is 'reactiveness' - I found that so much attention was put into ensuring that the player does not have to wait for trivial actions and animations (the load times after battles can still be improved and there are also some unoptimized visual transitions between turns

column1: This is proof that we (still) don't need Unreal5 visuals to make awesome games - it's the passion and attention to detail that count a LOT.
No bugs for my entire campaign playthrough of an early access release - that is absolutely incredible
column2: and almost unheard of in the 21st century! Well done LavaPotion you deserve some medals for pulling off something like that.

This game is a worthy successor to the Heroes of Might and Magic series. The developers have successfully transposed this archetype into the modern era with sensible quality of life changes.
The four factions that are currently in the game are very varied and a lot of fun:
- Arleon is the traditional Castle faction with the addition of some mythical faeries. They focus on defensive melee units and ranged damage supplemented by support magic.
- Loth are the Undead/Necropolis faction that combine aggressive armies with zombie resurrection and destructive magic.
- Rana are reminiscent of the Lizardmen from the Warhammer Universe
column2: former frog slaves that break out of their bondage. Their armies are made of melee bruisers and poisonous ranged Shamans.

column1: - Barya are a Middle Eastern faction made of gunpowder units with glass cannon melee units.

Balance for the game is quite good with all factions boasting various strategies and approaches. The magic system based on the units fielded in your army makes a refreshing changes of pace to the spam casting of HoMM3.
I am looking forward to additional factions
column2: more maps and new campaigns.";90.3;1.0;2.0;345.0;Posted: May 16

column1: I have been having the honor to stream through the first main campaign with my community and have lots of thoughts! There won't be any spoilers since I really want people to try it themselves. As an older kid who enjoyed watching my parents play HOMM from their deskside
column2: Songs of Conquest feels like an amazing foray into the genre and an absolutely wonderful spiritual successor. The units are all beautifully designed and animated
column3: the campaign itself that I've been through so far has been very fun and full of interesting lore
column4: and I've really enjoyed all the characters and scenery the game presents.

column2: in the later levels
column3: a large difficulty spike that forces you to really be as efficient as possible; mission 3 our of 4 made me restart it entirely due to not really knowing where my town goals were
column4: and while it was a little frustrating
column5: I really enjoyed it actually. Going through the mission entirely blind and then using what I've learned to be more efficient and go through the level more effectively adds a lot of repeatability and really helped me appreciate my own ability to adapt and overcome challenges that I felt were previously insurmountable.

column2: I don't have anyone in particular to play multiplayer with currently

column6: but it's generally pretty fair. Along with that
column7: this IS a week one review

column2: while it does not effect my opinions on the gameplay itself

I just wanted to note that Lavapotion have been absolutely stellar and I'm excited to see the support they give to the game in the future; we just don't have enough developers that are this devoted and lovely nowadays and wanted to give them a shoutout.

column1: Nostalgia for HoMM 3 led me to this tile
column2: and while I was following the game with much interest
column3: I did not know what to expect from its early access stage. Now I do
column4: and I felt the urge to write down my thoughts to process the substantial impact this experience left on me. It is a personal piece
column5: and a praise
column6: but a candid and reflected one
column7: from which I hope that you
column8: dear reader
column9: can take away some conclusions
column10: if you are in the mood for a lengthy critique. Feel free to skip to the last paragraph to find my summary.

column1: The certainty of experiencing something special trickled in immediately upon launching the game. It required a bit of time to set up a quick skirmish game
column2: to choose a small map
column3: and to decide on the faction I would take
column4: as well as that of my opponent. While my brain went to operate in strategy game learning mode
column5: focusing on concepts and preferences and numbers
column6: a feeling emerged
column7: faintly at first
column8: but soon overwhelming. At a certain threshold
column9: I realized it was caused by the mesmerizing music
column10: whose melancholy
column11: pathos
column12: subtlety
column13: and sincerity deeply sucked me into the world of Songs of Conquest. What a fitting title for a game carried by its strong music
column14: and with a musician in each faction! Before even starting my first play session
column15: my analytical stance was gone
column16: and replaced with intense immersion
column17: joy
column18: and anticipation. After transitioning to the actual game
column19: my initial feelings were substantiated and further intensified by the gorgeous pixel art
column22: the vibrant and spot-on sound design
column24: if my comments appear overly enthusiastic from time to time
column25: please bear in mind that I fell in love quickly and heavily with this one.

column1: After being blown away and naively wandering through the exciting world for a while
column2: my strategic thinking
column3: while still taking a back seat
column4: slowly returned - after all
column5: losing is not fun
column6: even if it is presented gorgeously. At this time
column7: it became clear that the game did not rely on smoke and mirrors to fascinate for a brief while
column8: but that underneath all the splendor
column9: there exists a rock-solid foundation built from tight design
column10: a clear vision
column11: and great overall balance
column12: allowing the streamlined interlocking systems to become larger than the sum of their parts. Let me explain. Many reviews complain about altered or missing features from the HoMM series
column13: like the unit cap on stacks
column14: the seemingly weak magic
column15: or the difficulty to achieve lossless fights. While these design decisions certainly shift the game feel away from HoMM 3
column16: which surely can curtail your enjoyment with the title
column17: I see the in them thoughtful modernizations countering (in a certain way extremely satisfying) tactics such as concentrating units to render single heroes close to invincible
column18: or winning not by units

column1: Songs of Conquest embraces the tension of close decisions
column2: bloody battles and risk-reward thinking that is core to the early game feeling of the HoMM franchise
column3: and strives to maintain it longer through the game session than its predecessors
column4: which more often than not spiral out of control
column5: abruptly ending runaway winning and expansion streaks through singular (albeit epic) fights between superheroes
column6: won by the bigger doomstack (adjusted for overpowered relics
column7: skills
column8: and spells). Songs' experience is different
column9: but I appreciate it highly: Lossless fights are still a thing
column10: but they do not come granted with a large army or spellbook. The limited unit and army size encourages experimentation with different compositions
column11: and the novel magic system further augments the relevance of unit choice
column12: as spells are fueled by acting units
column13: not by mana reserves. There also is a common complaint that the units do not possess enough special abilities. While the game could benefit from increased asymmetry (there is room for more abilities
column14: faction-specific spells or building effects)
column15: the units are far from being interchangeable. Even just with basic stats
column16: they adopt distinct combat roles. Clearly the game benefited from extensive balancing before being released into early access. Not the cookie-cutter balance evening everything interesting out of your game
column17: but the feeling that each designed item
column18: spell
column19: unit and system has a purpose
column20: even if it might be only niche. Some areas still need polish (I always wanted research in my HoMM
column21: but the present implementation is rather formulaic)
column22: but I am impressed by what already is here.

column1: Clarity is a big strength of Songs
column2: and I am quite certain that the developers were extremely conscious in their decisions and executed their vision stringently. The result is a great game flow which does not overwhelm you with intricate decisions
column3: does not waste your time with busy work (we could talk about picking up all the glitter here
column4: though)
column5: and from time to time poses a good challenge to mix things up (enemy hero approaching capital
column6: main hero bound with converting an enemy city
column7: secondary and tertiary heroes exploring). Like in many good board games
column8: simple subsystems interact to regularly create challenging decisions while keeping the outcomes and reasons for failure and success clear. This is a foundational but especially hard aspect of design: Cut what is distracting
column9: cut what is not working properly
column10: cut what is undermining other systems
column11: avoid feature and scope creep
column12: to arrive at a faceted jewel.

column2: the UI is slick and presents all relevant information in a well-arranged fashion (OK
column3: let us not talk about the town defence organization screens
column4: these really feel clunky
column5: but particularly so because of the ease you navigate through the rest of the game). The factions feel familiar and far from standard fantasy tropes at the same time
column6: making them both immediately relatable and unique. While I very much appreciated HoMM's high fantasy setting (which wonderfully supports the powerful magic and the colorful and expressive range of characters)
column7: the great heaviness and sincerity of Songs' lore serves its own atmosphere excellently
column8: which is further supported by clever presentation (I love the level up zoom and bang
column9: the visual and sound effects when the souls of a defeated army are released (which can be heard globally
column10: even in absence of vision
column11: during turn calculation)
column12: and the battle victory screen highlighting the final action). These loads of immersion really got me into roleplaying feels
column13: fighting epic battles for the good of my faction.

column1: Nostalgia that can never be truly relived
column2: and will always be remembered through bittersweet
column3: rose-tinted glass. Nothing is ever perfect
column4: and it is impossible to fulfill all expectations when trying the daring task to live up to a decade old legend. Songs of Conquest has the courage to recreate the strengths of such a legend. For this courage
column5: it is rewarded
column6: ending up both as a beautiful piece of art and an emerging masterpiece in its own right. It proves again that a small but capable
column7: passionate and considerate team is able to achieve what all the disconnected executives and Ubisofts in their industrialized
column8: greed-driven corporate mindset failed to accomplish with far more material resources and numbing crunch. But without fostering inspiration
column9: the genuine joy of creation
column10: and the human desire for expression
column11: such an endeavor can never reach its true potential.

column2: I wholeheartedly recommend Songs of Conquest to anyone looking for a crisp
column3: holistic
column4: nuanced
column5: and well-flowing turn-based strategy experience
column6: for people wanting to scratch their HoMM 3 itch in a carefully yet distinctly modernized way
column7: and for fans of deeply atmospheric
column8: artistic games
column9: especially in the dark fantasy and retro settings. It is a rare example of a love letter which manages to avoid old pitfalls
column10: knows well what to preserve
column11: what to overhaul
column12: what to remove and what to add
column13: and executes on these difficult decisions with great confidence in its own qualities.";16.4;1.0;2.0;296.0;Posted: May 21

column1: My first impression of this game was bad
column2: however
column3: after more consideration
column4: I decided to change my review to recommended. Most negatives still stand
column5: the game doesn't feel like a new game to me
column6: it's an imitaion of HoMM3 with inferior graphics and much less content.

column1: I don't like the pixelated graphics. It looks much worse then HoMM3 and no
column2: it's not artsy or ""beautiful"" like some have suggested. The buildings are so similar in design
column3: it's hard to tell one from the other.

column1: In spite of the game looking old
column2: the system requirements are to be taken seriously. I played a medium-sized map and it was pretty sluggish going. AI turns took long with the screen greyed-out so you couldn't really see what was going on. It felt like it was lagging. I have an okay PC capable of running most AAA games
column3: but it's not high-end so maybe this is just me.

column1: Now for the positives. I'm gonna try to explain the concept using the example of Arleon
column2: which is an alliance between humans and faey (elves or fairies?). You have 5 human unit types and 3 faey unit types in your town.

column1: The game promotes replayability by encouraging you to only use one or the other in your playthrough. How? Through wielders
column2: which are your standard heroes. Wielders are very specialized and they buff or benefit from certain unit types. Fortunately
column3: you can pick any wielder in the beginning based on what playstyle you want to pursue.

column1: Your towns have building slots. You shouldn't build a barracks for every type of unit. Instead
column2: you should pick 3-4 unit types and build multiple barracks of the same kind. For instance
column3: if you picked a wielder that buffs ranged
column4: you should build 2-3 archery barracks to greatly increase archer generation. Obviously
column5: this means you sacrifice some other buildings as there are only so many slots.

column1: Units come in limited stack sizes and wielders can carry only a certain number of stacks. So in the case of Arleon
column2: you can go with minstrels
column3: footmen
column4: archers and peasants
column5: if your wielder prefers humans
column6: and not recruit any faey. If you have 8 slots in your army
column7: you can decide to carry 3 archers
column8: 2 footmen
column9: 2 minstrels
column10: and 1 peasant and your playstyle will be about protecting your archers
column11: while they defeat the enemy.

column2: even the magic system is tied to your units
column3: so it's another reason/way to handpick an assortment of units. Different units generate different mana types so you want to carefully consider which ""schools"" of magic you want to prioritize and pick your units accordingly.

column1: The number of wielders you can have is tied to the munber of towns you have
column2: so you should capture every settlement you can. Playing 4 wielders affords you a lot of benefits over playing just 1 or 2.
there is lots to discover and lots to experiment with. I'm currently concerned about the lack of sufficient maps
column3: but hopefully the community gets busy.";17.5;1.0;0.0;109.0;Posted: May 16

Here's my experience in a nutshell:
- Collect nearby resources and build up the town
- Get walled by neutral camps blockading the way out
- End turn until I can build up an army
- Bash my way through neutral camps
- Collect nearby resources and build up the town
- Get walled by neutral camps blockading the way out
- End turn until I can build up an army
- Bash my way through neutral camps

Combat is extremely simplistic. You sit and wait for the AI to approach and the side with bigger numbers wins. There's two unit types -- ranged and melees. They all play the same. Spells exist... I guess? There's too few of them to really care. None of them impressed me. The wielders are figureheads that don't actually fight which makes fighting enemy wielders not much different than neutral camps. There's just... no variety. No strategy. Just a war of attrition.";1.8;0.0;6.0;82.0;Posted: May 21

I was added to the Alpha test for Songs of Conquest extremely late
column2: but was instantly impressed by this game. As many reviews have noted
column3: it is heavily inspired by the Heroes of Might and Magic series
column4: but Songs of Conquest really helped me see how much of my love for HoMM games is based on nostalgia.

column2: the combat system is brilliant. The increased complexity of terrain height
column3: troop movement
column4: attacks of opportunity
column5: and stack size limits
column6: for example
column7: really make each movement in battle a careful tactical decision. No longer can I just zip around with fast moving doom stacks! If HoMM was great when I was a kid
column8: SoC is great for me as an adult.

column2: the magic system generates spell points in various schools based on the types of troops in your army and the time elapsed in combat. So rather than devastating spells being the beginning (and thus end) of combat
column3: thy're something you work up to. Magic also informs your troop selection
column4: and makes the development of your army composition a tricky - and interesting - series of decisions. Instead of might vs. magic
column5: the two work together synergistically to deliver a single
column6: unified strategic experience. The downside is that there is a bit of a learning curve for magic in the game. Good tool tips help a lot with that.

column1: Once I understood the above points
column2: I also came to appreciate the wisdom of the developers' decision to simplify the strategic map compared to the old HoMM games and eliminate the town screens entirely. This is meant to be a tighter and faster-paced game than HoMM
column3: and it succeeds in that. The downside is that for the same reason
column4: it may ultimately lack the longevity of those classic games. But it is well worth the asking price already
column5: and I know that the developers have a lot more content planned for this fabulous game!";3.6;1.0;0.0;46.0;Posted: May 23

column1: First time I've played a turn-based strategy game like this since the battle for wesnoth in the 2000s (just found out they're still updating it
column2: wow). Really captivating artwork
column3: animation
column4: and music. Combat is mostly intuitive with a relatively simple to understand unit/base progression system. Resource management is also pretty straight-forward
column5: and the marketplace building makes getting whatever you need for upgrades really easy... maybe too easy hah!

column1: Just finished the first campaign after many failed attempts
column2: and the most glaring issue is probably the snowball effect of the AI. If you're not constantly attacking and whittling down the enemy troops
column3: you'll simply fall too far behind and get wiped eventually. This was frustrating for someone like me who likes to slowly capture/explore every part of the map as I play. On the fourth stage of the first campaign
column4: the only way I could win was to rush the objective before the enemy units could stack too high. Playing this way left about 30% of the map unexplored for me. Possible solution for the devs might be to increase the time before a wielder can respawn making your victories more rewarding by giving you time to rebuild and explore.

column2: this game is still super fun. Excited to see what sort of additional units/buildings they put in the game as well as more campaigns. Also a co-op campaign would be pretty neat.";30.8;1.0;0.0;71.0;Posted: May 23

Pretty fantastic game. Only one big complaint. Tons of depth in places that the retro games this pays homage to don't have
column2: such as in town building
column3: mob fights
column4: etc. This feels like playing one of the good HoMM games (which for me means 2 & 3) but made in the modern era with modern game design principles. Really excellent. Systems in game are more closely linked to each other in a lot of ways than in those older games
column5: so everything is more meaningfully connected between town-building
column6: army-building
column7: the adventure map
column8: and combat. For example
column9: I particularly like how spells and troops are tied together in combat and effected by army layout
column10: it makes for a really nice flow where you pick troops based not exclusively on their direct combat performance
column11: but also their ability to let you cast the right spells for the job
column12: split stacks with that information in mind
column13: and then use the troop moves to improve your spellcasting and use the spellcasting
column14: in turn
column15: to improve and assist your troops' performance. In fact
column16: the feedback loop design in the whole game is impressive.

column2: which is great. You'd think it would make the game too forgiving
column3: but what it really does is open up a lot of possibilities for dynamic strategy decisions. Forgiving
column4: yes
column5: but at a cost. For example
column6: I demolished a fully upgraded creature dwelling
column7: medium size
column8: because I needed a smaller structure in the short-term that would let me move troops from the rest of my kingdom to my front line
column9: as I was losing a war of attrition with an AI which had a short supply line and was able to replenish troops quickly. After I got the boost
column10: I was able to demolish that structure and rebuild a new creature dwelling. It's really nice to feel like every part of your kingdom can dynamically adapt to changing circumstances (if you're willing to wait for new construction
column11: as construction takes multiple turns) instead of being stuck in whatever configuration you started in.

column2: I do have that one major complaint
column3: and that's that - for now
column4: anyway - the AI is much too easy on ""normal"" difficulty to be satisfying. ""Normal"" is currently the highest difficulty. There are negative reviews that mention that the AI is too difficult
column5: or cheating. In my experience
column6: that's totally incorrect
column7: at least in any meaningful way. I don't know if the AI *technically* cheats on the back-end or not - I'm not sitting there doing the math for what they must have at their castle or anything - but if it is cheating
column8: it isn't cheating enough. Based on what it was throwing at me I can't imagine it's cheating
column9: because I can't imagine any developer would program an AI to cheat that badly. I assume that people with that impression are either inexperienced at turn-based strategy
column10: or aren't reading descriptions and tooltips. I found my own power level to escalate far faster than the AI even when I made somewhat obvious mistakes
column11: like wasting movement on backtracking
column12: unknowingly wearing artifacts that slowed my adventure speed
column13: forgetting to use secondary wielders
column14: making mistakes that led to needless building demolition
column15: and so on. The AI makes poor tactical and economic decisions
column16: especially in regard to building and to the adventure map. The battle AI is more competent
column17: but it's still too easy to go without losses and snowball. Limited stack size helps a lot with keeping you from snowballing too hard
column18: but the tools are still all there to overwhelm the AI
column19: and the AI doesn't seem to be able to use those tools to fight back well enough. Hopefully a top priority is harder difficulty settings
column20: because I think the core designs of the adventure and combat systems are bordering on genius
column21: especially with how well-thought-out the interactions between systems are.";15.3;1.0;0.0;91.0;Posted: May 22

Songs of Conquest hearkens back to the style of classic strategy RPGs like Heroes of Might and Magic. Visually the game looks great
column2: the character sprites are detailed and expressive with colorful maps to traverse. However
column3: sometimes wandering around the map to collect resources is a bit tedious when there isn't much else going on around you. Gameplay is easy enough for a beginner
column4: there are helpful tutorials that can be toggled on and off
column5: but it also has enough depth for those seeking to immerse themselves in the more strategic elements such as building up your town's defense and productivity.

column1: The UI is simple enough to navigate and doesn't make you feel bogged down by menus. Building your settlements is fun and watching the buildings evolve as you upgrade them to produce more soldiers and resources is satisfying. The battle system incorporates the usage of terrain and elevations to give advantages or disadvantages depending on your positions. It's simple enough to pick up the battles
column2: but mindlessly attacking won't bring you to victory so it's important to think about how to use your troops to their capacity. Despite being melee troops
column3: the footmen seemed awfully weak and felt like sending paper soldiers off to battle. The Rangers on the other hand
column4: were extremely useful. You can also upgrade the different troop types as you advance your settlement.

column1: The music is...present. It's not bad by any means and sometimes there are cutscenes with bards singing songs but it didn't feel very memorable.
Overall the game seems very well made thus far and is a very enjoyable experience if you like old-school strategy RPGs.";9.0;1.0;0.0;155.0;Posted: May 20

column1: I came for a game like oldschool Homm

column1: Being a solid and beautiful contestor in the genre right from early access
column2: Songs of Conquest offers alot of innovative gameplay.

column1: Unlike in other games of the genre
column2: you are very flexible with your building paths
column3: having the ability to build any building into different building slots (small
column4: medium and large) which vary from settlement size and level. You can either go classic and go for every dwelling or decide to go hard into a certain troop.

column2: there is an increase in strength for higher level troops but it is a slighter progression than you might be used to. There are caps on unitstacks
column3: that can be upgraded
column4: but also stop you from building doomstacks from the same unit very early on.

column1: Troops also grant your heroe (wielder) essence (order
column2: chaos
column3: destruction
column4: creation and arcana) from which they can produce powerful magic
column5: some troops give just a bit
column6: some give a lot and others do give few but multiple essences. Spells are chosen from a spellbook
column7: you don't have to learn them. There are 4 spells per essence and 20 more that are combinations of 2 of them combined. So you are able to wield powerful magic from the get go.

column2: 2 small campaigns and a map editor. And a great community to boot.";113.9;1.0;0.0;94.0;Posted: May 20

If i like the game ? I think it's the best HMM like ever even yet in early access (i've played all HMM except 1 and 2; fallen enchantress; age of wonders 2 and 3; warlock the exiled 2; disciple II; kings bounty II and maybe some i'm forgetting).

Why ? Nearly all new stuffs you add and change in the original formula are smart and full of potential. Stuff such as unit-based mana with 5 colors enabling many different combo and synergy; the fact that you start instant with all spells unlocked give you instantly the feeling of power and being an overpowered mage and make early game more enjoyable than in HMM.
I also appreciate the fact that there are fewer neutral fights on the map but more decisive
column2: less homogeneous (less one monster type army or only one regrouped stack army) and more rewarding; and simply more free loot scattered across the map; all this makes the games more fluid and the fights against the neutrals less redundant.

column1: Do i think it's a perfect game ? No
column2: because :

column1: There are problems intrinsic to games where the player has a lot of potential and where the AI must ""master complex game mechanics"".
After a few hours of games I had already found unbeatable low-cost strategies for each faction that allowed me to defeat armies much stronger than mine.
For example very quickly make dire dreaths
column2: a single stack of this unit allowed to do almost all the fights of the map without the slightest loss (this is a little more difficult if the armies are composed of ranged units but the AI does not know how to use them I will come back to it later).

column1: Another example make a lot of stack of 1 or 2 ancestral chelun and some stack max of shaman or Eth'dra
column2: upgrade your hero level 3 in creation and arcane and spam spells of invocations of obstacles
column3: teleportation
column4: push
column5: mists
column6: swarms and arcane storms to totally block the opposing army
column7: gain abundant mana and not lose any unit.

column1: A last cheese to illustrate my words
column2: ravagers and riders gain attack for each square traveled before attacking as with the cav of HMM however in this game we can make movements a square by a square without ending the turn
column3: so that our ravager is not in the zone of control of an enemy
column4: this one can go back and forth on 2 squares and then attack with a huge load bonus while it has technically almost not gained momentum before attacking.

column1: This being just a few examples of cheese among the many find after a few hours of games.
The AI does not know how to use ranged units
column2: they advance too far and too often before firing which drastically reduces its damage and exposes it to enemy melee units.

column1: We can not increase the difficulty of the AIs neither in the campaign nor in skirmishes result I did not encounter any difficulty both in the skirmishes and in the campaign and this from my first hours of games (it should be noted that I very quickly overexploited some mechanics of the game and the poor intelligence of the AIs but if I do not I have the impression of underplaying and creating my own difficulty artificially) Beating the AI is currently without challenge for me (I don't lose any units in almost all the fights from the beginning of the game).
So I looked at multiplayer. However as you already know
column2: you did not design the game for that
column3: that's why you work on the simultaneous turn which is for me essential to be able to make games with more than 2 players (my last 4players FFA game lasts 8 hours to do only 20 rounds and I rushed to finish because I wanted to sleep).

column1: I told myself that I had to play mainly in 1v1 but the lack of matchmaking puts me off because I am afraid of finding too little challenge or a risky challenge sometimes falling on a player with 10 times more hours of play than me. (logical you didn't expect so many players and multiplayer demands) We can try to determine our level of mutual play before facing each other in order to avoid this kind of problem but it loses its fluidity to find balanced games.

column2: this game is a pearl full of potential and this especially in view of your means. However
column3: some flaws can hurt more demanding and experienced players
column4: but can you be thrown the stone when none 4X should I say no turn-based tactical/strategic game solves either the problem of artificial intelligence by making it challenging
column5: fun and quite predictable or the challenge of multiplayer (Almost all games of this genre have a very low multiplayer player base
column6: no matchmaking
column7: too long games and balance problems)?

column2: all these challenges are still relevant and far from being overcome
column3: but talented and adventurous small studios like yours are taking a big step in the right direction. So for all these reasons thank you! Thank you for your efforts
column4: for the time you take to communicate with your players
column5: for the attention to detail

column1: I am writing this review after having played 5 hours.
I can't believe it took this long to have a new game in the genre of HoMM3.

column2: what an update!

the pixel look within a 3D space is a great way to give it a fresh modern look while still calling back to its retro origins. Every sprite is carefully crafted and animated and it is so nice to see them move.

column1: The world map movement and interactions feels every bit the same as HoMM3 and I would not want it any other way.

The most notable change is that your town and every building in it is physically present on the map. I think this is a great add-on because because it makes the action of making your town and expanding it much more tangible and satisfying.

column2: I love how they handled the town building. You are offered with a limited amount of spots for your buildings but you are allowed to decide the locations
column3: types and quantity of buildings you want to have in your town. It is a nice additional strategy layer that lets you specialise your towns for your needs. You could potentially have a town that only produces resources or one that is made to focus on creating as much units as possible. It really does feel like an improvement to HoMM3.

column1: I would say the combat is the part of the game that changed the most.
The tactical aspect stays true to its origins
column2: while adding features that only deepen the experience. (The elevations that gives you defensive or ranged bonuses are a welcomed improvement).

column1: Units have a variety of special abilities that gives them a specific play style. For instance
column2: I am still on my first game with the Barya faction and I love how the spearman has extended reach and can attack through other units. It is something that I don't think was present in HoMM3 and it makes for fun tactics. That said
column3: I really hate that the musketeers need to reload.

column1: The spell slinging is probably one of the more unique aspect from the game. You don't have just one type of mana
column2: you now have 4. From what I have seen
column3: they are mostly affected by the hero you chose and the type of units he carries with it. During combat
column4: you start with no mana and you accumulate it depending of which actions you make with your troops
column5: mixing the different type of mana to cast various spells.

column2: it changes the relation you have with your mana. Where you once saved it for strategically important fights
column3: you are now encouraged to use it as soon as you have it. It makes casting spells something you do on a much more regular basis
column4: which is nice. But the sad thing is that you lose what was once an important resource to manage
column5: making the choice of using spells a much more trivial one.

column2: I have been playing for almost 5 hours and I am having a blast!

column1: There are things I am not 100% on board with
column2: but in this case the good definitely outweighs the bad.
I already have the feeling that this is a game I will be coming back to on a regular basis.
this is extremely solid. There are tweaks and balancing to be made but I am confident the devs will be responsive to the community and tackle these issues as they come up.

column1: With the success it already has
column2: I can only hope there will be new factions
column3: maps and scenarios overtime because this game surely deserves it.

column2: this game is a must buy.";4.3;1.0;0.0;146.0;Posted: May 20
