column1: Songs of Conquest is a game that you'll probably buy because you are a massive fan of Heroes of Might & Magic. If you are one of those
column2: I can tell you that you can buy it and be satisfied
column3: it is quite faithful while introducing many new things that don't ruin anything. Trust my word as someone who has played all Heroes media over the course of 20 years.

column1: If you aren't a fan of Heroes
column2: then this review is for you.

column1: Playing through Songs of Conquest is a great experience
column2: something you'd curl up to during a fresh may day and immerse yourself in while hearing the birds chirping outside. It is quite relaxing and stimulating. I'll try to explain the pros and cons of the game as best as I can during the course of this review.

column1: The game is divided into three parts. The management
column2: the adventuring
column3: and the combat.

column1: The management and adventuring are neatly combined together so I'll talk about them first. There is no one singular map in the game
column2: rather many different maps with different goals and playstyles. On each map
column3: your goal is to go around the map collecting resources and treasure to amass power for yourself
column4: whether it is empowering your wielder with artifacts or getting access to stronger armies by buying them with the resources you have gathered. This part of the game is very good
column5: with a nice ambient soundtrack
column6: and some amazing visuals. (Which we will get into later) It has a nice sense of progression
column7: as better loot is typically guarded by harder enemies
column8: which you have to face in combat.

column2: you are put into an entirely different game
column3: seemingly
column4: as you then have to use the troops you have to fight enemy creatures in a chess-like environment
column5: with a field that has a hexagonal field. There are many different aspects to combat
column6: such as elevation giving bonuses to your units in combat
column7: terrain you cannot move your units to and through
column8: as well as magic that your wielder can cast to turn the tides of battle. It is always quite tense and exciting as you would optimally not want to lose any units
column9: and in late-game battles
column10: it can become insane.

column1: Your wielder is the person which will be leading your armies and moving around the adventure map. It gives a very nice RPG element as you can give them new skills
column2: and upgrade existing ones
column3: of which there are many - all the while giving them differing equipment and artifacts. There are also trade-offs when leveling up with your hero in the skills that you choose
column4: so it is always going to feel more personalized the more you play and the hero you have sees so much progress.

column2: the game suffers. There are currently a substantial amount of bugs
column3: thankfully none of which seem to be too gamebreaking. This is fine in my eyes however as the game is still in early access. The graphics are great
column4: however
column5: giving a sort of Stardew Valley kind of vibe.

column1: There are also some balancing issues where there are some blatantly overpowered and underpowered things in the game. In the campaign
column2: there is also one very insane difficulty spike which struck me as odd.
though
column3: the game is great
column4: and I'd easily recommend it
column5: especially as the devs are relatively nice to the community and transparent
column6: with many updates being churned through. I'd give it a higher rating maybe in the future
column7: but for now
column8: until the bugs and balancing issues are fixed
column9: as well as the relative lack of content
column10: I am giving it a";37.0;1.0;0.0;185.0;Posted: May 19

column1: Mild Story Spoilers for the First Campaign Mission Ahead:
I've never played Heroes of Might and Magic
column2: so to me my closest comparison is to Warcraft 3. I prefer games that have a story
column3: that have world building
column4: that find a way to pull you in and tug at your heartstrings a little. I like to be immersed. When I was first introduced to the game watching a YouTuber play it
column5: it struck me as generic. The songs were a neat touch
column6: but hasn't this all been done before? And then I watch as the protagonist mercilessly butchers a bunch of rebel farmers
column7: threatens others for not dying in her name while she was away
column8: and wince as she brutally attacks a party of strange and potentially friendly foreigners.

column2: they wrote an actual story.

column1: The game is drenched in atmosphere. The music is outstanding
column2: the story is minimal in the style of many old strategy games but full of nuance
column3: scraps of history in the environment
column4: the artifacts
column5: the character interactions
column6: and the army rosters themselves. The world feels deep
column7: lived in
column8: full of stories.

column2: while distinct and very different from anything I've played before
column3: is really fun to figure out and play with. It's not especially intuitive
column4: but it's clearly very well designed. I've completed both campaigns now
column5: with a lot of saving and reloading before potentially risky moves
column6: and I can't say I've got a great grasp on how to play optimally in terms of base-building
column7: army composition
column8: etc.
column9: but I had an absolute blast. Exploring the world
column10: leveling up heroes/wielders
column11: meeting challenges with the forces you've managed to scrape together
column12: seeing how skills
column13: the wonderfully deep spell system
column14: tech trees
column15: your heroes inventory
column16: world buffs
column17: and units all work together to do awesome things
column18: it's all great fun!

column1: Keep in mind that the game is in early access. There are eight campaign missions at present
column2: each can easily take between 1-4 hours depending on whether you fully explore the map and kit up your characters (which I do recommend) or blitz for the objectives. While I encountered no game-breaking bugs
column3: the enemy AI did seem to break a couple of times
column4: with an enemy wielder who was probably meant to be out seizing resources and making the player's life more difficult was instead just sat in their own base
column5: or trapped behind some resources
column6: staring angrily out at the world. Also
column7: both campaigns are clearly just opening chapters. They set up the conflicts
column8: why the factions have the units they do
column9: and who some of the major lore characters are
column10: and they each resolve an arc of the larger story
column11: but they practically beg to be continued further. I really hope we get to see more of that story because the foundations are fantastic.

column2: in its present state
column3: is a brilliant introduction to a largely forgotten genre of game. It has story
column4: deep and engaging gameplay
column5: and a whole lot of potential. There's at least a minimum of 24 hours of narrative campaign gameplay
column6: and a whole lot more if you get into playing skirmish games or decide to try out the map editor or the community maps. If it got a few bug fixes and were released as is
column7: I would be glad to have purchased the game. I'm eager to see what more is added
column8: to see the fundamentals polished further
column9: and especially to see what more is built upon these excellent foundations.";43.1;1.0;1.0;102.0;Posted: May 19

column1: The gameplay is a great homage to my memories of the Heroes of Might and Magic series

column1: It seems deceptively simple to begin with
column2: but the longer you play
column3: the more depth you discover to the mechanics
column4: unit interactions and character levelling choices. Several times
column5: I was taught a lesson by the AI player
column6: often a very painful lesson
column7: but on learning it I understood the game better. To think
column8: during my first few hours
column9: I thought the magic system was under-powered. Ha!

column1: Sometimes the campaign feels a little unfair and relentless - but persevering and eventually tipping the balance and ending the AI onslaught is very satisfying indeed. The 'just...one more... turn' vibes are strong
column2: and a bit dangerous.

column1: I am really looking forward to seeing where the developers are taking this game in the future. It's already worth the price in its current state

column3: which makes for many more strategic decisions to make.

column2: gives freedom to customize the buildings in your city. So now
column3: you get to decide what units your city will generate. But it also means that you now need to be conscious about your economy. Unlike HoMM and its straightforward economy
column4: it's up to you to get the right ressource/unit balance. Also
column5: there is a tech tree! The tech tree is very important
column6: and the ressources required to gain upgrades will have to be considered when building armies. The tech tree is a huge hole that needs to be filled with ressources
column7: you'll probably never feel like gathering ressources stops being useful at any point in a normal game.

column1: A thing that veterans might not like: the magic. The spell system takes time to get used to
column2: but I like it. There are only a handful of damage-dealing spells
column3: and they're pretty weak. This makes combat much more interesting. a fireball might change nothing to the combat's outcome
column4: but summoning a bush to block the path to your ranged units could pull the odds in your favor.

column2: It is Early access
column3: so there are little unpolished things here and there: Some spells can level-up
column4: but you are just never told how. some units can have a speed of 3
column5: which are so slow that they become unusable because the fight will end before they reach any target. Also
column6: It's a chore to manage troops in cities.";40.2;1.0;0.0;660.0;Posted: May 18

column1: While Songs of Conquest is starts as EA it has a lot of polish to it. Soundtrack
column2: pixel graphics and overall athmosphere is quite nice and quality is really good. While a lot of fans of turn based strategies know Heroes of Might & Magic series ( and pretty much acknowledge HoMM3 as the best entry) will enjoy art style and setting
column3: sometimes you will get a bit mad at how small some of the icons/ui elements are - sadly at this moment there is no UI scaling option
column4: but overall maps and units are distinguishable and gorgeous.

column2: with classical mechanics like initiative
column3: counter-attacks on melee hits and magic. Well known stacks (units) are somewhat limited
column4: so no more 999+ ghost doomstacks roaming in multiplayer and destroying everyone. While normally in these type of games you would have 'mana' resource for your Hero (that casts spells) there is a twist in SoC - you gain mana passively for each turn from your hero's abillities and your stacks/units - every one of them has some specific mana type. All spells are unlocked from the start
column5: so you can cast them in battle whenever you have corresponding mana type points - this means you can't start spellslinging in the 1st turn
column6: which makes some of the more powerfull spells a later option.

column1: At the moment there is only 2 campaigns
column2: consisting of 4 missions with increasing difficulty - 2 more faction specific campaigns are in the works. After completing each mission you can hear the titular
column3: which are pretty nice addition and summary of a mission. While these 8 missions will net you somewhere around 8hrs of gameplay
column4: Devs thought about user created content - you can make/try out user made campaigns and maps by yourself. Also multiplayer is available
column5: but sadly there is no simultaneous turns.

column1: This review is literally days after release so much of what I say here could be rendered moot over time.
However it's a grand improvement over the first due to some changes in optimization
column2: allowing less lag and stuttering. I don't understand how
column3: but I think it just puts the pressure more on your graphics card than... whatever it was before which is actually a good thing (if you have a decent graphics card). I only played about 30 minutes of the first one but I dumped six hours into this one
column4: four of which was a singular battle in the massive City of Troy
column5: emulating a three-way siege battle that I played like an actual RTS. I constantly moved units around
column6: retreated
column7: fortified and reinforced battle units. I just ordered the defensive team around but after four hours and a massive full retreat
column8: my defensive Spartans ultimately lost against the Romans. It was an incredible amount of fun.

column1: I have also had fun administering my own various buffs and nerfs through customization. I think the Roman's and their shields are just too tough as they are
column2: so I gave them a smaller health pool. I found Persians too easily trounced so I gave them some extra stats and increased attack speed. So it gives me a bit of an MMO Tycoon feel to it that I enjoy. I try to make fairly even teams. Or a defensive posture that are outnumbered but can utilize chokepoints. Ever since I learned about the Battle of Thermopylae
column3: I've always been fascinated with the battle tactics of chokepoints and I was able to live that fantasy for four hours last night dealing with it.

column2: what is the game? It's as the title claims. It's mostly a simulator and you can be as involved as you like
column3: as I mentioned earlier. You just place units on a battle map
column4: load it up and watch them duke it out. You can control a singular unit as well but I've found that they don't perform as well when you're controlling them for some reason. I possessed a troll in a big siege battle and his health drained very quickly. I wandered to a different troll who'd been fighting for a few minutes and his health was still at 95%. So maybe there's just something about a posess-ee that makes the AI prioritize your unit more
column5: I don't know.

column1: 1) A scrollbar for more than 18 teams. I like to do micro-management with teams so I like having dozens of teams on the same side. A single platoon with some catapults and archer placements can take 6-8 slots just on their own. We need to have a scrollbar on the setup menu so we can get really micro with it. I imagine it might complicate the color palette but hey... 1b) Let us choose that too! I don't mind all of my Spartan units just being red. I can arrange them as I see fit.
2) I have a discussion thread on this going but oddly
column2: I want smaller maps for smaller-scaled sieges. Including some castles. Maps to come is already a given considering the game is only days old
column3: but wierdly I want to have a map where I can do smaller
column4: Bannerlord-esque engagements. The 300 versus 2000. We don't have castles yet and the closest thing we have is the Mount Olympus but the attacking AI doesn't behave and won't utilize both paths and the defensive posture on that map has a massive advantage. The current setup page even has a notation about how huge the maps are and don't place stuff near the edges
column5: you could do the same thing with the small maps if people try plopping 2million units on a small map you could have those big red letters saying ""Be careful
column6: idiot!""

column1: 3) I don't know what the programming capability of this in the game's current engine and state
column2: but I'd -like- to see some better AI. It's not bad at times
column3: I've seen platoons split off when one entrance fight goes on too long and they'll split off to find another entrance. I just feel they ignore some tactics too easily. You can mitigate this to some degree in RTS mode but I still don't fully understand what all of the orders do. I'll try to collect units in one spot only for half of them to split off to attack the enemy regardless of me telling them to hold.

column2: more units and more maps and I have no doubt that's all on its way. As it stands
column3: very fun and surprisingly stable.";13.3;1.0;9.0;616.0;Posted: 16 May

column1: This isn't a total war game. This is a game where every single unit has their own AI. No matter how many millions you put on the battlefield. In large battles
column2: the bodies start to pile up. Literally. Every corpse has their own physics and a certain amount of blood that starts to flow according to local topology and pool at low points. You can disable the blood if you really want to
column3: but it's amazing just how realistic it makes a finished battle. The last few units wading through the blood then climbing the hill made from their fallen allies to meet their opponent at the peak.

column1: They pull this off using the GPU
column2: so those requirements aren't for show. They run AI and physics using the obscene parallel processing ability of modern GPUs. As such
column3: even massive battles maintain over 30FPS on my GTX 1650 at ultra 1080p.

column1: I look forward to seeing the roadmap followed
column2: and am excited by the fact there are no firm release dates for the features on said roadmap
column3: which means they aren't crunching to a release date.";2.4;1.0;1.0;276.0;Posted: May 21

column1: I've barely touched this game. Literally got it less than an hour ago. However
column2: I can say beyond a shadow of a doubt
column3: that it deserves a positive review.

column2: I don't have a top-of-the-line gaming PC. It's decent
column3: no doubt about that
column4: but there's plenty of games I have to play on medium or lower settings if I want smooth performance. I went into this game thinking ""oh
column5: sweet
column6: I never had a chance to check out the first one
column7: and people say this one has even better performance
column8: maybe I'll give it a try."" At that point I was expecting my epic fights to consist of MAYBE 1000 guys vs 1000 guys.

column1: Fast-forward half an hour and I'm simulating an epic battle between 1000 sherman tanks and 1
column3: 000 spartans. That's right
column4: ONE. MILLION. Not only that
column5: I was running it on high graphics settings
column6: and my fps never dropped below 30. I don't think I've ever had one million of anything on this PC without it instantly exploding.

column2: would watch 100
column3: 000 chickens body 100
column4: 000 spartans again.";5.9;1.0;1.0;209.0;Posted: May 19

column1: It is early access build when I am writing this so a lot is probably going to change. I am really excited about this game and whats to come. They only thing that bothers me is the footmen models. I would like it if they got more diverse for example some of them have cloaks
column2: some have chainmail
column3: some don't have helmets
column4: some have different types of helmets
column5: and it would be cool for more weapon types like maces and axes. Other then that the game is amazing but still has many bugs like the RTS mode bugging units so they cant move and they get stuck on each other a lot and then stop moving completely. The there are 5 HUGE maps and 13 units right now. The battles can get boring some times with little variety in units but it still is very fun even with only 13 units to choose from. I had 3000 spartans fight 1000000 persians and still got a crispy
column6: tender

column2: it'll be more fun when modding tools comes into it. Personally
column3: I would like a slightly cleaner UI because it looks rough. The new engine is incredible
column4: It is so much easier to run this than the first game with wayyy more units
column5: amazing (I used to be able to run max 20K in 1 but 1.8 Million in this one). More options for graphics is really good. The aiming is still janky as all hell and a slight incline makes shooting pointless. Aim should always personally be spot on 95% of the time or at least 90% of the time
column6: not 80% as standard. Health points are really weird because soldiers can just rambo through bullet after bullet when in reality
column7: without plates or heavy armour
column8: they can only take 1-5 max before dying. Sound is decent but obviously it's been toned down for rendering purposes so it can sound a little weird but that's really not an issue. Artillery if added in the future should take noise priority regardless for more immersion (possible audio option in the future?). The shooting AI is mostly braindead
column9: rushing into bullets without going prone or taking much if any cover. AI should not have to stop moving in order to attack. Unsure if that's an issue with rendering or not. Grenades for soldiers would be nice. Dynamic health dependant on armour feels realistic and that's great. Attention to detail was a really nice touch in maps and on characters however everyone feels like a clone but again that's probably a rendering feature. a set of 3 versions for each unit with tiny differences would be nice but I don't expect it because of rendering issues potentially. However these are mainly smaller things. The most glaring problem is the ugliest UI I've seen in a game. Other than that it's an incredible game
column10: it feels a little bit like a copy paste with a better engine
column11: but with some new features. added. I'm almost certain this game can thrive. Good job.";4.6;1.0;0.0;107.0;Posted: May 16

column1: I didn't even know there was an UEBS1 let alone an UEBS2. I came across this game quite accidentally within my Queue.

Curiosity got the best of me so I checked out the videos and the reviews. Then I decided that for about $20 bucks it was worth a try. I must say that even though this title is an Early Access Game it's fun to play. Sure it's limited with what you can do
column2: but it it has so much potential. I really hope that Brilliant Game Studios follows through with the final development of this game. Between them and the community there is an opportunity to really make something unique here.

column1: The sandbox mode is the only thing you can play around with currently. Even with the limited characters that you can use you can still have fun adjusting the size of the armies and create different scenarios. Speaking of which
column2: just make sure you meet the minimum requirements to play this game otherwise your rig will have a hard time processing extremely massive battles. This game is decently optimised and is almost like running a benchmark when you play it. Even a high end PC will be pushed to its limits if you let it. ""Yes"" the battles can be that large.

column1: Just be aware that UEBS2 is still an Early Access Game and it has its share of bugs. Some are having problems in getting the game to load. Also
column2: if you get bored easily then you might want to avoid this game in its current state. But the way I see it is boredom easily sets into the boring mind. As for me this game will be a good addition to my library because it's a blast to watch the battles unfold and command different strategies. Especially when you have a million battle ducks fighting a hundred thousand zombies. You're about to get ducked! Cheers!";11.7;1.0;0.0;427.0;Posted: May 16

The best way to explain my feelings on this game is through a story. So this monster cockroach had taken up residence in my bathroom for like the last year but whenever I tried to catch him he would always slip my grasp. About a week ago I finally corner the bastard in a cartoon box. I find a way to maneuver the roach into the toilet without wasting any time
column2: and a sense of victory washes over me. But is this enough? Oh hell no I want this ♥♥♥♥♥♥ to suffer. I decide I'm going to drop a load on him before I flush him
column3: a dishonorable sendoff. So I get on the toilet and start going to work. It starts coming out and this is one solid log I had been holding on to for about half an hour I aim by looking through my legs
column4: all is going well
column5: the log is right on coarse. Eventually it makes contact
column6: and this is when all hell breaks lose. The roach goes full rambo and climbs UP MY ♥♥♥♥ towards my butthole! I panic and start jumping around like a 50's housewife who just spotted a rat. Mind you my log hadn't been broken yet so I'm spreading that ♥♥♥♥ all over the bathroom in the process. Best part? The little bastard got away. Now I'm sitting on my computer procrastinating cleaning my bathroom covered in fecal matter.

column2: neo nazis

column1: 1. Preheat oven to 425 degrees F (220 degrees C).

column2: white sugar
column3: brown sugar
column4: water
column5: cinnamon
column6: and salt in a saucepan over medium heat. Bring to a boil
column7: remove from heat and set aside.

column1: 3. Roll out half the pastry to fit a 9-inch pie plate. Place bottom crust in pie plate; pour in apple slices.
4. Roll out top crust into a 10-inch circle. Cut into 8 (1-inch) wide strips with a sharp paring knife or pastry wheel. Weave the pastry strips
column2: one at a time
column3: into a lattice pattern. Fold the ends of the lattice strips under the edge of the bottom crust and crimp to seal.

column1: 5. Pour butter-sugar mixture over top of pie
column2: coating the lattice
column3: and allowing any remaining sauce to drizzle through the crust.

column1: 6. Bake in the preheated oven for 15 minutes. Reduce heat to 350 degrees F (175 degrees C)
column2: and bake until the crust is golden brown

An open-world multiplayer game with one catch... complete and total anarchy.

column2: this is Rust's greatest strength and it's greatest weakness. You start with nothing and progress by gathering resources
column3: building a base
column4: crafting weapons/armors
column5: etc. However
column6: your interaction with the other players is what makes Rust special
column7: as it can keep the experience from getting boring and provides incentive to improve at the game.

column1: Because players can do what they want
column2: anything can happen and THIS is what the game is all about. The game is centered around player conflict
column3: but alliances can be indirectly formed with other players.

column1: Rust can be the most brutal
column2: but also the most rewarding game if you invest the time into it. That being said
column3: I do recommended the game to others
column4: ***so long as you know what to expect going into it.***

column1: - You will die A LOT. Because of the nature of the game
column2: everyone assumes you are a threat before anything else and will kill on sight most of the time. Other players are just toxic... get used to it. This makes it tough to get started but it gets better with experience.

column1: - Your default should be: DO NOT trust anyone. There are some genuinely kind players out there
column2: but weeding out scumbags is a skill itself that can be developed.

column1: - Your base can be destroyed by other players. You'll learn to recover quickly and get back up and running when this happens. With time and practice
column2: you can be the one dishing out the carnage.";2082.0;1.0;0.0;147.0;Posted: May 16

column1: Death is a great teacher. Failure in Counter-Strike: Global Offensive is
column2: as it always has been for this series
column3: the greatest way to learn where you should have gone
column4: what you shouldn't have done
column5: and how you could have done better. Possibly the most addictive
column6: frustrating and satisfying game I've ever played. Counter-Strike players spend a lot of time learning -- consequently
column7: they are always getting better. Growth is an important factor in Global Offensive
column8: especially if you're coming into Counter-Strike fresh or after a sabbatical. This is an extremely hardcore
column9: skill-based first-person shooter
column10: and it forces you to think differently than other modern shooters. If you’re a Call of Duty player
column11: you’re going to need to change your play style to succeed here. Counter-Strike also tries developing into something new here as well
column12: despite doing little to push itself beyond what it’s always done best. Global Offensive modifies old maps to keep veterans on their toes
column13: and introduces official new modes that encourage different play styles for the first time in almost 15 years.";1465.5;1.0;1.0;3.0;Posted: May 16

column1: Kata “hormat” dalam bahasa Ibrani menggunakan kata “kabad” yang secara hurufiah berarti menjadi berat
column2: atau bertambah berat
column3: atau berbobot berat. Pada zaman kuno
column4: sesuatu yang berbobot berat dianggap memiliki nilai yang lebih besar. Sampai hari ini pun harga dari batu dan logam mulia yang dinilai oleh bobot mereka
column5: artinya semakin berat bobot dari suatu batu dan logam mulia maka harganya semakin mahal. Sedangkan untuk orang
column6: yang dinilai adalah bobot keberadaan dan peranan orang tersebut dalam masyarakat dan sesamanya. Semakin berbobot keberadaan dan peranan orang tersebut maka semakin penting dan mulia orang tersebut.

column1: Dalam bacaan kita hari ini menunjukkan bahwa Alkitab mencatat orang tua memiliki bobot yang besar. Para rabi Yahudi kuno mengajarkan bahwa orang tua harus dihormati karena mereka adalah mitranya Allah (God's partner). Mereka bekerja sama dengan Allah untuk adanya seorang anak. Allah adalah pencipta kehidupan
column2: dan orang tua adalah media yang melaluinya TUHAN memilih untuk membawa kehidupan baru ke dalam dunia. Sebab itu
column3: menghormati orang tua bukanlah soal apa yang mereka sudah lakukan
column4: perbuat atau berikan kepada kita. Ketika kita menghormati orang tua sebenarnya kita sedang menghormati peran yang TUHAN berikan kepada mereka
column5: yang olehnya kita sebagai anak boleh hadir dan ada dalam dunia ini.

column1: Renungan bagi kita hari ini adalah: pertama
column2: kita wajib memberikan penghormatan kepada orang tua karena peran yang Allah berikan kepada mereka demi menghadirkan kita sebagai anak ke dalam dunia ini. Kedua
column3: kita harus mau mengampuni mereka
column4: jika dalam membesarkan kita ada kesalahan yang mereka perbuat yang menyakiti hati kita. Jangan merendahkan mereka hanya oleh karena satu atau dua perbuatan salah mereka kepada kita sebagai anak. Jangan kita kecewa akan apa yang orang tua kita tidak berikan kepada kita
column5: sebab apa yang mereka bisa berikan itu adalah semua yang ada pada mereka. Ketiga
column6: jika TUHAN masih memberikan kita kesempatan
column7: buatlah segala sesuatu yang baik dan membahagiakan orang tua kita selagi kita hidup. Cintai dan sayangilah mereka
column8: yang memungkinkan kita ada hidup sampai saat ini. Keempat
column9: ketika kita menjadi orang tua
column10: buatlah apa yang baik kepada anak-anak kita seperti yang kita kehendaki diperbuat orang tua kepada kita sebagai anak. Jangan sekali-kali melanjutkan apa yang tidak baik dari orang tua kita kepada anakanak kita saat ini. Ingatlah
column11: bahwa anak-anak lebih memperhatikan apa yang orang tuanya lakukan ketimbang apa yang orang tuanya katakan. Kelima
column12: kita menghormati orang tua kita dengan cara menjadi orang tua yang terhormat dalam membesarkan dan mendidik anak kita. Kita dapat mengasihi orang tua kita ketika kita mengetahui berada di posisi yang sama dan melihat nilai yang sama sebagai orang tua. (YMH)

column1: The Fire Spirit card is unlocked from the P.E.K.K.A.'s Playhouse (Arena 4). It spawns a very fast
column2: area damage
column3: short-ranged Fire Spirit with low hitpoints and moderate damage. It resembles a small chunk of flaming coal. Fire Spirit launches itself at its target when attacking
column4: destroying itself on impact. It is the same as those spawned by the Furnace. A Fire Spirit card costs 1 Elixir to deploy.

column1: The Fire Spirit's area damage is very useful against swarms of weak
column2: small troops like Goblins
column3: Spear Goblins or Minions. However
column4: due to its relatively low health
column5: placing it next to these units will result in it dying before it can attack. Placing the Fire Spirit at a distance allows it to safely deploy.

column2: you want to place it close to her instead
column3: so that it is killed as part of its attack instead of being killed by the Mother Witch
column4: otherwise she will spawn a Cursed Hog from it.

column2: a Fire Spirit can damage all the Lava Pups just as they explode from the Lava Hound
column3: defeating them.

column2: an effective strategy is to pair it with troops that deal high single hit damage but are easily stopped by the small troops mentioned
column3: such as the Mini P.E.K.K.A. and Prince.

column1: The Fire Spirit will connect to a Princess Tower provided it is equivalently leveled. Although it can easily be stopped
column2: its cheap cost often lures out cheap spells and can cause opponents to over-commit Elixir-wise with their defenders. If used at the start of a match
column3: it can also act as a way to tell what deck your opponent is using based on the card that they use to stop the Fire Spirit.

column1: Fire Spirit can compliment pushes effectively due to its good cost-to-damage ratio and fast movement speed. For example
column2: if the player is pushing with a P.E.K.K.A. and Fire Spirit behind and the opponent drops Minions to counter for example
column3: the Fire Spirit drops the health of said units to be finished off by a Zap or cheap ranged units to protect the P.E.K.K.A
column4: letting her continue towards the tower without taking extra damage.

column1: It is most effective with fast moving troops like the Hog Rider
column2: as they will not collide with each other as much during an attack.

column1: A Hog Rider and Fire Spirit combo can make short work of Cannons.
The player can use units to soak it up. For example
column2: the Skeletons or another spirit result in a neutral Elixir trade.
a Furnace costs 4 Elixir and can spawn up to 7 Fire Spirits
column3: giving the player almost twice as many Fire Spirits for their Elixir. It can allow for more consistent chip damage to Crown Towers and can bait spells due to its cost. However
column4: the Fire Spirits do not spawn all at once
column5: and its upfront cost is higher
column6: so in a situation where the player needs quick area damage
column7: the Furnace is much less versatile.

column2: it is a good idea to combine the Fire Spirit with spells to defeat certain troops for a low Elixir cost. With a Zap
column3: it can defeat anything up to Wall Breakers
column4: with Arrows
column5: it can defeat anything up to Skeleton Dragons
column6: with Fireball
column7: it can defeat anything up to a Night Witch
column8: and with Lightning
column9: it can defeat anything up to an Inferno Dragon. Use these combinations when you are lacking better counters for these troops or to get a good Elixir trade that would be granted compared to using two Spells.

column1: Pairing the Fire Spirit with Electro Spirit is very effective
column2: as they both cost 1 Elixir
column3: which will only use a total of 2 Elixir. This combination can take out units such as Princess
column4: Minions
column5: Archers
column6: Bomber
column7: Firecracker and can even completely stop a Goblin Barrel with the help of the Princess Tower. This combo can help a lot of decks which try to bait The Log or Arrows
column8: since the combo is very effective against swarms. It is also good on the offensive side
column9: having more damage potential than The Log and can hit air. The player should make sure to deploy the Spirits a short distance from their targets to ensure they can finish deploying and attack successfully.

column1: Although the Fire Spirit’s area damage radius is not enough to completely stop a tower-centered Goblin Barrel
column2: there is still a way to counter the Goblin Barrel with Fire Spirit
column3: although 2 of the Goblins will still get one hit on the tower (240 total damage at tournament standard). Place the Fire Spirit on the tile directly behind the tower
column4: and if timed correctly
column5: the Fire Spirit will push one of the goblins toward the tower
column6: and it will one-shot all 3 goblins. This trick is very precise but can be pulled off consistently with practice. A tip for timing: Place the Fire Spirit at the exact moment when the Goblin Barrel is one tile above the river.";22.5;0.0;0.0;30.0;Posted: May 22

column1: Loaded the game up for the first time and was immediately ear-raped by an e-sports broadcaster and booming dubstep. Main menu is so busy I got anxious just trying to find the options to silence all the manic e-sports noise. Played a few rounds against bots to shake the rust off (I used to play competitive 1.5 and Source back in the day) and instantly remembered why I left CS behind. We've come a long way with shooters since the Source days
column2: and nostalgia aside
column3: there's just nothing here for me anymore.

column1: 70k players have found something that appeals to them about this
column2: and I won't argue the charm of a simple

The standard game mode (Bomb Scenario) involves either defending or exploiting a bomb site. I spent most of my test-play time playing this mode
column2: but I did branch out to the Arms Race and Hostage modes. Most competitive matches that I've watched stick with the Bomb Scenario match type
column3: as well
column4: which is another reason for the mode's popularity.

column1: The Bomb Scenario mode comprises a maximum of 15 elimination-style rounds that last until one side wins a majority of the rounds. Players spawn either on the Terrorist (T) or Counter-Terrorists (CT) side
column2: which determines the objective. Terrorists need to plant a bomb at one of the two marked bomb sites on the map. The CT team must prevent the terrorists from planting the bomb or defuse it before it explodes (the bomb has a countdown timer of 40 seconds). The defuse process itself takes 5 seconds
column3: so getting to the bomb site quickly is a priority. Of course
column4: eliminating all the players on the other side makes this objective easier
column5: so keep an eye out for enemies at all times.

column1: CS: GO's Bomb Scenario mode is a simple
column2: yet enjoyable
column3: twist on the standard multiplayer FPS setup
column4: which opens up a ton of variability in each round. Another game mode
column5: called Hostage
column6: flips the tables and has the Terrorists defend a hostage
column7: while the Counter-Terrorists attempt a rescue mission. CS: GO typically gets new mission-based modes with new operations. The current operation
column8: Operation Hydra (released in May 2017) brought War Games
column9: Wingman
column10: and Weapons Expert modes to the game. These modes introduce twists on regular gameplay and affect the available weapons
column11: the match objective
column12: and the playable maps. These operations typically include a narrative-driven campaign
column13: too.

column1: Along with making the game free to play
column2: Valve added a battle royale mode called Danger Zone. CS: GO's take on this latest gaming craze is much smaller in scale than that of Fortnite and PUBG. Instead of the typical 100-player matches
column3: solo matches are restricted to just 16 players and team modes are capped at 18 total players. The map size is also much smaller than those in either of the other titles.

column2: players get to choose a spawn point on the map. Each drop point is limited to a single player
column3: so make sure you choose your preferred spot quickly. Matches unfold in much the same way as in any other battle royale game. Your goal is to eliminate all the other enemy players or teams. You must scavenge for weapons
column4: avoid taking damage from the random bombings
column5: and keep pace with the ever-closing boundaries of the play area.

column2: CS: GO does bring some unique mechanics to the genre. For example
column3: as the match progresses
column4: you can purchase weapons and items
column5: which are delivered by drone to your location. Be aware that these drone deliveries can reveal your hiding spot
column6: though. Another cool mechanic is the in-game map that highlights the regions where either you or enemy players are located. The map is not detailed enough to give away specific locations
column7: but the information it provides is helpful for planning your next movements. CS: GO also has the upper hand in terms of combat mechanics. Weapons and movement especially feel more accurate than in Fortnite and PUBG.

column1: All these factors make for a much more condensed and manageable experience. I particularly enjoy that matches tend to only take about 10 minutes from start to finish. In terms of potential improvements
column2: I would like to see a few additional maps and gameplay variations
column3: such as a one-on-one mode or an eight-person team mode.

column2: Equipment
column3: and Combat

column1: When I first started playing CS: GO
column2: I was confused by the weapon purchase system at the beginning of each round
column3: and I suspect most newcomers will feel the same way. Basically
column4: at the beginning of each round
column5: you have a certain amount of money to purchase weapons and other equipment for the round. In the first round
column6: you only have enough cash on hand to buy a pistol and one other item (I talk about equipment a bit later). During the round
column7: you earn additional cash by eliminating enemies and
column8: of course
column9: for your team winning the round. The losing side also gets some cash
column10: but the cost of multiple weapons
column11: grenades
column12: and other equipment quickly adds up
column13: so winning teams and skilled players will have the tactical advantage. In later rounds
column14: players on both sides have more than enough cash to buy multiple weapons and items.

column1: Terrorists and Counter-Terrorists have access to most of the same weapons
column2: and the ones that are different are balanced with each other. CS: GO organizes weapons by type: pistols
column3: shotguns
column4: submachine guns
column5: rifles
column6: and machine guns. Generally
column7: the more powerful the gun
column8: the more it costs. However
column9: don't simply buy a weapon because it's the most expensive one. Take some time to experiment and find a loadout that works for you. You can carry up to two guns (a pistol and something else)
column10: which is always a good idea
column11: for those times you are caught by an enemy mid-reload. There are also quite a few fan favorites
column12: such as the ""Deagle"" (Desert Eagle pistol) or the AWP (a powerful sniper rifle) that tend to make an appearance in most matches. One recent addition
column13: the R8 Revolver
column14: has a distinct feel; the trigger-pull is slow
column15: but it is highly accurate and powerful once it fires.

column1: At the beginning of each round
column2: players can also purchase equipment. The equipment list for either side is mostly identical. The main difference is that CTs have a bomb-defusal tool and the option to purchase a rescue kit (which cuts down on time it takes to rescue a hostage)
column3: while terrorists get C4 to plant at the bomb site. Both teams can purchase a Kevlar vest and helmet (you start out with these in casual modes)
column4: and a Zeus x27 (a one-hit-kill electrical weapon). You also have access to a wide range of grenades and decoys
column5: which can really disrupt a team's progress. For example
column6: the flashbang grenade emits a blinding flash of light that renders your vision useless. Smoke grenades are a great way to cover movement across exposed sections.

column1: CS: GO relies heavily on reaction time and twitchy movements. Thus
column2: line-of-sight is one of the biggest advantages you can create. Of course
column3: that also means
column4: that other players can camp out at locations where they know they can catch unsuspecting enemies off-guard. The central path in Dust II (which you must jump past to avoid sniper fire) comes immediately to mind.

column2: but the damage system may require some adjustment. Basically
column3: unless you use a rifle
column4: you need to hit an enemy several times (in high-impact body areas) or many times (in the arm
column5: leg
column6: or stomach) to eliminate them. Reload times on more powerful weapons are also longer than what I originally anticipated. Note that your character's movement speed depends on the type of weapon you carry. So
column7: in effect
column8: you will be able to move more quickly equipped with a pistol
column9: for example
column10: than with a machine gun.";56.8;1.0;0.0;187.0;Posted: May 20

column1: Personally I like CSGO more than any other FPS and here is why (This is totally my opinion and may be different for you too so be easy lol)

column2: Halo
column3: Battlefield
column4: ect... players actually have a brain and use it towards sticking together and making sure they clear the round and aren't running around like headless ♥♥♥♥♥ trying to get the most kills.

column1: 2. You feel really competitive unlike any other game I have personally played (coming somewhat close to Halo.) And once you start getting better and start to understand where to use which guns or figuring out your favorites
column2: you will splurge on CS for hours.

column1: 3. Players are nice and feel as if they got your back
column2: which makes any co-op game a huge plus. you will get a few cheaters here and there since they made the game free way back when and have been struggling with it for years
column3: but when you get a legendary team it makes your day.

A decent first-person shooter game. It is unique when compared to other games in its genre because of certain aspects like game customization (players can utilize a developer-like console) and the movement of a player's avatar. Game customization is fairly deep with commands that can change/modify game settings
column2: network settings
column3: the UI
column4: and much more. The movement is unique because the avatars do not completely stop when releasing a keybind for movement
column5: nor do they instantly reach max speed when pressing down on a keybind for movement. This promotes complex mechanics for maneuvering and facing targets
column6: bots
column7: or enemy players.

column1: I recommend this game due to everything that was previously mentioned
column2: but there are some cons to the game. Most gamers can attest to a trend of cons that are caused by certain groups of player communities. These include botting
column3: hacking
column4: griefing (in-game toxic behavior) and scamming (trading in game gear/skins with other players). My only advice to stay away from these parts of the game is to disengage from the aforementioned actions yourself
column5: and to build a ""Green-Trust factor"" with Steam (this you can research this online or in the Discussion Board). For the most part
column6: I've been able to keep away from these types of players
column7: but I've still become wary of them after my first 50 hours of gameplay in the casual environment. Happy gaming everyone!";181.9;1.0;0.0;1.0;Posted: May 16
